Absolutely amazing game, the great story, the great gameplay, its all so good, read the books too, you'll love them as much as the games 10/10
God bless 4A Games

Just as good as the first game with a few upsides and downsides. The story and combat are vastly expanded upon from the first game. But some of the surface levels felt a bit dragged out. This game never gives you a break so get ready to have your butt cheeks clenched.

Last Light make up the grind for achievement better since the last game. The story for this one was more dramatic in this one. As for the 9 DLC's are nice since some give a bite more lore of the game as well a museum for all the assets of the game up close. Really excited to play Exodus.

Having played Metro 2033 before, I didn't have high hopes for Last Light. I generally don't like horror games or games that involve mindlessly gunning down mutant monsters but this game ended up being one of the best games I've played. Like the first game, the post apocalyptic setting and atmosphere are the biggest strengths of this game. However, the general plot line, pacing and gameplay felt much better than its predecessor. Even though I got the "bad" ending because the Metro series has a somewhat stupid morality point system, the whole experience was super immersive and intense. 

8.9/10
good gameplay, good story, and good experience
The whole Metro trilogy is incredible!
Original apocylpse experience with real life stimulation inventory management system
better than half life 2
A mix of horror and action and a great story line. Totally worth it
This game fucking rules
scary af
Great story lovely
Fuego

The game was playing fine, until a couple chapters in. It crashed at a certain point. After that i started in safe mode and the game kept crashing, always at the same place in the level.
Then i made the mistake of not starting the game in safe mode and now the game won't start at all. Even after verifying the game integrity and a reinstall.
This is after i noticed certain options weren't changing (mouse sensitivity) and the game having a narrow FOV. Plus cutscenes are locked at 30 fps
Underated game, maybe better than fallout
real fun

Metro Last Light Redux is beautiful and compelling in every way imaginable. While I think the first one was more horrific and darker than this sequel, this game manages to keep everyone on their feet with the continuation of Artyom's story with plot twists, redemptions, and a meaningful karma system. Listening to background conversations and 'various forms of entertainment' was pretty neat. I replayed the main story twice because I got the bad ending the first time, and I was motivated to retry to get the good ending. Playing a second time forced me to rethink my playstyle and the way I see things, and I was perfectly content with it. There are many ways of going around things and many outcomes. 

The best immersive playstyle is on hardcore ranger survival. That is the best and only playstyle, in my opinion. I also enjoyed the extra DLC missions such as the developer room, last stand, character, sniper, and simulation missions. I despise the spider mission for obvious reasons. There's a lot to do, and the game is easy to get all achievements for completionist runs. It is one of the best sequels to post-apocalyptic games and stands tall compared to Fallout and Stalker in its own way.

Last Light has the exact same tense survival gameplay and same excellent Sci-Fi/Horror writing as the first Metro 2033 game. If you liked that game then this direct sequel is simply more of that, but with a longer story and a few new weapons. 

The original Complete Edition is no longer available for purchase and is also not even listed anymore so just buy this game. The Ranger difficulty is actually included with this version instead of as a paid DLC and all of the Redux remaster's improvements to optimization, graphics & gameplay (more weapons) make the game better. This version also includes all of the extra mission DLCs of the previous Complete Edition.

Another funny russian story - great job guys
Loved that funny russian dude - very awesome guy
Not quite sure why u made us have sex with russian woman tho - she a bit of a let down

Much like its predecessor, Last Light is a gloomy, atmospheric narrative-shooter set in the post-apocalyptic metro of Moscow 20-some years after the war that ended the world we know. If you enjoyed Metro 2033 and want more of Artyom's story, pick this game up without hesitation. Jumping on here won't make much sense as this is a very direct sequel, although it does assume a specific ending from 2033 regardless of what ending you actually got, which is a bummer.

Excellent game, great story. You can run and gun it in spartan mode or slower more careful in Survivor mode. Set up so if you want you can play through and get the standard ending spartan and then follow a guide to get all the rest of the achievements and the good ending in survivor mode.

I am ready for the last part of this saga.
this feels like the only FPS game with a meaningful story
still 1 one of the best FPS game
an action packed or stealthy adventure through ruins and tunnels in post apocalyptic moscow, go on spiritual journeys, save aliens/mutants or don't, it's pretty cool.

It's got good gameplay overall, but more than once I'd find myself trying to figure out where to go next, and the compus didn't help at all. There were also times where I'd take unavoidable damage, which is a real problem in a game that focuses so heavily on survival and keeping your health topped up. 

My biggest issue with this whole series, that focuses so heavily on immersion, however, is the way they decided to indicate damage to the player, with the most obnoxious flashing red and heartbeat sound that would even follow you over into cutscenes if you had the misfortune of not finding a healthpack before entering one.

If you're hungry for STALKER you'll enjoy it, just expect to get even more frustrated at this game than those ones.
Very fun game, definitely my favorite in the metro series
10/10. Amazing story, fun game play. Definitely different than the first one, not as "horror" based and more of a stealth action game, but highly enjoyable.
Gg Franchise

Metro Last Light is a great game and sequel to the first, With amazing graphics, visuals and environments. Great gameplay, and atmosphere, as well as a fitting continuation to the story that started in 2033.

The graphics matched the redux-ed 2033, which are great for a game its age, but what it excels is utilizing these graphics and also the amazing environments its has to make some stunning visuals and vistas that are screenshot worthy.

The gameplay improved from the original 2033 game, but the redux 2033 had the gameplay elements added in the original last light to it, and this one stayed with that, and they were good and still are, consistent and easy to get used to across both games, yet very fun to play.

The story was actually great, with plot twists, and expansions to the lore, and exploring some morality type system as well. 
This game has choices without it being obvious, but every single thing you do in your play through is being remembered by an invisible to the player, morality points system. it can range based on kills you commit, or dont, to conversations you listen to, or dont, and many other things.

Overall this is a great game and great sequel that is very fun to play, and replay, multiple times over. I definitely recommend it, with the 2033 Redux as well!

Suffers somewhat from the it's-perfectly-okay-to-engage-in-the-indiscriminate-slaughter-of-thousands-of-unnamed-grunts-who-are-just-following-orders-but-it's-morally-reprehensible-to-kill-the-truly-evil-fucks-pulling-the-strings trope, but other than that it's a great game.

i love this game, its a ton of fun! the guns are cool and allow customization, the levels lean into stealth really well and allow you to still go guns blazing if you want or any in between but the element of surprise is a huge advantage that you'll wanna keep hold of!  the game looks both beautiful and a lil ugly but its great! the story uhh i played this game a bunch of times and i forgor the story lol but is cool theres a cool guy and twist villian that is really chill and a totally fun character, he's always fun to see :)  theres also a bunch of side content involving missions and a arena thing and they are kinda hard but still super fun! over all these games are pretty cheap and are really fun so if you think you might wanna play then totally pick it up and give it a try!

I edge to Anna

A worthy successor to the first game. The main story is phenomenal, you have moral points and depending on your choices you get either a dark and depressing ending or a good and optimistic ending. So there is definitely replayability value and many weapons to choose from.
Theres a lot of DLC's, most of which add a new perspective to the main story, most of the dlcs are amazing, especially "Kshatriya".
Can't wait to play Exodus, althoug when I finish it, I'm gonna feel empty inside and sad.

I like how the dark ones expect you to spare genocidal maniacs in order to forgive you first for wiping them out, something you wouldn't have done if they didn't suck so much at communication in the first place.

I also find ironic the fact that they look down on you for taking lives in order to protect others but proceed to kill hundreds of Reds while having the ability to knock them all unconscious at once.

P.S: I got this comment under a YouTube video. Thanks jonr9467.

Metro Last Light Redux does the same thing 2033 Redux did.. but better.
I've only played Redux versions of the games, but I loved them. So much. And this one.. oh my god. It holds nothing back and its amazing. Please, play this game.

The 2nd installment of the franchise is great. I like that its similar to the 1st game, in terms of mechanics, graphics, story, etc. and it doesn't include major changes. The story is again unique and gameplay is enjoyable. There are no bugs and not insanely hard levels, the achievements are easy to get, and just like the previous game, this one makes you replay the game again to see both endings and play on both difficulties. I did however experience a few random crashes, it didn't bother me. The game also has a few dozen DLC levels where you play as certain characters from the game plot and experience their POV. Overall the game is unique and it displayed the slavic/russian culture greatly, especially seen in the theater part. Runs great on newer systems. I would recommend. 9/10

If you're looking for an action shooter with a good story, this... ain't it.

Half the time I had no idea what was going on. The story just isn't told in an engaging way so it just seemed like it isn't well put together. I kinda felt the same with the first game but I think I'm getting outta the Metro at this point.

The game stood in my library untouched for a long time. Gave it a go as I had a rare craving for a FPS - and lo and behold, it's a really great game! You can see that a book inspired this as the setting is already dripping with atmosphere and structure and the devs really did well with the visuals to enhance that. The mechanics are basic, but fun enough. Play on harder difficulties for a more interesting experience.
the best metro of all the metro series
If you played the original one then i suggest playing this version too it's just as good.

Having all of the 4 released games after, I still have replayed this old story,  and it was fun and exciting as it was when I played the game a few years ago for the first time and at that time, the excitement of being part of such a story was amazing, and it felt almost the same now. I' awaiting for the Next Metro!

Metro Last Light beats Metro Exodus 10times harder, these classic ones are way better made in many ways. stories,characters,environment. Last Light and 2033 feels way more apocalyptic and the living in the metro's felt amazing while as your story goes through it.

It's been years since I uninstalled Last Light, and I have no desire to complete it. This game's atmosphere paled in comparison to the original Metro 2033. It was similar to Dead Space 1 vs 2 in that the original had a horror feel while the sequel had an action combat feel. 

Unlike Dead Space 2, however, Last Light was simply boring to me. I think the issue was its too straightforward gameplay, especially with human enemies. 2033 balanced people and demon problems, and generally felt like you fought to survive. There was no reason to pursue the enemy and decimate them because it was not worth it. Last Light felt like fighting just because. I could kill everybody if I wanted to and still have extra ammo left over. I got tired of the constant stealth missions through bandit or soldier bases. Going to the surface had always been scary, so I enjoyed the brief moment where I had to go outside. Then I went back underground to the human-centric combat, which is where I stopped when I uninstalled. 

There were several combat sequences in Last Light that I think were intended to make you feel like you were in a pinch, but to me they didn't feel high stakes. For example, Last Light had a moment in which you defended yourself on a small raft while monsters flew out of the water at you. Sure you were fighting in close quarters, but that was about it. In 2033, there was a fight in which you were carrying a kid with one hand, stumbling in the dark with narrow field of vision as monsters darted out of holes and lunged at you. You relied on the kid on your shoulder to yell at you so that you could turn around and protect your back. And don't forget in 2033, there were engagements with a special monster that you could NOT afford to kill. Staring them down was the best -- and most unnerving -- option. Recalling those moments makes the pit of my stomach crawl. 

TL;DR Last Light felt like standard fps with some spooky designed enemies, but that wasn't enough to hold my attention.

Well, that was a bit of a wow game - gave the first game Metro Redux 2/10 - this one 8/10.
Last Light is waaay more interesting than the other imo; fights were more evenly balanced and the story was excellent. Gear was a bit easier to find although I never had enough to buy fancy weapons; got lost in some places trying to find an exit from (say) a burning room until I realised I wasn't really getting hurt.
The mapping and save system are still awful but at least I had some investment in some of the characters this time; I don't think I'd play it again in any sort of a hurry, but I did enjoy it. Gladly purchased in a sale, wouldn't pay full price for it, it's too short.
Good game.

A worthy successor to the first game. The main story is phenomenal, you have moral points and depending on your choices you get either a dark and depressing ending or a good and optimistic ending. So there is definitely replayability value and many weapons to choose from. 
Theres a lot of DLC's, most of which add a new perspective to the main story, most of the dlcs are amazing, especially "Kshatriya". 

There are several glitches present: Sometimes when you are going down a ladder it feels as if you are frozen and moving pixel by pixel (could be an issue due to high frame rate?). Some weapon icons with mods bug and look broken (only the icon so its fine). Sometimes when you throw a molotov or a knife the hitboxes behave really weird and just go thru the enemy without hitting them... Sometimes you can literally get elevated really high up on vertical flat objects as if they are ramps. The frustrating part in the main game is that many times when you are trying to be fully stealthy and kill silently enemies, randomly other enemies have ultra sense and panic and scream for alarm (even though they didn't see or hear anything)

Now lets talk about the extremely painful parts: 
In the Developer pack in the Shooting range as well as Combat arena Challenge 8 but mainly 9/10 are extremely difficult. For several reasons. You are swarmed by enemies non stop, (heavy undead soldiers that take a lot LOT of bullets to die), you have fast monsters + a monster with a lot of health that uses it claws as a shield. The problem occurs that you have limited ammo so you need to be really accurate and try to use it wisely. The other problem is that all your weapons take a long time to reload, but you have no time to reload since enemies attack you EVERY SECOND. From the whole arena since they spawn in all directions you get shot all the time so your best bet is to stay edge map. But the next problem occurs, the AI soldiers literally throw grenades with EXTREME precision and most times you don't hear them from all the shooting you are doing non stop or even if you see it, you have barely anytime to react and run to a safe spot. When using the bolt action sniper you are literally frozen when loading every bullet, so the grenade always kills you.

The Tower pack: Its one of the HARDEST dlc's in any game i've played for several reasons. You fight enemies in large waves, you have a scarce weapon choice, with zero mods, you run out of ammo really quick and reload really slow, at some point you get attacked and slowed down while reloading and you die. You need to keep buying ammo supplies and in some levels buy back up soldiers to help you (which die easily if you don't help them). The enemy soldiers prefire you at all times even when you are behind cover. Its extremely extremely frustrating to finish. (but there is a glitch you could use to get the achievement easily).

what a great game, besides the 2-3 chashes i experienced on a particular level the game has nothing negative, very good atmosferific maps, both stealth and change approaches are well mad.. story??? mindblowing, for a game this old  i wonder why i havent played it so far, maybe its poor advertising but 11 hours just for the story on a 2$ are vfm

The second game in the Metro trilogy and i really have to say is as good or even better than the first part.

The game takes us back to the world of metro, but now seeing more of the world above the metro and the consequences of our actions in the first game.

I love how the surface was crafted for this new game, now we can see even more of how destroyed moscow was left and through some visions in some of the mission how the world was before it and how some people saw the missiles hitting moscow. This game teaches us more about the world, its people and the way it is working now, now its time to redeem us for what we did in the first game in the way facing many foes and proving ourselves as true spartans.

I love how as well as the first game this game feels ALIVE, I really can't explain how even in more of one playthrough I found myself listening to conversations around the metro, listening to the little dark one and trying to imagine the world through his eyes, how every conversation with my fellow rangers felt like a conversation I was having with them even tho we're playing as a silent protagonist, this was meant to be like this and i gotta say the developers nailed it in this game. In their own words Artyom is the player and it really feels this way in the game.

I really feel like the true correct way to play these games is in the difficulty ranger hardcore, having to rationalice every bullet you have, waiting until you're in the blink of death to use a medkit and how it makes both you and the enemies glass cannons makes the experience even more inmersive, first play the game in normal mode to familiarize yourself with the controls and then do a whole new run with said difficulty, trust me is totally worth it.
cccfgc

Fantastic game... rugged and rusty graphics and environments adds to the apocalyptic dystopian future where people live under ground to avoid the radiated topside.

As the protagonist you are conferred with the responsibility to take care of the last surviving member of your race against strange black humanoid  creatures that only you are not affected by.

Graphics: As mentioned above, there appears to almost be no repeating texture and it suits the gaming atmosphere of a future where humans live underground after a nuclear attack.

Sound: Music is almost non-existent. Instead, you are treated to a nice ambient sound that murmurs down the train tracks you must utilize. Sound is excellent.

All in all a good game but with a difficult ending to reach for the "good" ending. It requires multiple replays to get everything right and even then a good gaming guide.

Overall, highly recommended!

My only complain about this game is the fact that you get limited time to enjoy the beautiful scenery because of your gas mask filters running out. 10/10 If you enjoy story driven - FPS games with some survival horror elements.

The sequel of metro 2033 and like 2033 it is perfect. the story is incredible the gameplay and graphics are same as 2033. while playing the game I've encountered an annoying glitch where i couldn't knock out/ kill people because one of the missions corrupted the save. METRO: Last Light-REDUX

Gameplay: Taking into account my review on METRO: 2033 it improves a lot, the enemy AI reacts to deadly injuries by taking cover to keep the shot in cover, the arsenal is also broader but eliminating the electric cannon but introducing long-range rifles and short range. During my game I actually noticed that the campaign is longer which I like and gives more motivation to search for things or see the things I have missed.

Achievements: Includes 49 campaign/weapon/map/DLC/Developer achievements, including the two endings.

Soundtracks: Incredible simply by saying that the main theme is very good, including its downloadable content and the theme of each side to give it a very good atmosphere.

Maps: The scenarios are incredible and very large to collect objects and develop strategies to eliminate enemies.

DLC: Includes about 7 DLCs which expand the story a little or others that are tests including the RPK which is a heavy automatic rifle.

NOTE: Before purchasing this product on Steam, I tried the XBOX One version and I must say that the PC version has problems with some animations that would be good to review for computer platforms.
Those who have the courage and patience to peer into the darkness will be the first to see a glimmer of light in it.

I would like to semi-recommend Metro: Last light. It's well worth playing both for the story as well as for the gameplay, but if you're looking for a canon storyline and/or the same, neat gameplay one had in the two other Metro games, this isn't it. In my opinion having played the 3 games back-to-back, this one comes out the shortest. Keybindings are less well planned, you have less options in how to play and creating your own weapons also is clunkier and less elaborate. The story isn't canon in relation to Metro Exodus (in my experience).
So yeah, definitely playable in it's own right, but I wouldn't recommend it if you want a similar game to Metro 2035 Redux or Metro Exodus.

Metro Last Light Redux: A Gripping Descent into Post-Apocalyptic Moscow
Emerging from the irradiated ashes of nuclear war, Metro Last Light Redux rekindles the embers of the critically acclaimed 2013 original. In this definitive remaster, you don the gas mask of Artyom, a Ranger navigating the claustrophobic underbelly of post-apocalyptic Moscow тАУ a labyrinth of Metro tunnels teeming with mutated horrors, hostile factions, and dwindling hope.

Redux polishes the already impressive visuals, transforming the dank tunnels and irradiated landscapes into breathtaking vistas of decay. Glimmering gaslight illuminates crumbling Soviet stations, while flickering neon paints a desperate beauty across overgrown ruins. Every crevice whispers of humanity's lost glory, while mutated monstrosities lurk in the shadows, their guttural growls a constant reminder of the fragile grip on survival.

The gunplay, while not revolutionary, feels weighty and satisfying. Each bullet precious, each trigger pull a gamble against dwindling resources. Stealth becomes a desperate dance, navigating chokepoints and scavenging for supplies, the ever-present gas mask your lifeline in the toxic air.

But Last Light is more than just a shooter; it's a masterclass in atmosphere. The haunting melodies of the soundtrack seep into your bones, while the guttural growls of mutants and the frantic chatter of survivors paint a vivid picture of a world teetering on the brink. Every decision resonates, each bullet fired carries weight, and the moral ambiguity of survival gnaws at your conscience.

Redux expands the narrative with the "Ranger Hardcore" mode, a punishing experience for veterans seeking an even greater challenge. This mode strips away HUD elements, limits supplies, and cranks up the difficulty, transforming Metro into a true survival horror experience.

However, Last Light isn't without its flaws. The story, while gripping, occasionally stumbles into melodrama, and the open-ended conclusion might leave some players wanting more. Certain sections feel a tad repetitive, and the AI, while improved, can still be occasionally wonky.

Despite these minor blemishes, Metro Last Light Redux remains a masterpiece of post-apocalyptic storytelling and immersive gameplay. Its masterful atmosphere, challenging combat, and morally complex narrative draw you into its desolate world and leave you long after the credits roll. Whether you're a seasoned Ranger or a curious newcomer, Metro Last Light Redux is a journey worth taking.

Verdict: 4.5 out of 5 irradiated rats. An atmospheric masterpiece with satisfying gunplay and a gripping story, despite minor narrative stumbles and occasional AI quirks. Redux polishes the gem that was the original, making it a must-play for fans of post-apocalyptic shooters and immersive storytelling.

Recommended for: Fans of atmospheric shooters, survival horror, and post-apocalyptic narratives.

Not recommended for: Players seeking fast-paced action or a lighthearted experience.

Metro: Last Light Redux is a sequel to Metro 2033 Redux, which is a remaster of Metro 2033, making this game a remaster of Metro: Last Light. As it's in its predecessor, you play as Artyom, now a Spartan ranger, traveling the metros of Moscow after WW3. Set in 2034, this game is a tale of adventure, betrayal, greed, acceptance, redemption and a weird type of love. Based on Dmitry Glukhovsky's Metro 2034, Artyom must atone his past mistakes of striking the unforeseen enemies of the prequel who were actually an ally to him. If you've played 2033 Redux, this game is definitely similar to it. The graphics, ambiance, weapon customizations are practically alike. They added new characters that are important to the plot, a few amazing weapons, we got more areas to explore both in the metro and on the surface, such as the Kremlin, the Red Square, plague-infested Oktyabrskaya Station and the aforementioned flooded station of Venice. Not even that, you also get new content in the form of more short levels, a developer pack and a wave-based mode. My God, I hate the Tower, but I do love Kshatriya. As with 2033 Redux, this game has its fair share of bugs such as the elevator, where the character just jump out to the ceiling and a few NPC bugs. But the worst offender so far is the sudden crashes of the game. I am sick of it, my game crashed more than ten times. I don't know what's causing it, because when you click Continue after the first crash, the game will crash again. The solution I took is to go to Chapters, then to your current mission. Yeah it sucks to replay the mission, even worse if you're doing Ranger Hardcore, hence I would not be doing RH for this game. In the end, even with its bugs, I would recommend Metro: Last Light Redux, I find it to be a great sequel to 2033 and a great addition to the franchise as a whole. This game regularly goes on sale, bundled with the trilogy, so getting the bundle is basically a no-brainer.

I think this game is worse than 2033, but still worth playing.

What I like about this game is that it adds more depth to the other factions. In 2033 it felt like it was more "commies bad" or "nazis bad", but here we get a better understanding of what's going on in every faction. There are also more weapons to choose from and more customizations. The scariest areas in this game are also scarier than the scariest areas in 2033.

What I don't like about this game is that it's too hollywood-esque. In 2033 it feels like every station was just managing to get by, but slowly approaching an independing doom. This game lacked any real sense of existential dread which I think is a subject that's closely tied to this franchise.

Some areas were more frustrating than fun and felt like they encouraged you to just rush through them. Every enemy encounter with a monster felt more like a waste of bullets than a threat that you needed to get rid of if you want to survive. At least human enemies drop bullets and can be stealth killed. Better just hope that it's the right kind.

The most unfun areas were the swamp/water levels where it wasn't always clear where you can walk or not because there's often tall grass or bushes blocking your sight. Some of the enemies in those levels also felt like bullet sponges, but it might be that my aim is bad or that I don't know what their weak spots are.

I really didn't like Anna and it felt like the relationship between her and Artyom was completely pointless. There were however good characters, both major and minor which had just the right amount of focus put on them. Pavel is arguably the best written character in the game. I won't spoil why.

The canon ending feels unreasonably difficult to get, but it doesn't mean that the non-canon ending is bad. I just feel that canon endings should be the easiest to get and alternative endings should require some more effort.

I'm not sure if I'd encourage you to play this on RH survival, at least the first time if you're considering playing it more than once, since ammo feels a lot more scarce in this game than in the previous one. It's not exactly impossible to do it, but running around and waiting for whatever timed objective to complete isn't exactly my idea of fun.

If you liked 2033, then get this game. The gameplay loop is just about the same, at least in the redux versions which are the only ones available for purchase at the steam store rn. If you haven't already played 2033, play that first and consider buying the bundle on sale. As I'm writing this, it costs less than 10тВм on sale so it won't put you in lifelong debt unlike if you'd buy whatever poorly made safe bloatware AAA game with awful optimization that your average big game company decided to publish this month with mandatory DLC worth 10 times the price of the game itself on launch day.

Played through this half a dozen times on console. IMO, despite some jank, the Metro series is one of if not the best atmospheric single player shooters on the market. Little touches really sell the environment, like wiping off your mask, and there are some genuinely tense moments that might have you sweating (friendly advice: you should definitely be playing on the hardest difficulty). Plus, at this point 4A is practically giving the games away, so no reason not to pick it up.

200 character summary
Metro Last Light is a linear story driven horror survival FPS with multiple endings, It has great graphics and some very tense gameplay, Customize your weapons and save the Metro from itself.

Story & Characters 9/10
The Story follows the adventures of Metro 2033, It is also based on a novel with the same name, People are still in the metro because of the invisible threat above ground. You play as the same protagonist from 2033, Artyom, Not much has changed, except for the shift of focus of enemies. I feel the mutants are less considered threats here, Surely you still need to kill them if they attack you, But in the last game they felt like the enemy, And here I feel other humans are the real enemy. The game like 2033 has multiple endings, So maybe that was just the impression the game gave me by the choices I made.

In the last game I did not feel any of the characters stood out or where particularly memorable but I do feel they improved on the NPC characters this time, there was more bonding and faces started to get familiar. Saying I care about their wellbeing is a bit over an overstatement, But it surely improved a lot and I was curious towards them to say the least. The rest of the game felt really similar to the last installment, But that is not a bad thing.

Gamemodes & Gameplay 8/10
There is no multiplayer at all, It is all single player, Mainly the story mode, There are some extra missions which are pretty cool, Chapter select is still there But you can not go back trough normal progress, It is a very linear game, You are rewarded for exploring but any door could close shut behind you. Your choices do matter and in my experience it is rather hard getting the good ending.

Like the previous game you can choose between Survival or Spartan for your run, Spartan is more head on with easier enemies and more ammo while Survival is a more sneaky way of playing where it is better to evade enemies. Then there is Ranger mode which makes the game a lot more realistic in terms of difficulity, 2 bullets will be the end, But enemies go down a lot easier too, If you really want a Survival experience I would recommend going with that. I played the game on Survival, But I went trough it as a Spartan, and I had tons of ammo to spare mostly.

The main story is a shooter with a very tense Horror like atmosphere, There are some parts you have to follow people around or stuff like that, but it did not feel like a chore at any point. There are also a lot of different "New Missions" these are like extra missions you can play and some are pretty cool, There are sniper missions but also wave missions, all kinds of cool stuff that you will enjoy if you like FPS games.

Graphics & Soundtrack 9/10
Like Metro 2033 The game looks beautiful, surely it is all Dark and Grimey, But it creates an incredibly tense atmosphere, The sounds really enhance this feeling. The pre rendered movies look horrible, They have very bad graphics and play in 30fps. It is like it was pre rendered using a microwave. Next to that everything looks great, especially considering the age of the game. I also love the design for some of the weapons, Like the Shotgun Revolver, Who thinks of insane weapons like that.

Performance & Support 7/10
The game runs really well, absolutely no crashes, glitches or bad behavior like that. Like Metro 2033 It does have some issues with Vsync, It works, but not always, Other times you can't turn it off, It is a bit strange, But it is not a huge issue, It also has bad mapping with the default kernel driver using an Xbox One controller, It works fine with Xpadneo, so if you play with a controller, use xpadneo.

Endgame & Replayability 8/10
I am a little dissapointed with the endgame, Like Metro 2033, The game is extremely linear, It is very easy to miss things. There is a chapter select, But it will overwrite your last savegame and you can not go back and clean up the achievements. The replayability is okay, Since it has multiple endings and multiple ways to play. There are also a lot of achievements that are easily missable, If you want to perfect the game it will certainly take you a while.

Conclusion 8/10
Overall, The game is very similar to Metro 2033, At least I see very few differences between the 2 Redux versions, So this review might sound very similar to the review of 2033. Just like that game it surely is a great game worth picking up, And a must have if you like anything related to FPS or Horror. It is a short but thrilling ride a very linear ride but how you ride it is completely up to you, Kill or Sneak. Good or Bad.

Synopsis:
Nuclear warfare destroyed surface civilization, so now experienced Spartan Artym locates the alleged last intelligent surface dwelling creature called the Dark One... a alien like mutant who possesses telepathic and detection abilities. Before a formal acquaintanceship can unfurl, Artym gets detained by "those  from WWII who must not be named". The Dark One gets sold off for 200+ ammunition, the accepted currency of the world. Artym escapes prison with a communist comrade, narrowly escaping the chamber of flatulence, then being imprisoned yet again...by fellow comrade. He escapes to finally egress, only to yet again get separated by a traitor mentioned from casual conversation from the prologue. Yada yada...blah blah.

Bippity boppity boo. You find the Dark One, unveil a conspiracy, and stop the true madman behind the suffering. Do you live happily ever after? Depends on some superficial choices you make throughout the game. Ready?

Endings?
Good Ending:
Listen to people talk, especially if they are suffering. Donate for charity. Never execute and sneak around. If opponents surrender, knock em out with [X = Xbox Controller]. Spare unarmed personnel. Show mercy to most despicable people, only act in self defense. Find a missing Teddy Bear. Assist Comrades in dire situations. Free prisoners, etc.

Bad Ending:
Become Grim Reaper. Spare nobody. Pillage everything. Execute all traitors. Neglect pleading comrades. Be cold and heartless. That's how the Bad Ending is achieved.

Verdict:
Alright game, but stagnant pace due to limitations of NPC script-reading blocking essential passage ways. Prologue drawn out. Game is very much like Call of Duty. Sniper DLC forces you to not take down all targets, enemies prematurely scream "Alert!" when knifed (throw or melee). Tower DLC far out the worst. Difficulty greatly increased on 3rd simulation, useless NPC assistance become 30 second bullet fodder. Overall, an average experience .

7/10

pacing is all over the place
ammo economy is aids, there are sections where you expend thousands of bullets and others when you have three airgun pellets for a boss fight, of course ammo stacks to a measly 40 shotgun rounds so especially in mutant areas you need to camp choke holds with fire grenades or you expend so many bullets its just hopeless, it doesn't really matter that you collected bullets from previous areaas

on the otherhand easily the best parts is clearing out entire bases of reds or nazis, the stealth system can do with improvements but the enemies don't really have goldfish memory like other stealth games and you are not really meant to be able to stealth kill every enemy so it makes the goal more about getting through them rather than mass murder
going guns blazing is also fun, but every enemy has a headlamp for some reason and is braindead easy to headshot

Pros: the world design is fantastic and the whole atmosphere is well crafted. Props to the level designers.
The combat against the human enemies is quite nice actually. One of the better AI experiences you'll have in a shooter.

Cons: the character models seem off to me. All of them have really bugged out eyes.
Sound effects, much like the first game, are very bad. The guns sound like toys and that is a huge turn off.
The character movement is far too slow so fights against monsters are incredibly annoying.
Your character can't carry much ammo at all. This makes fights with humans very annoying because it always seems like you have barely any ammo and the enemies have infinite ammo. I get that they want it to feel like a survival experience but it should still balance out to where enemies have to watch out for their ammo as well, 
geez.
EDIT: forgot to mention this con. The performance is fine in terms of FPS as I had a solid 60fps at all times. However, there is a very annoying micro-stutter issue. It isn't consistent but mostly affects the animations and I see it sometimes when turning horizontally.

Overall, much like the first game, I tried it multiple times and just can't get hooked into it at all.

Metro Last Light is a welcome addition to the story, however it does not fully live up to the original game story wise, not the best title in the series, but by far not the worst. Still written well, the bad ending leaves a bitter taste in your mouth, and the good ending just feels TOO good to be true. 

I have come across a few bugs regarding the new boss fight idea this game tries to bring in, with the Big guys often getting stuck or clipping into unreachable areas. Like behind closed walls, rocks, solid barriers, so on. BUT after you restart the game you should be able to fight them normally.

I should also say that this the first Metro game to actually get a good scare out of me, there are a few scenes that make you feel watched, anxious. AND I'M HERE FOR IT.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handтАФthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedтАФthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 тЩетЩетЩетЩе minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.
what a incredible game story is 10/10 for me its the best action horror game i have ever played , for its age the graphis looks fantastic !! i highly recommend this game
A bit rich and in some aspects worse than the original, but still a very solid game and a welcome addition to the franchise.

A beautiful game made by eastern European dev's 
thank you for making this game 
also the books are great
horrible bug that randomly causes you to use your money as ammo, ruins the game
so good play it
great game really really great game only bad thing I have to say about this game is that it was too short :(

I could tolerate the anti-communism in the first game but this one is even worse, not to mention that after some more play time, the very linear structure of the game is starting to bore me. You have a very limited amount of input which affects the game. You just loot the environment for supplies, shoot or sneak around, follow the very linear story where you have no way to affect any outcomes. It feels like they wanted to make a movie but decided last minute to make it a video game instead. I don't feel like I can recommend this game if you already played the first one, it's just the same shit all the way through.

Very fun gameplay wise, for the most part. I played on hardest difficulty and there were times with mutant encounters that it wasn't fun as much as frustrating. The story of this one is much more packed and can be a drag at some points. Specifically when it came to the "magical" and station politics.
The first 3-4 hours where you are with Pavel then past that is good until it gets muddied down by the aforementioned politics. The story is kinda all over the place in this one compared to the very simple 2033.
It was better in the human combat and of course Anna is a W. Overall I enjoyed the first game more but this one is still very worth the time even with its story issues.
I like the game , it makes me feel comfort shooting these communist and 1939 bastards!!!

Pretty good, Like the previous game. Gunplay feels a lot better, Enemies aren't sponges you can kill majority of human enemies in one hit. Mutants are way beefier i've emptied entire clips into them a couple times for the mutant to just be pretty much unphased. If you aren't securing headshots they will eat your clip like gum.

Story has improved a lot, Main Character is still a huge clown not in a good way. Game is way easier than the previous title and felt like it had twice as much content, I skimmed A LOT of content cause i didn't want to deal with stealth.

Great game and a great story. Literally just continued and made things better from the first. My literal only complaint from the first game was immediately addressed in the beginning of this one. Highly recommend. Starting Exodus next. 9/10
0/10 no Khan sex scene

I've now played all 3 games. Without a doubt, the METRO series is my favorite single player FPS experience. They are a masterclass in how to create tension. The world-building is second to none. I will undoubtedly play all 3 several times over. Exodus is top for me, mostly just due to the weapon customization. They perfected it in Exodus. But the story, the atmosphere, the tension, it's there in full in all 3 games and I am glad to own all of them.

If you find that you are just dominating, up the difficulty, find the sweet spot, you owe it to yourself to experience the heart pounding anxiety of knowing you could die at any moment if you don't keep your head on a swivel.

For a players who love a survivel game

It's fitting that the game is called metro because the plot and every level is on rails, sometimes literally, but always figuratively. There's always just one path forwards with the only choice being an awkward sneak route or the usually more efficient plow straight through route (the AI is great at walking right into shooting galleries one after another). You just keep getting dragged from one bad situation to the next even when its obviously walking into traps or ambushes or bridges that will clearly break, and the game relies heavily on screwing you over in mini cut scenes to advance the plot. I learned to dread opening doors because its usually a mini animation that jams you up until you have walked through it and EXTREMELY frequently sets you up to be screwed over on the other side.

If someone bothered to make a true open world RPG (think fallout 4) out of this it would be spectacular. Otherwise its VERY much just a console game on a PC.
Just a note, Metro Exodus was comparatively much better so they did learn something from these. I hear there might be a sequel to that coming out which I would actually be willing to buy.

If you have heard of this game, which you probably have, it is not unknown that this game is visually outstanding. On my RX5500XT I had the game maxed out with a high framerate, well the majority of the time. the attention to detail is phenomenal, every part of the Metro has been carefully engineered with precision to create the look of a worn and dying civilization. This attention to detail creates an immersive and atmospheric game.



The music is good in this game. As you listen you can imagine the sadness in the citizens of the Metro, it's all based around slow guitar solos, creating a moody, lonely atmosphere.

Such an outstanding game in the genre of FPS singleplayer games and rightfully one of the genre's classics. The atmosphere of the postapocalyptic world is unforgettable, and I very much recommend the whole Metro series to anyone.

it's old, but it looks good and plays well.  the movement is tight and the weapons feel great.  some moments of frustration - a few times I got lost in rooms because I hadn't gotten close enough to some pretty random bit of wall texture required to trigger an exit, and in some later levels I would have liked more air filters so I could comfortably explore more.  also the karma/moral system is a bit opaque.  overall though, an enjoyable game.
Great Story Great Game Great Dance!!

Metro Last Light Redux, the sequel to the acclaimed Metro 2033 Redux, continues the immersive journey through the post-apocalyptic world of the Moscow Metro. Enhanced and refined, Last Light Redux builds upon the strengths of its predecessor, delivering an engaging narrative, improved visuals, and refined gameplay mechanics.

From the outset, Last Light Redux seamlessly continues the dark and compelling storytelling established in Metro 2033 Redux. The narrative picks up where the previous game left off, exploring the consequences of the protagonist's actions and delving deeper into the complexities of the post-apocalyptic world. Characters are well-crafted, adding emotional depth to the overarching narrative.

Graphically, Last Light Redux maintains the series' commitment to creating a visually stunning environment. The enhanced visuals capture the haunting beauty of the post-apocalyptic Moscow Metro, with attention to detail in both the environments and character designs. While it may not showcase the pinnacle of 2023 graphics, the game's visuals effectively convey the atmospheric and grim setting.

A distinctive feature of Last Light Redux is the introduction of propaganda, especially those that negatively portray the Reds, one of the most important factions in the game. This propaganda serves as a tool to shape public perception in the game world. The negative portrayal of the Reds adds a layer of political intrigue that affects the player's understanding of the factions and contributes to the moral ambiguity of the story.

The propaganda against the Reds is not just a thematic background; it actively influences the game experience. Players are faced with situations where trust is scarce, alliances are fragile and decisions must be made in a morally complex environment. That doesn't mean you necessarily have to showcase them as heroes, but what is shown in the game, which is also the main story, crosses all reasonable and unreasonable boundaries. I just think it's something that I should warn you about before you buy the game.

Last Light Redux maintains the series' signature blend of first-person shooter action and survival horror elements. Ammunition remains scarce, and players must navigate the challenges of a world torn apart by conflict. The addition of new gameplay mechanics keeps the experience fresh, and moral choices continue to play a significant role in shaping the outcome of the story.

In conclusion, Metro Last Light Redux successfully builds upon the foundation laid by its predecessor. The game offers a captivating narrative, enhanced visuals, and engaging gameplay, all set against the backdrop of a world shaped by propaganda and political intrigue. The negative portrayal of the Reds adds complexity to the story, making Last Light Redux a compelling experience for fans of the series.

Story is amazing. Replayed 4 times just for it. My PC isn't very good so I can't run Exodus, but the first two games were fine (a bit laggy in some levels for last light, especially when firing weapons). Last light is a bit annoying with its moral points I find. Been trying to get the good ending (which is also the cannon ending) for years. Currently following a walkthrough for all the moral points to get the redemption. But man its hard. Im not talking just don't kill the guards to be a good boy ''hard''. I'm talking ''did you eat your fucking brocoli'' hard. Some of these moral points are almost impossible to get unless you know about them. Its become sort of a running gag in my friend group where we call each other out on the most random actions and say: oh look out, you won't get the good ending (for trivial shit like eating your pizza the right way). Besides that, great game, great series! ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND. The characters, the story, the gameplay is so good. Have fun every time I play it. Just listening to random bs conversations from some of the guards I'm meant to mercissely kill later is absolutely GOLDEN dialogue. The metro series, I find, really dive into the human aspect of the apocalypse and how fucked up it can be for people. Kind of like the walking dead before it went to shit. Even Artyom, despite never hearing him talk to npcs, is so interesting through the various journal entries as well as his thoughts at the beginning of every level. Even if your not interested on completing achievements, I absolutely recomend you get the achievement for collecting all the diary entries from Artyom. For the simple reason that they are all interesting and fun read, and you really get to dive into the psyche of the character you are playing. In the end he is just a normal dude, trying to understand himself and the world around him. He gets praised by everyone for his exploits, yet stays humble and you can see he's just trying to figure out how to do the right thing in a world where that isn't really obvious anymore. Sorry for my rambling, but if your second guessing getting the metro series, I hope this review helps you make your decision and get this game. ABSOLUTELY WORTH IT 100%. Have an amazing life :)

[h1]DO NOT SUPPORT DEEP SILVER (The Publisher)![/H1]

"Paradox of Hope", a game in which a single developer worked on for 4 years was recently DMCA'd by the publisher DEEP SILVER (a multi-billion dollar company). The sole creator of 'Paradox of Hope' owns the intellectual property rights to the game. While the game drew inspiration from certain mechanics and visuals, it did not use any assets from other games, and thus, did not infringe on anyone's copyright. 

Despite NOT providing hard evidence to support their claim, the game was de-listed from the Steam store. The developer suffered mental health trauma as a result and has no money to battle it in court (vs a mega company). 

Research Paradox of Hope. Do NOT "buy" anything published by DEEP SILVER. Don't support companies that use their money and legal teams to actively ruin other people's lives.

Unlike Metro 2033, you can buy filters after the early game, and the ones you find out in the open are actually useful.

Artyom will automatically switch filters when one runs out completely. The only reason to switch manually is if you hate listening to choking noises / if you suspect hostiles are nearby and don't need the distraction.

You will find a LOT of upgraded weapons during gameplay, and you should only upgrade the ones you really, really like.

The "Bandits" chapter is the only one with both a merchant and enemies to fight - this means that if you're patient, you can earn a ton of extra money by swapping your weapons with the ones your enemies were carrying, backtracking to the beginning, selling them, then repeating. It can take awhile, but it's worth it - on non-Ranger modes each gun can sell for 100+, which should leave you with more than enough bullets to last you the rest of the game.

There are two big difficulty spikes in the game, and they both involve defending your position while waiting for something to arrive. Don't worry if you are getting killed all the time, the difficulty evens out after those parts.

Don't underestimate the Nosalis. They got a pretty huge buff from 2033.

Wait for the last ten/twenty seconds of air before swapping filters.

The Throwing Knives are incredibly overpowered, and you can retrieve them.

Ranger Mode is not necessary, the difficulty levels are properly balanced. It's not like 2033 where Easy made everything a bullet sponge.

If you are using an AMD card, turn off PhysX which is enabled by default. Your framerate will thank you.

The Kshatriya mission in the "Factions" DLC is the closest we have to S.T.A.L.K.E.R in the Metro engine for now. It's really good.

You get "morality points" towards the good ending by exploring (and looting) out of the way spots, listening to incidental conversations all the way through (civilians and enemies both), doing good deeds and avoiding enemy casualties. If you explore well enough, you can skip the pacifist angle and still get the good ending though.

Don't worry about getting separated from your allies. They will always wait for you to finish exploring, safe and sound.

Many stealth sections are based around advancing as far as you can without being detected to trigger a conversation that will make the enemies move on to more convenient spots.

With the exception of "Nightfall", none of the boss fights are about pointing a gun at the bad guy and pulling the trigger for a while. There's always an environmental hazard / vulnerable spot to target.

[h1] Overview [/h1]

Metro: Last Light is a story-driven post-apocalyptic experience, with a lot of emphasis on environments, and world design. The game follows Artyom, who races against the clock to save his people, the rangers, from an enemy clan, the Reds, who plan to take over a certain part of ranger territory, called the D6. His journey involves a lot of out-of-this-world experiences, for better or for worse.

[h1] Gameplay/Gunplay [/h1]

Last light's gunplay, to put it briefly, is tight. The guns' recoil is heavy enough to frustrate the player, but forgiving enough to feel fun and exhilarating if the player successfully counters it. The hitboxes are accurate, and the enemies are smart enough when IN COMBAT. However, they are not as challenging when they are not on alert, and sometimes end up being blind as bats. That's a huge turn-off in my opinion. 
The various gameplay elements, (ones not directly part of the combat) gel together perfectly. The intermittent filter replacements (sometimes in the middle of a full-blown firefight), the wiping of the gas mask to get a clearer view, and even the last ditch med-kit usage when you are literally seconds away from death are perfectly implemented mechanics. Deciding when to hit T to swap filters and become vulnerable in the middle of combat, or debating on whether to reload your auto-shotgun, or switch to a revolver while you are being swarmed by watchmen, or thinking about whether to go out of your way for some extra resources, knowing that there's a danger at every corner, will ALWAYS be thrilling.

[h1] The World/Lore [/h1]

The world design and environment are probably the strongest suits of LL. The overgrowth taking over the roads on the surface, or the worn walls of the tunnels, Metro's environments never failed to amaze me. I would take minutes just to look around during the surface levels, with the moisture from my mask distorting my view ever so slightly. The amount of Dishonored vibes it gives me is unreal.
Even walking around in the levels feels immersive. People trying to get accustomed to life under the ground is very interesting. I remember coming across a small play of sorts, carried out using hand shadows, where - upon seeing a dog-shadow on the screen - one of the kids said "Show us something WE know!" It's moments like these that make LL special. A man trying to get to a woman to give her a shot of insulin, only to be stopped by a guard because the woman was infected with a virus, or a bunch of watchmen teaming up on a mama bear who was merely trying to protect her cubs, and completely ignoring the player for the entire duration. These are the moments that show the true state of Metro, where desperate measures are no longer "desperate", they are just a way of life.

[h1] The visuals [/h1]

The game has to have some of the most realistic and cleanest graphics I've seen in my life. I don't know what sort of drugs the 4A engine was on, but does it look beautiful. The lighting is just on-point. The detail on the textures, and the ambient occlusion worked wonders, thanks to how many closed and narrow spaces there are in the game. The volumetric lighting was absolutely *PRISтАФfuckingтАФTINE*. The first time I saw fog, enveloping Artyom, and shifting around, I was just sitting there, awestruck, thinking about how old this game is.

[h1] The story and VA [/h1]

The story was absolutely amazing, I don't even have words. The narrative was delivered very well by the NPCs. I would be lying if I said that I absolutely loved all the characters, but this isn't the game's fault. The circumstances force Artyom into a lot of situations where he has to be the lone wolf, and as an indirect result of that, character development isn't really a strong suit of the game. That being said, I really enjoyed Pavel and Anna's VAs. Pavel going "Yo-moyo" at every random moment always gave me a good chuckle. [spoiler] The moment I realized I was betrayed by Pavel, I fkn lost it. I couldn't believe I let his "tak-tak-tak" get the better of my judgment, and think he was an ally. [/spoiler] Anna's VA felt somewhat stiff at times, when compared to Pavel, but she was certainly better than the other NPCs. However, her and Artyom's relationship was rather... rushed, in my opinion. [spoiler] I can understand that they [i]thought[/i] they were going to die, and that's why they opened up to each other, but there should have been a little more development in their relationship, at least after the quarantine sequence of the game. It happened all too quickly. [/spoiler]

[h1] Final thoughts [/h1]

If one looks at Last Light as a GAME (i.e. gameplay), it is perfect. Period. Amazing gameplay, jaw-dropping visuals, a terrific story, and characters who feel like they belong in the world and have seen a lot of what it has to offer: these things make this a must-play title in my honest opinion. The way it took advantage of my claustrophobia was amazing. Never in my life did a SINGLE entry (be it a movie, a game, or a book) make me excited for the ENTIRE franchise. Until Metro did.

Cheers

Metro: Last Light Redux is a great sequel to Metro 2033 Redux.

In this game you go outside of the metro station more often, it still manages to have the amazing atmosphere and immersion that Metro 2033 Redux had. The story is really good, and the characters are interesting. It isn't the exact same as its predecessor, the missions have new stuff in them and there are quite a bit more weapons. Overall it is more combat heavy than 2033, but not too much and it still manages to be amazingly terrifying at some parts.

I played the game on normal / spartan (spartan was recommended by the game; in 2033, survival was recommended) and as expected the game was really easy, but that didn't really take away from the experience I think.

Graphically it is really good and the performance is also good. It is more of a set piece game than 2033 with bigger fights and great world design, some parts of the game looked very good for how old the game is.

If you liked 2033, you will definitely like this and in general I would recommend this game to anyone who is interested (definitely play 2033 first, the story will make more sense even though it can definitely be ok as a standalone game).

Metro Last Light is a decent FPS with a pretty interesting atmosphere. However, it doesn't really offer anything that uniquely sets it apart from other FPS games. It is just that, a first person shooter, which would be fine at a modern standard but because this game is so apparently old, I wouldn't say it is worth it. Not at full price anyway. There are plenty of other FPS games out there that will give you a much better experience. However, if you happen to find this game on sale, you won't be overly disappointed and you may love it for the lore and world building. For me though, it is unfortunately pretty bland for my tastes.

One of my favourites. The story, the atmosphere, and characters are top notch. If you haven't played Metro 2033, I'd start there as this game picks up from the "bad" ending of that game. I'd recommend you play at least on hardcore for the added immersion.

Like the last game there are two ending you can get, depending on your choices and how you play the game. Listening to conversations, exploring the environment, and not senselessly killing everyone in your path will help you get the better outcome.

Also, in later stages of the game there's a bug that prevents you from being able to knock people out for the rest of the game. In my case it was the Bandits level, and replaying the previous two levels (one of which was purely dialog) fixed it. I also deleted the autosave and the save for the Bandits level (Documents > 4A Games > Metro Last Light) per the suggestions of one steam thread, not sure if it's strictly necessary but it worked for me. Be sure to disable steam cloud saves until you launch the game at least once if you delete the recent saves.

Overall, I'd highly recommend.

Metro: Last Light is the second game in the Metro saga and a sequel to Metro 2033, developed by an Ukrainian studio and loosely based off of a Russian novel by the same name.

An absolutely fantastic game in every way. This game captures the eerie and psychological nature of life in the Moscow metro - after nuclear bombs fall in an alternate timeline, wiping most of humankind from Earth - in a brilliant way.

Everything about Metro: Last Light is near perfect. The story is so well thought out. Last Light takes place after the events following what took place at the end of the first game, Metro 2033. Once again you are Artyom. Consumed by the guilt of having wiped out the Dark Ones towards the end of Metro 2033, you are now on an urgent mission to try and stop the last remaining 100,000+ inhabitants of the Moscow metro from wiping each other out in an all out final war. You do this with the help of one of the Dark Ones who managed to survive being wiped out following the events of the first game.

Levels are breathtakingly beautiful. I love how the game crafts such a sinister atmosphere both underground and on the surface. It's not the mutants alone that add to the uncanny atmosphere while you make your way through the metro; the lights and ambiance play a major role in creating that feeling as well. The mutants on their own wouldn't really be that scary as they are simply a product of a new world after the atom bombs fell.

Metro: Last Light is an absolute masterpiece. A rare gem in a time where games are filled with boring repetitive missions and poorly thought-out storylines.

I love the DLC missions too, especially Kshatriya - they should make a standalone Metro game where you have a massive map in which you are a ranger who is tasked with going through the level and you have to collect items from the surface in order to return back with them just like in the Kshatriya DLC mission. They could sell a brand new map as DLC every 6 or so months, each map uniquely designed with unique and very powerful mutants such as the Librarian or the Rhino or the Shrimp and so on... It would almost be like the game S.T.A.L.K.E.R but in a more Metro-esque way.

Honest reaction and feelings for the game:

"War never change", indeed. In war, there is no winner we are all loser. We lose lives, properties, and important things in our life. It's quite sad but this is how this game was made. The last speech that Colonel Miller said "It is time, Artyom" hits different. This game gave me both love and sorrow, any man who focused on the story line will understand what I said. Also, trusting a friend can be deceiving, I don't want to spoil no more if you wanna know what I'm talking about then you must buy this game (also part of supporting those who made it). This game is a masterpiece no matter how long it was made. Overall, this game is 10/10 for me.

In game reactions, well I like how the graphics was made so smooth and very detailed, no blur (especially when you hit the part where there is a stripper and when Paves invites you into their territory). I accidentally pressed E, it turns out pretty well that 5 bullets I paid was worth it good dancing. There is no glitch or bug in the game. 

Pros:

+ Smooth game play
+ Great story line
+ No blur in every scene very detailed
+ God-tier game
+ Worth it every penny you spend on buying this game

Cons
+ Not at all

Conclusion:
If you like a post-apocalyptic game you must buy and you won't regret it.

i love og Metro 2033 and i put up with all its issues because the experience was really special to me.

Metro Last Light was a game i pre-ordered on the Xbox360. i remember being so hurt by this game. it had day one DLC for spartan mode or something, where you had to pay $5 for a difficulty setting if you had not pre-ordered, so basically you just had to pre-order plus it was cheaper than standard in my region at the time. However the game had a really poor FOV on the xbox 360 and was near unplayable. it also had sections of the game which were faster pace than the original and that made the problem worse.

Now on PC + Redux edition, FOV problem is solved by editing an .ini file. So at the very least the game is playable, good even. My main problem is the general presentation of the game. While 2033 was based on the book and was more subtle in its themes, Last Light is more in-your-face about everything. There were more cutscenes and alot of it feels like an action movie, some slow-mo, always a sense of urgency and the player is sort of told how to feel throughout the chapters. Gameplay is improved.

i think the best thing to come out of all this, is that Last Light sold alot of copies back in the day, and 4A took that money and made Metro 2033 Redux along with the Last Light Redux.

This game itтАЩs like the  developers saw what fell short in Metro 2033 (broken stealth, cumbersome  gun play, weird story telling, lack of background music) then fixed it in Metro Last Light Redux. Very polished!

The pacing and the variety of the levels/missions are great. It's amazing as an atmospheric story FPS. It's very good at creating mood and atmosphere.  So if a post apocalyptic wasteland full of radiated monsters and subway stations populated almost exclusively by constantly warring factions of Russians and Germans scares you, then it might not be your thing.  But keep in mind you play as a very capable military guy, so you're completely able to murder pretty much anything in the game that tries to scare you.

It's more thriller than horror. Dead space is horror, Metro is more about keeping you on the edge of your seat not jumping out of it. When I first played through last light I was in a mental place where it felt so good to just sit and soak in all the misery surrounding you. It was like an outlet for me to feel my depression and just feel the s**t out of it.  Amazing.

I also had such a fantastic time with the enemy Al. Enemy soldiers used alot of teamwork, suppressed, covered friends, and fell back when they felt like they were losing a fight. Mutant Al was even better. They acted like a member of their species, and each different type of mutant fought differently. Moreover, I actually felt like I. was fighting PEOPLE and ANIMALS, not mindless robots.

It's pretty fun if you're into Russian language, radiationally mutated beings, being friends with some of those mutated beings, caring how many bullets you fire and collect. Lastly, being morally good to have the greatest ending. 

If you have any love for emotions or immersion in gaming, this game does the best job, canтАЩt describe how good the Redux is, possibly the best written, immersive emotional game IтАЩve ever played.

Unfortunately Metro Last Light gets low appreciation sometimes because many Americans and Europeans canтАЩt comprehend the glorious Slavic soul and atmosphere.

A lot of Americans end Europeans love casual and easy games such as COD or BF. The Metro series are too complex sometimes for their intellect, yet it deserves a minimum 10/10, they are all true masterpieces.

My review is both in part about my feeling of the game, and the recent BS from Deep Silver. I would like to say this game is very good, but it is not Metro Last Light. It is a story that was taken from a writting room and made into a game. The real Metro Last Light (the book) would have been so much better of a game. In the book it follows Hunter, the polis ranger that gives Artyom the quest thast kicks off the first book and game. If this game was at all like the book we would have seen a much more horror and action filled metro game. (the book) follows Hunter and two other people on a quest in the most haunted and dark tunnels in the metro. In it they encounter a monster that kills people by spewing fog around them in a station that no one ever gets out of. [h1] It didn't really need a remaster, but it's still a masterpiece [/h1]

The reworked version of Metro 2033 in Metro: Last Light's far superior engine makes perfect sense. It offered a chance for 4A Games to go back and fix a ton of things that have been bugging them. To act on lessons learnt from their mistakes the first time round.

The Redux version of Last Light is pretty much the same game as 2033 redux.

And so, here we are. Facing a re-release of a game little more than a year old. A re-release that offers little extra to PC gamers whose rigs were up to the task of running it the first time, that looks almost identical to the version you played last May.

In fact, where Metro 2033 Redux is a lovingly improved version of the original, Metro Last Light Redux is little more than a GOTY version. It includes every piece of DLC released to date and some of the additional weapons have been integrated into the single player story.

Visually the games are practically the same. I played the original and the Redux version alternately, chapter by chapter, and found it easy to forget which version I was playing at any given moment. Not to say that Metro Last Light Redux is bad looking. As I was saying, there is a one year gap between the original game and the remastered version, so it's still a fantastic-looking game. Which is why it doesn't need a remaster.

With so much special attention given to Metro 2033 Redux however, Last Light Redux isn't nearly as essential by comparison. Which is fitting, since it's also the worse game of the two. It's a fine shooter, but fans of the original's survival horror feel were disappointed by the sequel's focus on bombastic combat and boss fights over survival and atmosphere.

A new "Survivor" mode does its best to recreate that feel of Metro 2033 by making ammo more scarce and enemies more aggressive, but it feels little more than an attempt at a quick fix solution. Your mileage may vary on this. Some of you may prefer Last Light's feel. For those that want it, there's a new "Spartan" mode available in Metro 2033 Redux which emulates Last Light's combat system. Be aware that I will judge you for using it.

It makes sense for Metro Last Light Redux to exist on consoles, with locked 60fps framerate and higher resolution being the main selling points. Obviously this doesn't really impact PC owners. If you've not played Last Light before then Redux is worth picking up. It saves you some money over the original version, but if you already own the game there's very little to draw you back and buy it again. Unless you really want another set of Steam achievements.

I don't know why, but I have a weird connection with this game. I don't know if it's because I'm Slavic and I live in a former communist country, but somehow the story, the characters, the ruins of Moscow, they feel so close to me. Sometimes it's difficult, sometimes it's scary and sometimes it's downright annoying.
But despite everything, Metro completely captivates me.
The music is amazing and Artyom is one of my favorite main characters. The way he writes, thinks and acts is truly unique.

You can learn a lot from Metro.
But perhaps the most important thing that you can take is that something you think is a threat and you want to destroy may turn out to be your only salvation.

Honestly one of the best games i have ever played in my entire life. A massive improvement over metro 2033, which i also love to death. 
It is actually a pretty long game surprisingly for an fps title. Yes It is linear in a sense, but there are many nooks and cranies that you will be exploring. And the game doesn't get boring at all. Each chapter is just more insane than the last. The writing is amazing!

The graphics are also great and still hold up for 2023, the AI is also pretty decent and challenging.
It is truly immersive with 7.1 surround and settings set at very high with minimal hud, i have also taken soooooooo many screenshots because everything is so beautiful to look at. I suggest you play this game in total darkness.
I want to mention also that voice acting is top notch, especially when set to russian language. 

There may be some bugs, or a few crashes, but these were few and far in between and don't overshadow the greatness of the game. 
I'm actually glad i have played this game whilst i'm still alive. 
And i DO mean it. Its one in a kind experience! I can't even really call it a game. It is an EXPERIENCE! I will be replaying this over and over again.
