Metro Last Light... there is a lot about this game that I want to say, a lot of things that I want to write in this review.
To be honest I doubt whatever I type here will do justice to how good this game actually is, but here we go.

So Last Light is the follow up to Metro 2033, a post apocalyptic, first person, survival shooter that takes place in the remains of Moscow, where the poor people were force to retreat underground, in the metro, from a nuclear holocaust unleashed by the most powerful countries in the word against each other, and taking the rest of the world with them.
This is a reality that we, I fear are coming closer and closer and it is quite scary, considering actual world events that are taking place at the time of this review.

Now the story of this game takes place a short while after the events of Metro 2033, starting with an investigation into the last survivor of his alien kind to uncovering the truth about what power hungry people are willing to do in order to controll people. All of this, in a journey that can be about forgiving and being forgiven or about revenge and the bad deeds that people are capable of.
The story has a moral driven narrative, based upon the choices you make while playing.

The overall atmosphere of this title is dark, gloomy and foreboding while you are making your way through whatever remains usable in the Moscow underground, or the grey wasteland of what was once a city, an irradiated grave for all the people that weren't able to get to safety. There are also some rare places of color, light and joy, these are the safe heavens of the Metro, the stations where people have gathered into communities, trying to survive the end of days, actually having families and being happy, making music and forming a semblance of the civilization that was once above ground.
These are the 2 stark contrasts between dark or grey, empty and dreadful to light, music and joy.
Both the graphics and sound design capture the overall feel of this world amazingly, bringing to the screen the world portrayed in the Metro books.

The gameplay is a standard FPS affair with quite a few twists that are well suited to the type of experience that the devs aimed to craft. To begin with, resources are finite and you have to be careful how you spend them, bullets, first aid kits, bombs and so on are finite, and on the higher difficulties not very plentiful. You can engage your enemies in 2 ways, be it either in a stealthy manner or guns blazing. I adopted a very conservative play style for my play through of Metro Last Light, taking the stealth approach as often as I could in order to preserve my resources for any sort of unwanted encounter with a boss level enemy or a fight against multiple opponents.

Weapon wise this game has decent variety of them, rifles, SMGs, a sniper, some pistols and even 2 air powered guns. Every gun looks well used, some of them are hand crafted in the metro while others are relics of the world above and are barely kept in working order.

The only gripe I have with this game, and it's silly one, is the English voice acting. It's not bad, far from it in fact, but its the damn stereotypical Russian accent. At some point in the game I had a hard time taking something serious because of how funny I found it. Gonna be honest, stereotypes, tho not always true, make me laugh every time.

This game is worth the price, the story was so good, the gameplay is a breath of fresh air in a CoD dominated market, and the atmosphere is amazing. Metro Last Light is now one of my favorite games ever, and if I managed to convince you that it is worth buying, I hope you enjoy this game for yourself.

A truly worthy successor of Metro 2033 with the same subtlety in delivery and atmosphere and more content. I usually go guns blazing with FPS games but I had much more fun being stealthy throughout the story eavesdropping on everyone before knocking them out. Yes, I am a psychopath.

Still mediocre 5/10

The less : 

- The story is better in the first.
- Build-up and set-up are better in the first one. ( The plot of the first game felt more smooth in terms of progression is gone with a rather boring and unengaging story, I admit in the last few hours I lost all interest and just wanted to finish the game )
- Too many chapters that serve no purpose and are too short, which was better in the first one ( duration length )
- No climax, and the story is far-fetched and cartoonishly portrayed, predictable and annoyingly clich├йd.
- No new mechanics, that must be used.

The pros :

- The game is a little more fun.
- Better art direction.
- Better enemies, mini/bosses, environment.
- More gunfights.
- Better areas and hub.
- Sexy pleasure dancers.
- Improved graphics.
- The AI seems to be legermenetly a bit better than its predecessor.
- Some new weapons.
- The game is oriented more towards action than infiltration, whereas it could be more discreet.
- The mechanic of shooting projectors/lights is there, but the player is never forced to use it, which I think is a shame.
- The soundtrack is still absent, as it was in 2033, which could have helped reinforce the atmosphere if it had been emphasized.
- DLC, which makes it longer and more complete than 2033.

My conclusion :

The writing is laughable except if you have low-standart I guess. 
If you care more about the gameplay/fun you will prefer LL, if it's for the ambient/build-set-up and atmosphere probably 2033. 
But LL atmosphere is not hugely different from its predecessor, but I would say less present overall ( still averrage as 2033 ) I loved the level in the Swamp per example.
It's considered as a survival horror but ammos are plenty and you never feel you're gonna run out, the game itself isn't very scary as well, I never felt scared nor did I feel desperate for resources, and the same applies to the Survival mode, when you play as little as possible without exploring too much.

Movement is very jerky. Movement on the ground sometimes feels glitchy. Slight elevations from the ground can give you a glitchy feeling.
Gunplay is slow; on most levels, you can simply run past enemies without any consequences, without needing to waste ammunition. It's true, you can ignore most enemies. They don't detect you very well, so you can just walk right past them.
Honestly a lot of the game is slowly following an NPC through a very boring scripted walk with nothing happening at all, it felt like one of the least interactive games, even a visual novel had more interactivity at times.
The gameplay can be chosen from hard-hitting, infiltration, tactical or a mix of all of these. 
The game alternates between action and rest phases, depending on the level and chapter. 

Exploration is supposed to be a minimum requirement in Survival mode, with difficulty higher than Normal; in Spartan, the player can just rush around without worrying, without encountering any difficulty in most levels. 
Metro is a slow fps-shooter in its gameplay, and even if you play like a brute in action with a nervous gameplay, the game will remain slow.
Because it's a game that's simply immersive in a first-person shooter and relies mainly on its atmosphere, and its not very addictive gameplay, which is generic in the fps world in my opinion, it innovates and doesn't bring anything to the table, although I applaud the studio's work.
 
"Artyom!"/10 is a bad character who is just a <fetch quest>character when his psychological state could have been put forward to care about him a little.
Scripting a game with (dialogues, discussions, questions/answers) without Artyom being able to answer, the impression of controlling a mute spoils the whole immersion.

Metro is a good but not amazing franchise, and this was a very good game.  It improves many things from the first game, pacing being the most notable.  The first one had a very grindy survival horror zombie apocalypse feel, where this one pushes the pace and leans harder into action.   The characters and story are flushed out a bit more, though many feel even more one dimensional than they did in the first.  If you like Russian end of the world war stories, this one will scratch that itch quite well.  

The biggest fault with the game is the nonsensical moral choices that determine what ending you get.  Both endings are fine, they fit the story.  [spoiler]However, most of what ending you get boils down how you choose to play out the big showdowns with the mini boss characters.  Your free to kill hundreds and hundreds of solders committing war crimes, but for some reason if you kill the commanders who gave the orders to commit war crimes that is somehow immoral and you get the bad ending?!?!  WTF?!?!?  Sure it gives the story some symmetry, but it still feels punishing [/spoiler]  The way you get there just kind of spoiled what was otherwise a quite solid game.   

If you like any of the Metro games, you will also like this one.  I give it a 7 out of 10 overall.  Good, but not exceptional.

This redux "remaster" is basically a much more optimized and complete version of the original Last Light along with slight improvements to gameplay and new melee animations. One of the best sequels and FPS post apocalyptic games of all time! Almost on par with Fallout New Vegas except the Metro games are very restrictive and linear! The gunplay is decent enough but nothing to special. The graphics and sound are great. The story is also decent and the game world is crafted amazingly. Artyom is back again as the silent protagonist except during the loading screens. Anna the love interest for Artyom is not interesting and is barely in this game but the sequel Exodus redeems her character and makes up for it. Of course there is nudity like babes with bare tits and nice curves and ass to help sell the game haha. The male character models are great but the females ones all look unrealistic and samey. The voice acting is amazing only in Russian. Never play this game with English dubbing! Just put the voice on Russian with English Subtitles to be completely immersed in this post apocalyptic metro station in Moscow! I recommend this and it's previous game Metro 2033 they're both rich in lore. I've never read the books so these games do a good enough job. I feel this "remaster" of this particular game didn't change the graphics enough like they did with Metro 2033 Redux and instead in this Redux the only thing that's been changed is the lighting which mucb brighter which is disappointing which sucks because I feel the original Last Light has better lighting and detail! The only reasons to guy this Redux version is for better optimization and all the DLC comes in this version!

This game is a must-play if you enjoy post-apocalyptic settings and immersive experiences.

Metro: Last light follows on from 2033. The best thing about the metro games for me is how  its not just a standard straight forward shooter. The addition of inventory management and stress of looking after your valuable respirator means that you always have to think on your feet in various scenarios. The game is an excellent sequel to the first glimpse into the Metro universe. Last light does everything better than its predecessor. Expanding the world which felt already so lived in and moving the story in strange but powerful ways you can understand why these games have received such high praise and devout following. 
Fantastic game play moments can be had with shoot outs in radiation ridden wastelands and tunnels, some of which are considerably larger and free roaming than the first. 

Visually this game is a little buggy but nothing game breaking and still performs well graphics hold up pretty well.  The best way to experience metro is with headphones on as the sound is incredible and often truly terrifying. 

Props to Ukrainian studios 4A games for another fine game. Stay Strong UKRAINE !!

I almost didn't finish this game. After playing the original (redux'd) this sequel was overall disappointing. The first half isn't good, which is the point where I almost quit playing. After looking up a guide online and seeing I was halfway through the game, I continued playing the second half which is better but that was a low bar to surpass anyway.

The problem is the sequel's direction; instead of "Metro 2033 but better" the sequel was "not Metro 2033, let's make a generic action game". At one point in the story one of the NPCs even calls you "an army of one", which is what the sequel is aiming to make the protagonist. The sequel's gameplay wasn't meant to be a sequel to Metro 2033, just the sequel's story. The story suffers because of this though because they have to fit in boss fights that regularly break the flow of the storyline.

This isn't a game to buy for the game itself, it's a game you should get as part of a franchise bundle.

Don't forget to watch how the game ends on youtube after you see the ending. Basically the chances of you getting the canon ending without following a dedicated guide your entire playthrough is zilch.

WARNING: "BANDITS" Chapter has a progress breaking bug which I believe I found a workaround for.

Review: Love the game and this series. I played the first game years ago and decided to finish this one before I start Exodus just to get the full experience. Graphics are great for how old this game is, the combat is decent albeit a little stiff but I like to think it adds to the "grounded" feel to it. The story picks up where the first left off but the atmosphere and lore are what really sell this game. Now I haven't beaten it yet but I would be alot further if I hadn't come across this bug in the Chapter "Bandits". When you reach the part where you have to ring the bell for the ferry, whenever I would press the reload/interact button, my character would freeze in place and could only look around. I wouldn't be able to do anything else. I would reload the checkpoint to no avail and ultimately had to restart the chapter MULTIPLE times only to keep running into the same issue. Well I found out that if you restart the chapter and reach the point where you exit the train into the area where you ring for the ferry, as soon as you reach that area DO NOT RELOAD OR PICK ANYTHING UP.  You should be able to press the interact button and ring the bell and still be able to attack and heal yourself but whatever you do, DO NOT PRESS THE RELOAD/INTERACT BUTTION. Whenever you run out of ammo, you will auto-reload and fend off the enemies until the ferry reaches you. Once it loads into the next area, you should be able to continue playing as usual. Hope this helps someone!

Very fun stealth/survival/horror linear FPS game with lots of weapons (revolvers, machine guns, shotguns, sniper rifles, pressure airgun, boltgun, etc.) to try out. You collect powerful military grade rounds through map exploration that can be used as powerful machine gun ammo or used at trader shops to purchase consumables, weapons and weapon upgrades. Gameplay loop encourages stealth and pacifism (sneaking through enemy corridors, turning off light sources/lightbulbs/power generators and knocking people out from behind instead of stabbing or shooting them) to build up moral points to get the good ending.

Has lots of robust UI details and weapon customization/upgrade options and gameplay mechanics (easy access nonviolent takedowns) that were used to create the well-loved Metro 2033 Redux.

Moral point system is a bit vague at times at what needs to be done to get the good ending, but it is a novel implementation of the concept.

If you want the flavor with more fun, try either the first game or the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series.

I don't know how to properly describe this game other than just plain and utterly disappointing. It's basically a COD Campaign without the fun and a boring exposition dump every few minutes and sometimes seconds. The story is predictable and garbage, the characters (fucking PAVEL) are so jarring and cringe that it hurts to listen to them for too long. There was never a point that I was scared, unless you find stupid looking aliens and spiders scary idk, the gunplay is boring, NPC's are a decent challenge in hard mode and just straight up target practice in normal mode. The game is incredibly linear, in fact it doesn't get anymore linear then this shit. No matter what you do, the game is basically holding your hand, I honestly feel like I'm watching a terribly directed movie at points. Why so many people find this game amazing baffles me, I guess the soundtrack is ok, and some characters like Anna are funny but overall not spectacular. The main character is an idiot, his "diary" is filled with uninteresting shit that plays everytime you load into a new level, it's basically of summary of what you just did and what is going to happen yet it feels like a robot is writing this shit, in fact the entire game feels anything but human. I don't feel bad for characters that die or are suffering because they lack emotion or purpose. Sure the game's old but COD 1 absolutely nailed campaigns in 2010 and it was most likely more linear then this trash. I bought this for 1.99 and godamn I wouldn't mind having my money back, do not buy this game and Pavel can go to hell with his shitty dialogue.

"Metro: Last Light" is the sequel of "Metro 2033", with events that take place one year after the canonical ending of the previous game. Just as the first one, the player controls Artyom throughout a post-apocalyptic Moscow and the tunnels of the Metro. 

Gameplay-wise, I couldn't tell any significant differences (minor changes were made to Artyom's watch) in comparison to the first game of the series. The player can choose between a stealth- or action-oriented gameplay. If you enjoyed the first game, you will probably enjoy the sequel. 

Story-wise, the sequel dwells more into the Dark Ones and humanity's choices that led to the destruction of the world and that might lead to even more bloodshed. The atmosphere is really well constructed, aligning great with the story. Just as in the first game, the player's actions have influence over the ending through a system of "moral points" (which are not really explained in-game, but can be inferred).

8/10

An okay sequel to Metro 2033, which follows the first game's bad ending. It emphasizes more on gameplay over worldbuilding.

Story: The first game definitely had the better intro and middle section between the two, but the climax here was much better and felt like a real endgame battle, unlike the first game. The story felt like it had too much focus on the politics within the metro. Although not bad, it felt a little too overused for these kinds of games, especially within the FPS genre, but I'm glad they followed up on the first ending's bad route, which actually had more potential than the good route. It did, however, give the players a better understanding of the creatures in the world and gave us more mutants to deal with, but that's about it. One advantage it had one the first game was the DLCs. It expanded the lore of the factions and gave us information on the missing parts of the story which was great. The only DLCs that I felt the game didn't really need was The Tower and Kshatriya DLCs.

Gameplay: The gameplay, although pretty much the same as in Metro 2033, felt much better. We had a ton more variety for both enemies and weapons. There are now actual bosses you can battle, which do not feel like minigames, unlike the first game's biomass and the dark one at the end. The new weapon additions felt really great and packed just the right power. The customization of weapons was also expanded, with some weapons getting new attachments. It made so much sense that they added a sniper rifle, which was the one gun I felt that the first game really needed. Finally, the stealth, although it did not change at all, feels somewhat better. Maybe it is due to the placement of the enemies or the lightbulbs? I wonder.┬а

Sound & Visuals: The graphics are okay; they did not change from Metro 2033 Redux; they have the same models, effects, and everything else. The voice acting of some characters still felt a bit off, and the children still did not sound like proper children. The music was a bit too loud at times, even at the lowest volume, but it will sometimes not be that audible. The lights from the enemies were horrendous and were too bright at times, especially when paired with night vision. It just sucked so bad, and I had to sometimes take a break due to the glaring lights.

Enjoyment: If gameplay is what you enjoyed from the first game, this one will definitely be the better game for you, but if you're like me, who enjoyed the more story and ambiance aspects, this might feel like a little bit of a downgrade from the first game. Overall, it is still a good entry in the series.

As much as Metro LL has it's moments, there were plenty of times I was shouting "THIS JUST ISN'T FUN" because the navigation was trash in a 'limited' open world or a new mechanic would pop up out of nowhere without any kind of intro or guide.   The game just lacked balance primarily, though it's worst aspect was the kind of 'dark ride' style of gamemap.   It felt like there should be so much to explore, but you were so limited in where you could go and what you could do, that even in the moments when it should have felt expansive, you were just worried to go off what little path they created.  Deepsilver forgot the feeling that was created when you first stepped outside in Metro 2035, and went for what felt a bit like a cash grab in really dialing in LastLight by comparison.   I realize this is a game about people living in tunnels, but there's just plenty of better games out there that feel less claustrophobic in the gameplay itself, that you can pass on this one.

Metro: Last Light Redux builds upon the foundations laid by its predecessor, delivering a thrilling sequel that further immerses players into the post-apocalyptic world of the Moscow Metro. With its gripping narrative, refined gameplay, and atmospheric world-building, Last Light Redux offers a haunting and memorable experience.

The storyline of Last Light Redux is a captivating continuation of the Metro saga. As Artyom, you embark on a quest to save humanity from the brink of destruction. The narrative delves deeper into the lore and mythology of the Metro, exploring the complexities of factional politics and the struggle for power. The characters you encounter are well-written and memorable, each with their own motivations and agendas.

The atmosphere in Last Light Redux is as haunting as ever. The Metro's tunnels and the surface world are brought to life with meticulous detail and atmospheric lighting. From the remnants of a ravaged cityscape to the eerie darkness of underground catacombs, every location feels unique and evokes a sense of dread. The game's ability to immerse you in its world is truly commendable.

The gameplay mechanics in Last Light Redux have been refined and improved. The combination of stealth, combat, and exploration offers a diverse and dynamic gameplay experience. The stealth mechanics have been enhanced, allowing for more tactical approaches to encounters. While gunplay remains satisfying, the scarcity of resources keeps the tension high, making every bullet count.

A standout feature in Last Light Redux is the morality system. Your actions and decisions throughout the game can influence the outcome and the fate of certain characters and factions. This moral dilemma adds depth to the narrative, making you consider the consequences of your choices and reinforcing the theme of humanity's struggle for survival and redemption.

The Redux version of Last Light brings improved graphics and performance, making the game even more visually stunning. The attention to detail in character models, environmental design, and lighting effects enhances the immersion and the emotional impact of the story. The sound design and haunting musical score further contribute to the game's atmospheric and emotionally charged experience.

In conclusion, Metro: Last Light Redux is a gripping and thought-provoking journey into the heart of darkness. With its engaging narrative, refined gameplay mechanics, and chilling atmosphere, it stands as a worthy successor to the Metro franchise. If you were captivated by the world of Metro 2033 Redux, Last Light Redux is an essential continuation of the post-apocalyptic adventure. Prepare to descend into a world of peril, hope, and the ever-lingering question of what it truly means to be human in the face of adversity.

Metro Last Light continues the story from the first game with the same level of quality. Graphically, there are only a few improvements compared to the previous game, but that doesn't mean the game doesn't still look fantastic and hold up very well even today.

You can strongly feel that the developers experimented a lot and had a lot of fun during the development process. This game is also longer than the previous one and offers much more variety.

This game is the type of sequel that takes everything great from its predecessor and makes it even better while also introducing new elements.

Those who embrace it will experience one of the most immersive games ever created. I can only recommend it; it's an experience you shouldn't miss out on.

Firstly, if you liked Metro 2033 Redux, you'll love Last Light Redux. 
New and old weapons, new and old characters, and an even better story this time around (and almost no audio clipping whatsoever!). Gameplay and stealth are as good as the first, and the levels are amazing. Furthermore, after beating the game there are some fun bonus missions to take on. Plus, unlike the first game, the ending sequence isn't some pointless running simulator. 
I had a few "gamebreaking" bugs that made me have to reload/restart levels, most notable being getting to watch Ulman walk straight through a wall and disappear in the first damn level. Otherwise there were just some bosses or objects that wouldn't spawn in first try. 
A nice, somewhat short, story experience. 7/10

[h1] Review[/h1] 
IтАЩm really conflicted about this game. Metro mostly excelled because of the amazing atmosphere, unique setting, and story. I found the first game way much more memorable, but this doesnтАЩt say last light is a bad game. There are many improvements compared to the original base game, not the redux version. Which is another thing I will talk about.

[u]Redux[/u]
First of all, the problem is that I donтАЩt see any reason to really have a remastered version of this game except to cash in some more. The only real change in the game is the тАЬgraphicalтАЭ update which basically just makes the games texture have more gamma or something. Original used to get a discount, which for the metro 2033 remake is justified, but not for this тАЬremasterтАЭ of last light. Only reason I donтАЩt recommend THIS version of the game as I donтАЩt like such practices. Down below a review to the game itself.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
The biggest change is the stealth system, which is now harder and more fleshed out due to the possibility of knocking out people which rewards moral points instead of killing in stealth sections so you can get the good ending.

The combat feels quicker albeit I didnтАЩt found the impact of the guns as good as in the first game, mainly due to a mix between design, animation and sounds. I would say the combat is improved due to it being more often in the game and also more difficult due to more, faster and tougher enemies.. Resources on the other hand are even less of a problem than in the first game as you can even pick up weapons and sell them.
You can choose between spartan and survival mode, the latter being the biggest change that filters run out faster/you find less and the reloading animations are slowed down, which looks odd as its just literally a slowed down version of the same 

I really like the new weapons added into the game, generally a good progression while also giving player choice. You want to use a faster shooting weapon like the Kalasch 2012 or a more accurate with more damage but a tiny clip size like the SSV? Its not a complete straight line of upgrading your weapons anymore but a slowly progression with a lot of player choice. Neat!

The biggest offender in this game is the tedious trailing mission again, the whole game is longer but also has more of everything, more stealth, more shooting, more exploring but also more trailing missions.

[u]Story[/u]
Here is where I donтАЩt really seem to make my mind up on it. ItтАЩs a good thing they made a new story and skipped the atrocious sequel book. But the base story that is there feels a lot more off from the tone of the original. The metro itself is a very desolate place with some sprinkles of civilization, but most of the time you will find sprawling cities full of people on and even on the surface. 

The new story is totally fine, but ends a bit too happy, especially that the black ones now wield absolute supernatural power, being immune to gunshots, can manipulate the mind and physical realm as they please. Also, the ending works with a lot of deus ex machinas or just general plotholes altogether I wonтАЩt spoil.
Albeit I like that the different factions are being shown slightly more albeit its mostly rangers, Reich and commies being focused on.

What really annoys me are some of the newly introduced characters, Anna. Early on you get her as a short companion who is supposed to be a really good marksman. The thing is her character is just utterly annoying to me, she belittles the player and calls her rabbit, someone who has singlehandedly killed off (due to a speech between two guards this is canon) two armies on the frontline map or met multiple mutants and anomalies. I donтАЩt know whatтАЩs dumber, the writing to make a strong independent woman who insults the player, or the character itself.

The premise is clear to most people and as soon as you meet the black creature you have to run around with some kind of goblin that is supposed to be cute because it trying to learn human culture and language. But what hits me is the dumb writing in this case, why exactly can he speak perfectly Russian, but randomly asks the player how they call things. Like storms or clothes.
ItтАЩs definitely not all to bad, especially the dialogues from guards or other side characters you meet are really interesting, especially unique characters like Pavel are a great addition that really invested me into the game.

[u]Sound[/u]
Not only are good, well-known tracks from the first game here, but also a lot of new ones and best of all a lot of environmental sound effects. Stuff that you would hear in Stalker and such. Very eerie and atmospheric. I really favour a good soundscape, and a good environmental track repertoire is always something I like the most in games.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Considering the base games graphics, I was mostly impressed by the surface area biomes. From the wind effects to the general detail in the many destroyed buildings in the fore and background of the levels its one of the graphically most impressive games I played. Additionally, the feature that the gas mask will have blood/dirt or water hindering the sight was a neat addition. 

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
Metro still excels in giving me an atmospheric game I can lose myself in. Combat is fun and the resource management is still rewarding me for exploring albeit I donтАЩt need it that much as its not balanced that well. Its not all well tough as I found the story itself rather lacking, especially some characters you meet. The biggest issue the trailing missions are back again and bigger than ever. I think its new additions average out the downsides and make it a slightly less memorable game.

Terrific sequel that improves on its beautiful predecessor in almost every way. I say almost because a couple of areas like story and moral point feature (great as they both still are) didn't quite match up to the original in my opinion. However, that's no reason to ignore this great title especially if you enjoyed 2033.

The plot takes off sometime from the original game's canon ending when the missiles were launched. The Dark Ones are seemingly obliterated and Artyom has joined the Spartan Order - a group of rangers and stalkers that fight for the Polis station, perhaps the least corrupt faction in all the Metro. While the Spartans now have control of the D6 bunker, reports reveal that a single Dark One managed to survive the destruction and tasked with hunting it down with Colonel Miller's daughter Anna. However, Khan insists to Artyom to spare it as this may be his last chance to redeem himself after the horrible act he committed. Meanwhile, multiple factions throughout the Metro have their eyes on D6, with the biggest hellbent threat being the Stalinist Red Line. Artyom must survive these hazzles by compromising with the surviving Dark One and proving to it that there is still some morality left and humanity deserves to be spared from its species' vengeful wrath.

Cannot say too much about the gameplay as it is not significantly different, but it did not need to be. Last Light makes many improvements to the experience though with more detailed and polished stealth elements for instance. The levels also have a little more variety now. For example, one level which I particularly enjoyed has you controlling a rail car and using light/flames to fight spiders in creepy optionally explorable halls. For me though, one of the biggest selling points are the mission add-ons which provide more content after you have completed the main storyline. You get to play as different factions and characters, and all of this gives new layers to the world of the Metro. My favourite mission of all was the Spartan Ranger one as that had the most exploration and replay value, allowing you to explore the library (where you encountered the dreaded librarians from before) and scavenge for valuables while you upgrade and unlock new routes. And the graphics, well... what more needs to be said about those!

The game is not without flaws however. One for me involves the story. Don't get me wrong it is *still* a great tale. But some elements felt rushed or underdeveloped; for instance, the Red Line being the only true antagonists with a very one-dimensional villain, my question was "Why just them? Why are they the only people that really care about D6?". There is no answer/motive to this other than the main villain is just purely BAD and happens to care more about this than other bad guys in the Metro. Yes, the Reds are evil but when you get captured by Neo-Nazis, discover their concentration camps and witness murdering of innocent individuals for sick reasons such as "slightly disproportionate" head shapes, you'd think such a group would be more actively hostile to the player throughout the story. The idea that such an extreme faction with a fanatical leader would cease to be a threat for the remainder of the story (and stop caring about D6) after a short encounter does not make sense. It gives off this impression that either the writers cut some things out, or inserted things that never had much bearing on the intended plot to begin with. None of this stops the story from being an emotional rollercoaster with moving and touching moments, but it is a still little disappointing that the Fourth Reich and other factions play such a minor role with no involvement in the game's final battle. Had they been featured more, I feel there was potential to add more intensity to the plot. 

Another flaw is that the moral point system seems a lot more difficult than before. In Metro 2033 it was not too difficult to obtain the "good" ending as a lot of the points were self-explanatory. In Last Light however, a lot of them are just highly obscure and easy to miss. For instance, some stealth segments which are easy to progress through will have no moral points to gain/lose while other trickier ones do. Like, why is killing one hostile patrol morally ambiguous while killing the other is not? I did not feel like I needed a walkthrough in 2033 to obtain enough points to unlock both endings. In this case however, it took 3 attempts (even with a guide) to unlock the "good" ending which is just silly considering that one is supposed to be the canon one here.

Despite a few minor faults, this game is well worth picking up. Not many FPS's nowadays provide such deep and emotionally unforgettable experiences. I also highly recommend playing these games with the audio set to Russian for more immersion.

This is a great game.  It's immersive and the gameplay is quite fun, overall.  The gunplay is good, and the weapons feel fairly realistic.  You really get the sense that you live in the Moscow metro after World War III, and are fighting to survive.  I played it on "Spartan Mode", because I'm not thrilled with the tight ammo allotments in the other mode, and found it to be more enjoyable, overall.

This game works well on Linux using Proton 7.x.

***Minor Spoilers Ahead***

I do feel like the "good ending"/"bad ending" mechanics are really broken, though.  Throughout the game, there are a number of places where you have choices to do the nice thing or the mean thing.  When you do the nice thing, you get a white flash on the screen with alien sounds to accompany it.  When you do the mean thing, you get a dark flash, instead.  This is great.  The problem is that you can go throughout the entire game making nice decisions and still get the "bad ending" because you didn't find the dozen or so easter eggs that the developers insist you locate in order to get the "good ending".  So, even though you did everything right, you get the bad ending because you didn't find four hidden ammo caches on a certain level, didn't strum a guitar on another level, or didn't listen to enemy guards talking about nothing for several minutes.  In the end, it gives the feeling that "choices don't actually matter, but satisfying the developers' ego does".  So, if you want to see the "good ending", just watch it on YouTube.  If you try to get it through gameplay, you will almost certainly be frustrated.  Instead, I recommend just playing the game how you want to play it, and simply expect that the ending will suck no matter what you do.  It's a good game up until the end.

I... just don't think its a very good game.
For these reasons:
-Tonnes of predictable and immersion-breaking quick time events 
-Sluggish NPC animations that you have to wait for
-Cringey & cliche dialogue. The ending was the cringiest of it all.
-Voice actors for kids were terrible
-An outdated checkpoint-based saving system. If you screw up and have no meds/ammo left, good luck for the next checkpoint!
-Walk into a puddle = drown instantly
-Sprinting past enemies and getting to the next room is easiest way to clear levels (you don't get followed)
-Difficult to find out where to go in outside levels
6/10, a much more action-packed and linear shooter compared to its predecessor, with the horror atmosphere toned down a lot, and a slightly above average story (for a game)

Hold onto your gas masks, folks, because Metro: Last Light Redux is one wild ride through the underground tunnels of Moscow that will leave you gasping for airтАФin a good way! This game has it all: gripping storytelling, intense gunplay, and enough atmospheric tension to make your heart pound faster than a speeding mutant.

Picture this: you're sneaking through the darkness, hoping the flickering lightbulbs don't give away your position, when suddenly a horde of grotesque mutants charges at you like they haven't had their daily dose of post-apocalyptic caffeine. It's like a monstrous flash mob, and you're the unwilling star of the show.

But fear not, because the arsenal at your disposal is as diverse as the mutated creatures you'll encounter. From shotguns that pack a punch to homemade contraptions that would make MacGyver proud, you'll be armed and dangerous against any foe that crosses your path.

And let's not forget the immersive graphics that transport you straight into the dilapidated beauty of Moscow's underground. The attention to detail is so astounding that you'll catch yourself gawking at the scenery instead of focusing on staying alive.

Metro: Last Light Redux is a rollercoaster of a game that blends tension, action, and a touch of dark humor in one unforgettable package. Strap on your gas mask, buckle up, and get ready to embark on a post-apocalyptic adventure that will make you laugh, gasp, and maybe even question your survival skills. It's a wild journey you won't want to miss!

The writing in Metro: Last Light Redux is excellent! It picks up where Metro 2033 left off, following the protagonist Artyom on his quest to save humanity from annihilation. The narrative is filled with moral choices, intricate political dynamics, and emotionally charged moments that make the player's journey through the tunnels of the Metro truly engaging.
It's a showcase of the grim beauty of a decaying world.

Redux also benefits from gameplay improvements and refinements, making it a more polished and enjoyable experience compared to its original release. The enhancements contribute to smoother combat, improved AI behavior, and overall gameplay satisfaction.

The DLCs are Okay... except the TOWER... no way that one was playtested, it's bit... DIFFICULT (and that comes from Ranger Hardcore player).

All in all...Metro Last Light has a captivating story, exciting gameplay, and a frightening atmosphere. It provides a thrilling post-apocalyptic experience that fans of atmospheric fps will enjoy.
DEFINITELY WORTH TRYING OUT!

It seems like it would be an excellent game but there are definite shortfalls on the execution portion.I am not an expert gamer. My view on the game is it could have been great except:
- Way to many cutscenes, some useless, many long, some that add little to the story, & finally some interactive ones that apparently you should 'know what to do' BEFORE you have to reload a few times.
- Quite a few battles are  foolishly difficult, more enemies attacking from every angle than you have the ammo to repel. Even on the easiest difficulty, some spots have more enemies than one can actually shoot. They attack in such quick succession the weapons available are unable to reload fast enough or need to load themselves when switching. It is just dumb. Presumably the master gamer can crank these settings up but someone just checking out the series for some R & R game playing it just is not enjoyable.
- The objectives are not very clear & often neither is the correct path. 
- There are quite a few glitches, causing one to replay the same levels over & over. This is particularly frustrating when going for some of the Achievements.
After reading & watching many different walkthoroughs to determine WHAT TO actually DO and playing through twice it was better but I will not play through again as the game wasted way too much of my time with it's (BS). I also have Metro 2033 (similar but less glitching) but will not purchase anymore of the Metro series.

 metro last light redux is a FPS survival horror game developed by 4A games and published by deep silver that was released in august 2014 for PC, PS4, and xbox one. last light is a direct sequel to 2033 and the franchise creator dmitry glukhovsky wrote the main story and most of the game's dialogue. like it's predecessor, last light is a post apocalyptic-themes fps with stealth and horror mechanics. the areas and levels are larger compared to 2033 and the game encourages exploration a lot more than the first game, by allowing the player multiple paths to choose between. the game also gives players the freedom to utilize different combat tactics.

the dev team kept a strong focus on the atmosphere, as that was one of the main things 2033 was praised for. while doing this, they tried to overhaul numerous gameplay mechanics such as improving the shooting, and animations were refined as well. they made the controls more accessible, and fixed a lot of the issues with the AI. another big goal of the dev team was to incorporate more survival horror elements, as they wanted to make players feel unsettled by playing the game. the story was excellently-written, but i did feel as if the main character was a bit soulless. nonetheless, the story had intimate, compelling, and engaging moments, and while it may have been unevenly paced, the game did a great job making introducing characters that earned genuine sympathy from me. 

i definitely recommend waiting for a sale for this game as you can get it for $3.99 on it's own, or in the metro saga bundle, you can get this game, it's predecessor metro 2033, and the third game in the series, metro exodus for around $15. those are great prices for a couple remasters, PLUS you get the third game in the saga and it's season pass.

I don't know if I have ever had an experience with a video game like I did Metro Last Light. As my first full metro game, I am blown away. This game manages to be a masterpiece while at the same time being terrible. 

I played through the game on survival mode and on the second hardest difficulty and might I say, I'm glad I did. The game felt pretty easy for the most part as I played stealth heavily but the combat wasn't to bad either although the combat in the game can be unforgiving at some points like when you find yourself getting the worst check point and having no syringes and needing to reload 1000 times before you can lucky and carry on. This game looks great in my opinion and the grittyness fits the theme of the game really well although, I was taken out of immersion because the game is filled with bugs and some, session ruining ones. My first experience happened when I wanted to reload a checkpoint and to reattempt something, the game crashed and kept crashing when I reloaded and clicked continue. I had to restart the chapter due to it. During one of the last missions I placed a mine and the same problem occurred. besides those darn bugs, I had no other major and/or game breakers besides getting stuck inside enemies or enemies was seeing me through was sometimes but some not seeing me when standing right in front of em LOL. 

All in all Id say give this game a shot because of the dumb but fun combat, interesting areas and (I know I didn't mention it in the first part) great story, even though I didn't really know wtf was going on for a good chunk of it lol. I gonna start reading the series and play through 2033 before carrying on in order!

First 6 hours are really cool and atmospheric, Metro is at its best when it just lets you be on your own and take it all in. I'd say it starts going downhill at around Venice where it ditches the focus on loneliness to show you big sprawling towns filled with happy people, give you a girlfriend, and then give you a companion on almost every level from then on. One particularly annoying companion is the fan-fictionesque "Dark One", who serves as an almost religious figure, judging you for your sins in the ever so pretentious "morality" "system". That system was the weakest part of Metro 2033 because it directly went against the design of the game and existed entirely as a gimmick! Why would they double down on it in the sequel? I'm not fond of being morally chastised by an annoying little alien for 7 hours straight at all and if the game really cared about choice and morality, it would've let me shoot the stupid thing.

Metro: Last Light Redux is an immersive and thrilling first-person shooter game that takes place in a post-apocalyptic world. The game features stunning graphics and detailed environments that truly transport the player into a desolate, yet beautiful world. The gameplay is engaging and challenging, with a variety of weapons and tactics available to the player.

One of the standout features of Metro: Last Light Redux is the attention to detail in the storytelling. The game builds upon the lore and history established in the previous game, Metro 2033, and expands upon it in fascinating ways. The characters are well-developed and memorable, adding an emotional depth to the game that is often lacking in shooter games.

The survival elements of the game also add to the immersive experience. The player must ration their resources and manage their equipment carefully in order to survive. This adds an extra layer of challenge to the already intense gameplay.

Overall, Metro: Last Light Redux is an excellent game that is not to be missed. With its stunning graphics, engaging gameplay, and immersive storytelling, it is one of the best first-person shooter games on the market.

In accordance with my review of 2033 Redux, I have to give this a soft Not Recommended. Great concept, slightly disappointing execution.

Note: I played on Survival Normal. [b]I would strongly recommend playing on Hardcore[/b] as Normal was [i]too[/i] easy; having played Hardcore in the first game, Normal took out a lot of the unease and desperation, feelings that really help immerse you in the atmosphere. (That said, I still managed to run out of ammo entirely at one point; mutants are very squishy if you have the wrong gear.) I believe I would have rated this game higher if I played it on Hardcore, but I'm not invested enough to replay it.

To avoid repeating myself too much, I will mostly talk about things specific to Last Light in comparison to 2033. Last Light is in the same world and same engine, for better or worse:
+ Same rich visuals, music, and overall atmosphere.
тАв Same hit-or-miss voice acting and super expository dialogue.
тАв [i]Why is Artyom a mute? Why is this built into the gameplay? He talks in between every level, but never during![/i]
тАв Enemy AI is hit or miss, but I'm used to it and the worst offenders (looking at you, Librarians) don't make a reappearance.
тАв Stealth is hit or miss.
тАв Lots of in-engine cutscenes that take control of the camera.
тАв Comparison/hierarchy of weapons is unclear.
- You may suffocate to death [i]waiting for people to stop talking[/i].
- You walk faster than your companions.
- Night vision is broken.
For more details on these subjects, see my previous review.

Improvements over 2033:
+ There seems to be more to do in the stations, e.g. minigames, and there is more noticeable variety in the environments. Still not really worth spending much time in, but it's an improvement.
+ Artyom's character arc is genuinely interesting: [spoiler]After launching the nukes, he regrets his decision and wants to atone for his sins and save the last Dark One.[/spoiler] He's trying to do the right thing in this war-torn world.
+ I actually like the more segmented level design as compared to 2033 Redux. At least at first, I felt it help with the pacing, though some of the transitions in the later game feel a bit weird and abrupt.
+ Interesting new enemies.
+ Less bugs in general.

Complaints:
- One, mainly: the story. Artyom's personal journey is interesting; the world surrounding it is not. There's a lot of build-up of political conflict between the Order, the Reds, and the Nazis, but overall it felt more confusing and disjointed than compelling.

I played through Last Light recently to refresh myself on the story so I could play Exodus, and it showed me the same problems I had with this game the first time I played it. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay is just a straight improvement from the first. I still had just as much fun romping through the tunnel system and ruins of Moscow, and things feel just a bit smoother here. I don't think there was a single point throughout the game where I had to look up what I was supposed to be doing. 

My largest problem is with the story of the game, so spoilers ahead. 

Metro 2033 had two endings, but it's more likely that players got the "bad" ending where Artyom blew up the home of the Dark Ones and killed almost all of their race. The game continues from that outcome, but then constantly blames you for everything that happened. Khan and the child dark one guilt you the entire time about you blowing up all of its family. Not only that, but to get the good ending you have to set a good example for the child dark one following you. Most of the game, revenge against Pavel is the driving force and if you want to get the good ending you completely have to disregard that and choose to save him from the fate he deserves. I cant understand the thought process behind this, yet it seems they continued this trend with Exodus where they continue the game from the bad ending. Here's hoping the next Metro game doesn't do the same.

Metro Last Light Redux is a stunning first-person shooter game that delivers a captivating and immersive post-apocalyptic world. The Redux version features enhanced graphics, improved lighting, and better overall optimization, making it an even more enjoyable experience than the original release.

The gameplay is intense and challenging, with a great mix of stealth, exploration, and combat. The weapons are well-designed and satisfying to use, and the enemy AI is impressive, providing a real challenge that keeps you engaged.

The story is gripping and emotionally charged, with well-written characters and an engaging plot that keeps you invested until the very end. The atmosphere is dark and oppressive, with a sense of impending doom lurking around every corner.

The sound design is also top-notch, with an incredible soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's themes and creates an immersive experience that draws you in from start to finish.

Overall, Metro Last Light Redux is a masterpiece of a game that delivers an unforgettable gaming experience that will stay with you long after you've finished playing. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters or simply enjoy a good story-driven game, this is an absolute must-play title that deserves a 10 out of 10 rating.
Great story line. Great graphics. A must play title

Some sections definitely drag on for a little longer than they should and the story is kinda meh compared to the first, but there's still plenty of parts I did enjoy and the finale is still pretty cool. Also you still have to fix the stupidly low FOV.
Only buy if you want a more fun version of the first game.

Continuation of the excellent first part with bug fixes and overall gameplay improvements. Weapons have become better, graphics too, new barrels have appeared. The plot continues the book story with some differences. And most importantly, you can kill a lot of Russo-fascists and Russo-communism. The authors looked right into the water, some dialogues are simply amazing with their insight and prophecy. And, of course, Moscow after the apocalypse is simply beautiful. I am waiting for the same results in reality in the swamps. 8/10

This game feels like an expansion of the first. While being grounded in horror survival, the first game establishes a world thats terrifying, Last Light continues this but expands the worlds a little by adding more exterior levels above the metro. There are no new mechanics to combat besides new weapons, but otherwise its the exact same as the first game While enjoyable, the story suffers from some pacing issues and character motivations seems to be on rails with the story itself and not to add character to well, the characters. And speaking of rails, this game has so many "on the rail" type shooting sequences it started making my head spin. The end game feels a bit rushed and some enemies health pools will drain literally all of your ammo which is frustrating. Anyway, onto Exodus!

If you haven't played Metro 2033 before, I suggest you play it first. Coming to metro 2033 Last Light: if you like story-oriented games without caring about graphics, this game is for you. Both the venue and environments of the game, and the stealth-based gameplay really make the game very enjoyable. Of course, if the weapon animations were a little faster and closer to reality, the game would not be beaten. If you are a suspense lover, there are plenty of tense scenes in the game. In the game, they stretch you a lot, and in some parts, you even get scared with the monsters that come from behind or in front of you. There is sexuality in some scenes of the play. one of them according to the option you choose. another is necessary because it is necessary for the continuation of the story. It has an average of 10 hours of gameplay.
I am writing this review as I finished the game and I recommend this game to everyone.

The story is filled with "random bs go!" moments but connects many of the elements and ideas much better than its predecessor. The ending in the first game felt very rushed and unemotional, but this was fixed in this one. The ending is built towards much earlier in the game and gives the much needed immersion for what is to come. All in all, decent game for a discounted price.

Metro has something most other games lack, and that is a complete and unapologetic level of immersion that is sure to throw off some, but is invaluable to me. Scratching on the lighter, burning the webs of huge mutated spiders, wiping the blood and filth off your gas mask as your air is running out, peering into the darkness, gun wielded from the hip, jumping at every screech and groan from the black tunnels, is an experience very few games can even hope to replicate. Metro isn't an FPS per se, it's supposed to be played more like a survival horror, especially on the higher difficulties where every bullet counts, and the claustrophobia truly begins to settle in, with no hud, no crosshair, nothing to break the immersion of the stifling atmosphere of the metro tunnels deep under the earth. The world and story of Metro is engrossing in a way few other games can even hope to match, set in an unapologetically bleak, slavic post-apocalypse. It's not a perfect experience, having some of the jank that naturally comes with the territory of having been made by a not AAA studio in Eastern Europe, with a limited budget, but the passion is there, and it's a incredible experience if you open your mind to it.

Metro: Last Light Redux is a first-person shooter and survival horror game developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver. It is a remastered version of the original Metro: Last Light game, with improved graphics, gameplay mechanics, and additional content.

One of the standout features of Metro: Last Light Redux is its atmospheric and immersive world. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic Moscow, where players must navigate the dangerous underground metro tunnels and the irradiated wasteland above. The game's graphics are stunning, with detailed character models, environments, and lighting effects that help to create a sense of realism and immersion.

The game's gameplay mechanics are also well-crafted. Players must scavenge for resources, manage their weapons and equipment, and engage in tactical combat with both human and mutant enemies. The game also features a stealth system, allowing players to sneak past enemies or take them out quietly.

Another positive aspect of Metro: Last Light Redux is its strong narrative and characters. The game's story is well-written and engaging, with multiple endings and branching paths depending on the player's choices. The game's characters are also well-developed, with their own motivations and backstories that help to create a sense of empathy and connection with the player.

The game also features a variety of additional content, including new levels and gameplay modes. The game's Ranger Mode, for example, removes the game's HUD and increases the difficulty, adding an extra layer of challenge for players looking for a more hardcore experience.

Overall, Metro: Last Light Redux is a well-crafted first-person shooter and survival horror game with a stunning world, engaging gameplay mechanics, and strong narrative and characters. While it may not appeal to all players, it remains a must-play for fans of the genre and the Metro series.

The game is very linear; pointing you in the correct direction all the time. Not letting you get lost, and never giving you a puzzle to solve. Even with this, the game does not feel linear. Yes, there is no fork in the path. Even with the different choices you make, you are still going to the same places and doing the same things. But it does not feel like that while playing. The gameplay is super unique, in my opinion, offering you to be able to take many different play styles depending what you want to do. Don't want to kill people? Just sneak around all game. Want to play stealth sniper? Or John wick everyone? That's an option.

Beyond just the gameplay, the story is amazing. The dark, gloomy landscape of the surface. The grimy, claustrophobic feel of the metro. It all plays into a very Immersive experience that honestly gets addicting. Even walking around a station and listening to random conversations can be very fun, honestly.

This game is 100% worth a play, if you love post-apocalyptic/survival/horror games.

I played Metro Last Light back to back with the original Metro 2033 and while both share basic premise and UI, they are very different games. Where Metro 2033 is dark, scary and you crawl step by step through dark tunels, get lost and scavenge for ammo and filters to survive a bit longer, Metro Last Light is much more light and forgiving. The game is much more accesible - ammo is plentiful, maps are more well lit, stealth finally works (yay!) and everything is less gloomy.

Personally, I liked both - while different experiences, both were very well executed and had captivating story, varied missions and a lot to offer. If you're fun of story driven FPS games, I would recommend both!

The ATMOSPHERE is 10/10 and punches way above it's class.  Story and narrative elements are great and also punch way above it's class.  The little towns and villages are a real joy to walk through and see what is going on.  You won't find any side quests or anything like that, but there's a lot of world building going on here, and in the narrative events and cut scenes. 

Graphics are actually still really good.  Several times had to stop the game to take a screen shot and remind myself this came out nearly 10 years ago.  I played on Hardcore mode as that has more of the survival horror/resource management that, for me, adds to the atmosphere.  There's no HUD, which really works on a game like this and really immerses you into the game. 

The gunplay is pretty good, at times the weakest part of the game.  If you're looking to run and gun, do not play hardcore mode.  Hardcore mode plays more like Rainbox Six.  You light up a map of enemies and they will erase you quickly.  For me, Hardcore forced me to stealth through the human conflicts more which I really liked.  Upgrade your weapons, stocks and sights, asap and you'll have a better time.

Stealth plays really well.  Kind of a poor man's Splinter Cell.  I really liked clearing areas and rooms.  Makes you feel like a really bada$$ merc for sure.  Take out the lights, sneak around, shush the bad guys.  Sometimes you have to use throwing knives to distract or make a really silent distance kill to move forward.  All awesome.  My only complaint is that sometimes the activation distance/hitbox or whatever for turning off a light or stealth kill doesn't always kick in when you'd expect.

The mutant battles really force the gunplay so it feels a little bad sometimes.  But this isn't a game that wants to make you feel like a powerful bada$$ on the surface with the mutants.  You're exposed.  Breathing poison air.  The mutants are faster than you and deadly, and you'll feel relief whenever you make it through and back underground where it's "safe".

All in all I'd recommend it if this sounds remotely interesting to you.  It's worth the $20 asking price and it regularly goes on sale for less than that.  The developer is based in Kyiv, Ukraine and supporting them through what they're going through, I think, is a good thing.  Here's an excerpt from their website: "As a company, weтАЩre doing everything we can. We provide financial and logistical assistance to the team scattered across Kyiv and beyond. WeтАЩre also proud to support and amplify personal efforts of our staff who are volunteering, making donations, delivering medical supplies and food, and a lot more тАУ most of all those who are fighting on the front lines."  https://www.4a-games.com.mt/4a-dna/studio-update-exodus-sdk

[h1]Metro: [i]Last Light Redux[/i][/h1]The story takes place in the same post-apocalyptic world as its predecessor, but takes place some time after the events of the end of the first game, in 2034. With a new companion by his side, Artyom needs to race against time to prevent a civil war. wipe out what's left of humanity.

It is then that the Ranger embarks on a new journey filled with even greater dangers. In this unprecedented adventure, the enemies are not just the terrible mutants or radiation zones, but the very human beings he wants to protect.

The game is an incredible first-person experience, with a wide variety of original and themed weapons. The various features and elements make the adventure very close to a survival filled with mystery, terror and a lot of action.

Race against time to save humanity in a beautiful world made from the ruins of what was once the height of civilization. In Metro: Last Light Redux, adventure awaits in every new landscape or dark tunnel. Try this classic game completely revamped right now!

[b]One of the main strengths of the game is the immersion that the entire atmosphere of the Metro universe manages to create. The art direction of the game is impressive and brings true works of art to life in the most varied scenarios presented. Which is already a true evolution of its predecessor, since it is a considerably larger production.[/b]

There are not many changes regarding the gameplay, which was already, at its base, just another FPS. However, all the additional mechanics present in the previous game are still here, with the addition of certain improvements. The game suffers from an effect common to sequels to great games - the reduction in difficulty. But nothing that interferes with the gameplay experience.

Despite offering moments of difficulty and real challenge for the player, several elements of the game (such as shortage of ammunition), which serve to make it more difficult, seem softer. Even so, Metro offers modes with extremely high difficulty for players who really want the most hardcore experience possible.

The graphic quality also deserves mention. Although the original game already had much better graphics than the first title, they have been even more elaborate in this remastering and are ready to give work to the consoles of this new generation.

[b]In short, [i]Metro: Last Light Redux[/i] is a game that, like Metro 2033, cannot be missing from your library.[/b]

Amazing sequel to Metro 2033. A solid FPS with a great story and interesting characters. The story is presented in a manner similar to Half-Life 2, whereby you maintain control of the player in first-person while characters move around and talk to you and each other. The lore is also very interesting and unique. You can often approach combat using stealth or action and the level design is also great.

Overall, I'd highly recommend to anyone looking for an immersive FPS.

"I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dinkum and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories."

it's a beautiful story, but i like the prequel better... let's just put that out there, this game feels shorter & it is. bad ending is totally worth it.

the most annoying parts are the game crashes that happen rarely, the auto-save in this also happens at some bad spots, if you are an explorer in your first playthrough

the DLCs are a tad hard but the most fun i had with the current weapons

the prequel is better in timing ...at saving the game.... IMO that was the most annoying part, graphics aren't great but it does create an atmosphere & it takes a while to get used to the mechanics for Filter switching, bit annoying that you cant grab ammo while switching your Filter, and Also if your filter switching gets bugged and you keep switching new filters, just reload the last checkpoint, BUT if you changed your filter and you are still gasping for AIR, take off your GasMask & put it back on... that should fix that bug, but yeah... some minor bugs.

if your gun doesn't shoot... it's probably because you are using the guns with a Pressure tank, best to avoid those are i think some (but i think there is a bug that makes all weapons stop shooting = reload last save, the game is short so no issues there) i also advise not using them for sniping but only with reflex sight aiming.

... the game wobbles too much and sometimes you are wobbling behind cover while being hit by bullets (that seem to be going through the map), because it has mechanics that work on a sort of timer... so you have to shoot then hide to the side of the map or you take dmg no matter what, there's no real indicator on when you are taking hits except this... invisible timing ...the blood on the sides of the screen, and the wobbling...like a drunken sailor, in a real situation you would see the snipers aiming at you  ...while 85% under cover...crouched down and unseen bullets are still taking you out. As well as rockets that pass overhead kill you still, like i said...unless you hide to the side of the map. 

i tried to be soft on this because i love the prequel, but this entire game annoys me on the first playthrough, lol... the 2nd playthrough is way more enjoyable. i got that OCD hoarding syndrome, but it's a fun game... knowing all of this hopefully makes you less annoyed with it, heh.

The bad would be the voice acting. It seems to be done by non-professionals and it shows, the character voices don't exactly sell what they are saying, sounds more like monotonous reading. But this can be forgiven on account of all the other many pluses of this wonderful game.

Metro: Last Light Redux is a first-person shooter game developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver. It is a remastered version of the original Metro: Last Light game, released in 2013. The game is set in post-apocalyptic Moscow, where players take on the role of Artyom, a survivor of a nuclear war.

The game offers a stunning visual experience, with its atmospheric and immersive environments. The remastered version of the game has improved graphics, lighting, and effects, which makes it even more beautiful and breathtaking. The sound design of the game is also impressive, with a haunting soundtrack and realistic sound effects that add to the overall atmosphere of the game.

The gameplay in Metro: Last Light Redux is engaging and challenging, with a mix of stealth, combat, and exploration. The game allows players to approach situations in different ways, offering them the choice to either engage in combat or use stealth to avoid enemies. The variety of weapons and upgrades available in the game add to the player's tactical options, allowing for a more personalized gameplay experience.

The story of Metro: Last Light Redux is captivating, with a strong narrative that keeps players engaged throughout the game. The characters are well-developed, and the dialogue is well-written, making the game feel more like an interactive movie. The game's plot is filled with twists and turns, which keeps players on their toes and adds to the overall suspense of the game.

One of the most impressive aspects of Metro: Last Light Redux is its attention to detail. The game's world-building is exceptional, with a level of detail that is rarely seen in games. The game's world feels lived-in and real, with its own history and mythology that players can discover through exploration.

Overall, Metro: Last Light Redux is an excellent game that offers a compelling and immersive experience. The game's stunning graphics, engaging gameplay, captivating story, and attention to detail make it a must-play for any fan of the post-apocalyptic genre. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience.

Just feels like a 2010s generic balls to the wall shooter with 2033's mechanics, but without being fun like it's predecessor, it has the exact same movement of the previous game but with horrible situations that require you to run away and sometimes doing an 180 shooting behind (the entire beast combat of the game btw), the game just turns into a bullet sponge simulator, it's way more linear than 2033, sometimes being completely soft locked by needing heals and having to start chapters all over again, I've played on ranger/normal and honestly i'd advice against it, just play on something easier and have fun.

Lastly but not less important, 99% of people will probably get the bad ending by design, that is not canon for the following game Exodus, this is complete bullshit, simply obligating the play stealth if they want to get the good ending is torture, and also because you'll have to play this shit storm all over again if what you want is the canon story.

This game was better than the first, they fixed a lot of things that I didn't like about the first one. There's more boss fights and it's nice that the story picks up where it left off essentially. This game was definitely more creepy than the first, I was for sure spooked out in some of the darker/low visibility scenes. I liked that they played more on the use of light i.e the flashlight and shadows. 

I think that the story could benefit from having more variety in voice acting. Just like the first game the Nazi's have Russian accents. Everyone sounds the same as if there were only 3 voice actors. But again, better than the first game. I also wish they'd change the story rhythm up a bit. Shoot shoot shoot, player falls down a shaft, shoot shoot, meet up with a buddy, shoot shoot, falls down shaft, shoot shoot, meets up with buddy. It gets tiresome.

Metro 2033 = Monsters and Ambiguous story lines
Metro Last Light = Monsters + Nazis + Reds and virtually everything explained crystal clear up front within the first, IDK, 20mins or so of the game. What happened?

Real quick, I did NOT play this game for 41 hrs. I keep not understanding why some games do this.

The first game was a really good FPS with good weapons and a good story. This has some of that, and it's on the border of being recommended but it falls just short of that. The story is OK, its given to you all at once in the beginning and then slowly reintroduced to you over and over again as if discovering something for the second or even third time is this profound moment. It's also sad to see so many "End of the World"/Horror cliches just thrown in for effect. So much so it's hard to make sense of it. Hands that come out of the ground to grab you, visions of the past, friends who betray you, crazy guy that somehow knows the truth from the beginning and lets not forget a good ole healthy dose of humanity can't stop killing and turning on each other even when its about to be completely wiped out. None of this is bad per say, and the main reason it gets a thumbs down is the gameplay at the end. The story is just not good enough to justify the sluggish boring take cover and shoot combat at the end. I'd say from the sniper ambush on to the end of the game the combat is just frustrating and bad. Don't we have enough FPS games where we kill Reds and Nazis? Isn't shooting monsters and barely escaping what made this game so good in the first place?

If you really want something like Metro 2033, but not this game, then I'd recommend Ashes 2063. Aside from that, I'd only recommend this if you have a high tolerance for frustrating mediocrity all in the name of seeing a few cutscenes probably available elsewhere. I've come this far so I guess I'll finish it begrudgingly but damn. Never again.

Graphics are excellent and the environments are detailed and fun to explore. The people you meet are interesting with meaningful backgrounds and great voice acting. Combat is enjoyable and fluid with a good amount of different weapons.

Also the last mission/final battle is so intense and will be one of the memorable experience i ever had.

Metro: Last Light Redux is an outstanding first-person shooter game that provides an immersive and terrifying post-apocalyptic experience. The game is a remastered version of the original Metro: Last Light, with enhanced graphics and improved gameplay mechanics.

Set in the dark and eerie world of Moscow's underground metro system, the game follows the story of Artyom, a survivor of a nuclear war that has destroyed the world. Artyom is on a mission to save the last remnants of humanity from a new threat, the Dark Ones, while battling rival factions and monsters along the way.

One of the standout features of Metro: Last Light Redux is its incredible attention to detail. The game's graphics are stunning, with highly-detailed environments that create a believable post-apocalyptic world. The lighting and shadows add to the game's atmosphere, creating a sense of dread and unease as you make your way through the dark tunnels and abandoned buildings.

The game's sound design is also exceptional, with eerie sound effects and an immersive soundtrack that heightens the tension and adds to the overall experience. The voice acting is also top-notch, with excellent performances from the cast.

In terms of gameplay, Metro: Last Light Redux is a challenging game that requires strategy and careful planning. The game features a variety of weapons and equipment that can be customized and upgraded, giving you a range of options to take on enemies and complete objectives.

The game also features multiple endings, depending on your choices and actions throughout the game. This gives the game a high level of replayability, as you can play through it multiple times to experience the different outcomes.

Overall, Metro: Last Light Redux is an exceptional game that delivers an immersive post-apocalyptic experience. With its stunning graphics, excellent sound design, and challenging gameplay, it is a must-play for fans of the first-person shooter genre.
