Oh, Metro Last Light Redux, one of my personal favorites! Here are some reasons why you should give it a try:

You'll never feel safer in the dark - This game is a masterclass in creating tension and suspense. Every corner you turn, you'll be wondering if you're about to be attacked by some mutated monster. But don't worry, you have a trusty flashlight to guide the way...if the batteries don't run out.

So many guns, so little time - Metro Last Light Redux has an impressive variety of weapons to choose from. Whether you want to go stealthy with a silenced pistol or go all-out with a flamethrower, there's a gun for every occasion.

The world-building is on point - The world of Metro Last Light Redux is rich with detail and lore. You'll encounter a variety of characters with their own stories and motives, and you'll learn about the history of the world through scraps of information scattered throughout the game.

The visuals are stunning - The game's graphics have been updated for the Redux version, and they are breathtaking. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the lighting effects create an eerie and atmospheric mood.

You'll never want to leave the tunnels - The game's setting, the underground tunnels of a post-apocalyptic Moscow, is one of the most immersive and engaging I've ever experienced. You'll find yourself getting lost in the dark, twisted tunnels for hours on end, and you won't even mind.

So there you have it, folks. Metro Last Light Redux is a must-play for any fan of post-apocalyptic shooters. Just make sure you bring a spare pair of pants, because this game is gonna scare the pants off you!

ENG:
Metro Last Light Redux is a sequel to the famous game Metro 2033 Redux, which continues the story of humanity's life after a nuclear war. The game has a deep and emotional story that transports the player to the incredible world of post-apocalyptic Moscow.

Having played through the game with a bad ending, I can say that it is a very strong experience. Although it may seem depressing and hopeless, it definitely leaves an impression. The game forces the player to think about his actions and their consequences, and shows that it is not always possible to find a perfect way out of a situation.

One of the biggest advantages of the game is the visual graphics that create an unparalleled atmosphere, as well as the soundtrack that complements the game experience. The gameplay is very exciting and varied, with a lot of puzzles and combat scenes.

Overall, Metro Last Light Redux is a very addictive game that will leave the player with an unforgettable experience. While the bad ending may leave players in doubt, it's worth going through to see what the consequences of our actions and decisions can be.

nice game your choice if you want to sneak or go on a rampage

I will assume that anyone looking at this game has played the original Metro 2033, as this is the sequel to that. so you are familiar with the tone, gameplay, and atmosphere the game offers. The redux is an updated version of the original Last Light that plays and holds up well against modern games.

as usual It's a narrative-focused role-playing game with a strong emphasis on the story, and it's the kind of game that allows you to completely immerse yourself in the world thanks to a lack of obtrusive HUD elements, which I would liken to Dead Space.

I didn't have any technical issues while playing through the game. The only issue I encountered was a bug where a boss became invincible in the garden mission. Other than that, it was a smooth and enjoyable experience.

To complete the game at 100%, you must complete the base campaign twice and each of the DLCs once. Each of the DLCs can be completed in around 20 to 30 minutes, so it's not that bad, and it all enriches the story and setting of Metro, with some of it building on what was established in the main game.

NOTE: Those who are afraid of spiders or may have arachnophobia should hold off buying. There are big spider-like creatures in the game. Do your own research to see if it's something you can handle.

While it's definitely recommended that you pick up this game, it's always wise to wait for a sale price.

Metro: Last Light is an incredible follow-up to the already impressive Metro 2033, offering an immersive and thrilling experience that improves upon its predecessor in every way.

The game's haunting atmosphere and attention to detail create a sense of dread and unease that is both captivating and immersive. The game's story is also engaging, with a captivating plot that keeps you invested from start to finish.

The game's combat is also more refined, with new weapons and mechanics that make for a more dynamic and exciting experience. The game's attention to detail and immersive gameplay create a world that is both terrifying and captivating, making for a truly unforgettable experience.

Overall, Metro: Last Light is a must-play for fans of survival horror and immersive storytelling, with its haunting atmosphere, engaging story, and intense gameplay making for an experience that is both thrilling and unforgettable.

This is a great game in a (so far) great series. I've played Metro 2033 Redux and Metro Last Light Redux twice and am going to start Exodus soon. The games are linear, you just move forward through the adventure, there's no doubling back. 

If I have a gripe with these games, the no doubling back is definitely it. That, and the slow aim/look even on max sensitivity when using a controller. 

These games are best enjoyed when treating your experience like watching a movie. You're watching Artyom's adventure more than you are coming up with creative solutions to problems. 

That being said, it's an enjoyable movie. The games are wildly different from the books, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. A game of the books would be tedious and boring, while a book of the games would be nonstop firefights. They really do compliment each other well though. If you enjoy one I encourage you to experience the other.

Metro: Last Light is a bold post-apocalyptic FPS adventure uniquely told from the Russian point of view. Last LightтАЩs setting and presentation are its strong points, though the last third of its 10-hour campaign is weaker than everything that came before it. If you want a fun first-person shooter that doesnтАЩt remotely rise to the greatness of single player-centric adventures like BioShock but is still fun in its own right, then Last Light may just be for you.

A good setting and interesting concept marred by poor performance and execution.

The setting and narrative of Metro is truly captivating- crawling through ruined Underground tunnels where bullets are currency, stations are towns, and the Surface is a thrilling, dangerous risk is represented beautifully in Last Light Redux.  The narrative is also compelling, if somewhat lacking in dynamism.  Chapters are short, pacing is all over the place, but the themes and characters are mostly good.

That about ends the good in Last Light to me.  This game isn't exactly a buggy mess, but the bugs encountered are so egregious it made me quit the game mere hours before the finale.  First of all, the morality system as I understand it (which will determine which ending you get) is partially reliant on how many enemies you kill.  This is fine, but the stealth is pretty half baked and boring, and there's a glitch about halfway through the game that completely eliminates your ability to knock out enemies rather than kill them.  Secondly, over a dozen times Last Light would crash on startup, and while verifying the integrity of the game files fixed this for a few times, eventually I had to resort to uninstalling and reinstalling the game, and now even that doesn't fix it.  I don't enjoy this game enough to pursue this any more.

I'm certain this game will appeal to many, possibly enough that if they encounter these same problems, they'll want to keep going regardless.  It wasn't for me though.

It's a great game.

I think it's better than Metro 2033 as this one really has another level of depth put into it. There's much better level design here than in 2033, crouch and stealth mechanics work fine for the most part, the story is a lot more meaningful and has a better and more emotional development overall. The gameplay is pretty much the same with a few minor tweaks and some more gear variety. The side quests and activities are much more interesting this time around and carry more meaning than in the previous game, however, for some reason, the entire low chaos mechanic seems to be broken, as even by following online guides and killing only when necessary, giving free bullets to beggers, listening to dialogue,, avoiding unnecessary fights with monsters and overall using a stealth approach for the entire campaign still gives you the bad ending for some reason. The effort for it feels entirely wasted to be honest, and leaves me quite frustrated - enough for me not to play another campaign, even though I enjoyed the story and everything else.

The bad side about this game is that it crashes a lot. While I haven't experienced a single crash in Metro 2033, here I had almost 10 crashes throughout my run without any apparent reason.

Rest in peace Andrii Korzinkin, you will live on in our games!

Animator Andrii Korzinkin, who worked at developer 4A Games, has died following a combat mission in Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The news was confirmed by designer Leonid Stepanov, who worked with Korzinkin at 4A on Metro Exodus before leaving to work at Remedy Entertainment.

"Andrii 'Nizrok' Korzinkin died while performing a combat mission in the struggle for independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine," wrote Stepanov. A talented animator, incredible person and real hero."

Korzinkin began his animation career as a 3D animator at Ukrainian studio Pixelation, during which he worked on the TV series Angel Baby. In 2017, he entered the game industry as a senior animator for 4A as it was working on 2019's Metro Exodus. Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine earlier this year, Korzinkin voluntarily enlisted into the Ukrainian military.

"Andrii was an awesome human being, very responsive and supportive, always ready to help, incredibly responsible and dedicated person," wrote 4A's technical designer Vitalii Keda. "He always stood out with his dry humor and strive for excellence. [...] You will be missed, dear friend. Rest in peace. Heroyam slava!"

About the game:
The game's atmosphere and unique design choices will make it a worthwhile experience for some, but Metro 2033 suffers from a number of issues (poor implementation of stealth, recurring glitches, etc.). Fans of post-apocalyptic stories should consider giving this a shot, if they can tolerate the aforementioned setbacks.

Probably one of the strongest recommendations I'll make here.

Metro Last Light is one of those few games that manages to capture a gorgeous picture almost no matter where you are.
Whether it be the unforgiving metro tunnels, or the harsh Russian winter of the surface, nearly every level is incredibly well-crafted.

It has one of the most beautiful soundtracks I've had the pleasure of playing to, and the sound design is great.


Past this initial praise, I would however like to bring up an issue I noticed with the game, which may very well just be me.
It's too easy, much too easy.

What I mean by this is that not even on Survival Ranger Hardcore (Hardest difficulty availible), do I ever really feel like I'm struggling. Supplies are plentiful if you know the stash locations and don't forget to loot enemies, the only real issue I encountered was the cap on how much you could carry, which led to me having to abandon a fair amount of loot on each level.

What I personally think can (and should) be done to fix this, at least to some degree, is a custom difficulty level, where you have control over different variables that affect the game's difficulty. This would give players much more control over their experience, and could drastically improve most people's experience.

That being said, this game is an incredible experience, and I found myself playing it over and over again, even with the linear story. I really appreciated the moral system as well, while it may be a bit black/white as it is now, it's definitely a step in the right direction, and I can't wait to see what this talented studio does with Exodus.


TL;DR
Great game, go get it.

EDIT: Updated for 250+ hours, several replays in and still loving it all the same

There is a game breaking glitch that will ruin your play through if you encounter it, and the best part is that there is no way to know if it will happen to you, it is completely random!

Once you get to the "Bandit" chapter, you may find that you are unable to sneak kill/knock out enemies. Congratulations, your save file is screwed. And if you delete your save file and start over all the way from the beginning, it may happen again, so f^$% me, I guess. I'm not replaying this game again, and it's a shame because I was really enjoying it. I cannot recommend you buy this game if this will bother you.

Update: I had to download someone else's save file that didn't have the bug in it to be able to finish it. My disappointment is immeasurable and my play through is ruined.

One day, I'd like to actually be able to play a game, rather than have the developers play it for me in a series of overly scripted sequences where I go here, do this, press this button when I'm told to...

Edit - Well, I kept going for a bit longer. Much against my better judgement. But I love the setting, really enjoyed the other two games and wanted to finish the trilogy. I just couldn't do it though. 

It's not just that the game's way overscripted, with lots of unskippable cut scenes, forced slow walking while some guy drops exposition, silly scare bits where you have to rapidly tap enter etc etc. 

It's that the story's pretty meh - I really didn't care much what happened - and when you finally do get to do some shooting, it's a pretty poor FPS - an extremely linear corridor shooter, with unsatisfying gun play and awful bullet sponge boss fights.

Overall, I'd say play 2033 and skip straight to exodus. I'm not even sure you need to play last light for the plot. I'd played exodus second and it seemed to follow on from 2033 pretty well.

Great game

Totally worth it. This second chapter expands the story of the first with meaningful character and in my opinion even better main story.

Survival and stealth improved, a little bit extra in the weapon department compared with the first one but if you are looking for a 1-2 tap and play both in sequence you'll probably just stick with the guns that carried you on the first game which I did. Sniper Rifle is useless except one mission (no spoiler), you can essentially transform your pistol in one with plenty of bullets that are even cheaper to build.

I really recommend this, remember to swap bullets in the AK-47 so you avoid shooting your money. In short, is the first one just improved and will meet all your expectations.

Proceed with caution is probably the best way to describe Last Light. In one word: frustrating. Artistically frustrating.

There are some NSFW strong nudity sections that you can't skip. They're required to progress in the story. If you're a YouTuber or streamer you will get in trouble for sure if you show that on screen. FYI. I don't have a problem with that being in a game made for more mature audiences, but be warned, it's not skippable and these sections are required to continue playing past a certain point which is very frustrating. 

On top of that the enemy AI are extremely frustrating, they'll see you behind walls and kill you with the flick of an eyelash. Stealth is not really an option even when it seems like it would be normally in the previous game. But the worst part about this game is that it feels like a walking simulator. There are so many amazing set pieces and areas filled with beautiful detail that look incredible but you can't explore it because you're locked on rails like it's a Pokemon Snap game. So many quick time events that you can't avoid, and levels like Red Square and The Garden that make you want to slam your head into a brick wall because of how unfair it is, especially as the last few levels of the game where you feel like you're almost done and the game just punishes you with levels that will probably take you days to complete on their own. The game feels like it's punishing you for playing it because you can't complete the story once you get to these impossible road blocks. Normally, you would be rewarded for progressing in a game and reaching the end. Not in Last Light. The Red Square level makes me not even want to play this game ever again because it's all RNG luck and no matter what you do, you can't actually do anything about it except hope and pray the game blesses you with good RNG after a million times of restarting this one single fight, after hours and hours and hours of being stuck on one impossible mission. 

So many moments in this game where you're only option is to run around in circles like an idiot for 10minutes while you wait for an NPC to take a grandma-paced joy ride on a long drawn out sequence with wave after wave after wave after wave of of unkillable enemy hoards that you can't do anything about and simply have to wait your whole life for until it's finally over. It kills the immersion completely and the majority of the fun since this will be the experience you'll get for the majority of the game's missions. Fair warning.

I don't know why it's like that. The first game METRO 2033 didn't feel like that as much.

Like most people, I came for the survival horror exploration elements, and got a GTA-V-strip-club, Call-of-Duty-quick-time, Pokemon-Snap-on-rails hybrid with a Fallout stamp on it. You can't explore, you're stuck on rails. The AI and wave after wave after wave after wave of unkillable enemies that see like an eagle that you can't sneak past, quick time moments, walking simulator moments, and genuinely impossible levels like Red Square just make this game right on the edge of unbearable to play. 

I genuinely love the METRO series. I have played both METRO 2033 and METRO Last Light on the hardest difficulty (Survival Ranger Hardcore) two times each. I will definitely be playing 2033 again and can highly recommend that game. But Last Light on the other hand, I'm at a crossroads with. If you're a hardcore fan of the series, you'll want to finish this chapter of the story. But play on EASY difficulty. Trust me.

If you're a casual gamer looking for a fun experience into the METRO world, Last Light is NOT it. I recommend trying out METRO 2033 Redux and/or METRO Exodus first. Both of those games are amazing.

a lot of people that have given this a bad review post that the story is "boring" but truth be told; just because the world isnt going to explode or the flood from halo isnt on the way etc. or some other massive  whatever doesnt mean that the story is lacking. peersonally i really enjoyed the story and the gameplay. it really surprised me how much i liked this game and ive already bought the more expensive more recent metro game. it takes place in russia and it is not as "decisions matter" as many games like dishonored or life is strange, however, for what it is it is a really well made game. especially considering the year it was made. dont discount it just because its not 12\10 on everything. it is still a game after all and think of it this way. if you spend $20 on a game. it provides a whole little story/world/etc. of experiences which you can play again if you wished..... or you could order a pizza and breadsticks for the same price and have a temporary pleasantry which will be so much sooner forgotten and lost to time. give the game a shot.

Metro Last light is a linear horror shooter taking place in a post-apocalyptic universe, it is the direct continuation of Metro 2033.

Taking up the universe of the previous game, we find again the different factions, a good bestiary and once again a very good story. There is still the loot system where during the adventure you can find materials to improve your weapons in a complete way, you also have to manage the filter of your gas mask to be able to pass in some areas of the game.

The combat system is also very satisfying, as in the first one you can do it by shooting everything that moves or in infiltration with various equipment for the 2 styles of play. There are once again two different endings depending on the choices you make during your adventure.

In conclusion, Metro Last Light is the sequel to 2033, so I recommend to play the first one first and then go on with this one, the gameplay is very similar to the previous one, only the story is really new.

Metro Last Light is a very good game. Personally the best way I can describe it? It's like a diamond with some rough edges.

It improves on the game-play in just about every single way from Metro 2033 and is a better game on almost every technical level. That being said, I feel it lacks the emotional core of the previous games story-line, instead going for a plot that feels both shallow and rushed.

It follows Artyom sometime after the events of Metro 2033's bad ending, i.e the canon conclusion. Without spoiling anything, the plot revolves around all the factions fighting for control over the D6 bunker which the Ranger faction now occupies after you discovered it at the end of the last game. The story will take you all across the metro all over again after an incident results in your capture and thus needing to re-link with your group.

It's fairly well paced, makes sense and motivations for the various factions are set-up early, however, its just not as engaging or interesting this time around imo. The factions have always been pretty one-note in the Metro series, hence why they're background and weren't the main focus of the last game. It really just comes down to the typical good faction/bad faction. This is fine as light context for a factions personality, but when you make these factions are a core part of the plot, I felt like more nuance was needed. Even the characters feel simplified this time around with the exception of a couple. Anna in particular is a massive missed opportunity. In this game in particular, her introduction and inclusion in the narrative is done incredibly poorly. She has no long-form and natural character arc, she kinda just completely changes her personality each time you see her until she becomes your half-arsed love interest. It just felt lazy.

Thankfully, everything else is an improvement.

Graphics wise, the game still looks amazing to this day, although the redux probably helps. The environments and weather effects in particular when you're up top look insanely good. The lighting is also a standout with some nice god rays and particle effects. Overall this game is still a knockout in the graphics department.

The game is also very polished. Running it maxed out at 1440p, it runs flawlessly the whole time with no stutters and the game was basically bug free the whole time.

In game-play, Last Light aims to polish the predecessor and it succeeds very well. Gunplay feels great thanks to both the good hit feedback as well as the stellar sound design. There are more weapons here than the previous game and they're far more modifiable than before. Stealth actually works properly now and is more fleshed out, allowing you to play most of your human encounters like its metal gear. Proper boss-fights are included more often now, however they are pretty standard and don't add all that much.

The difficulty levels return in full also. I played through the entire game this time on Hardcore Ranger Mode, the hardest difficulty and it was quite a challenge. For the most part, it was very fair but every so often you'd run into a section where it clearly wasn't designed for this challenge and the game would kick my ass. I wouldn't recommend this difficulty for your first experience however, seeing as it removes all hud elements including the quicktime prompts, meaning if you don't know them already, you'll fail them over and over again.

It about the same length as the previous game, both taking me just over 7 hours to beat on the hardest difficulty. It's not gonna' blow you away in the story department, but its incredibly fun, immersive and there's nothing out there quite like the Metro series. These games go on sale for dirt cheap all the time, so please check them out when you can, they're great shooters.

Metro Last Light as a sequel of the Metro 2033 was released in 2013. Developers have heard their fans and have hard worked in the mistakes from previous part.
The plot of the game is same good. The game is a direct continuation of 2033 and without knowing what is happening in the first part - it is very difficult to understand the second. We may see how character develops. His fluctuations in terms of morality, which we commit by certain actions. And all this in a compartment gives us 2 endings, as in the prequel.

I remember how fans were discussing that good ending may be myth, because it was really hard to get it. I played game twice - first in 2014 after the release and second time the console version. Both times I couldnтАЩt achieve the good ending.

The game showed us totally new version of the Metro universe. The game stopped to be such dark and scary as has been 2033. Last light is more cheerful, we may see flashbacks from the time before apocalypse. And the universe has developed, from the very beginning we get to know about new clans that oppose us. Gameplay became much easier and less hardcore - if previous Metro 2033 always tempted you to go into stealth, the Metro Last Light gives you an ability to choose. Personally me in both parts always decided to go into direct confrontation and choose more shooter and less stealth. 

I enjoyed the Metro Last Light, the game is exactly the same as the prequel, but at the same time completely different. Those who loved the gloom of the Metro 2033, in Last Light it will be very much missed, as was for me. But all the disadvantages that can be seen during the play do not spoil the overall impression of the passage, even after so many years after the release of the game.

[h1] METRO LAST LIGHT REDUX - REVIEW: BRO THAT SHIT IS GOOD [/h1]

Ok so I finished this game right after having finished Metro 2033 so this review is gonna be based on my experience following a order. Also on Ranger difficulty same as the first game.

So I think I enjoyed this game way more than I did enjoy the first Metro. The story here is a lil more complex with a lot of plot twist's to understand that will get you engaged af. While in the first game you just GO CRAZY about the Dark Ones and almost EXTERMINATE their entire race just because people believe that they are evil and worse than any other kind of creature out there in Metro: Last Light you have a way more well constructed story and characters motivations to actions, it's not as nonsense as the first game.

No words to describe the characters and your relationships with them, this game was made to make you feel like you are friends with them that shit is amazing. 

The only negative point I got it's the pacing of the game, the first hours are nicely entertaining but the last hour of the game is just a pain in the ass OMG. The resources just go almost nonexistent and it's the same thing killing Watchmen and Lurkers running from Shrimps in the rain and it doesn't stop raining. The fight with the Bear is very easy to go through and pretty cool, not bad, same thing for the first boss.
This is what keeps me engaged with the Metro Series 'cause even when the game can be a pain in the ass it rewards you with chill moments of character development and cozy ambience just walking around some station watching people interact with the world and you.

Well if you like the post-apocalyptic post-soviet russian shooter survival horror tactical genre Metro: Last Light is definitely worth EVERY cent you spend with it. I'd recommend it to everyone.

The theme of Last Light is redemption, and thankfully this entry corrects many major problems with 2033. I enjoyed nearly all of the base game. There's also a lot of DLC included, but after trying the infuriating Faction Pack Heavy level, I ended up skipping most of the rest except for the story-based Chronicles Pack levels.

Most notes below are largely relative to 2033 Redux:

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Proper explanation of most mechanics!
+Mission objectives almost (*) always clear!
+Ability to test a number of guns at the start!
+Less point-blank fights against hordes of mobs!
+More guns
+More enemy types
+Can still replay chapters
+Still lots of difficulties
+More engaging and understandable story
+Some likeable and returning NPC's

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Slightly more FPS gameplay vs survival of 2033
~Intro cutscene can be skipped with Use key, but this isn't documented
~Semi-hidden morality system still exists
~Couple of counter-intuitive morality results
~Really need ability to drag bodies
~NPCs still talk over one another. Subtitles on everything would be nice.
~Early periods of visceral violence, nudity, frequent references to rape
~Alerted enemies make everyone nearby instantly omniscient
~Few areas where stealth is very difficult
~Hard to finding the right spot where corpses are lootable
~Backstabbing mutants is unpredictable

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Checkpoint save system still sucks for stealth or short play times
-Still can't read journal entries if you bound 'F' elsewhere
-(*) Final level has one section of absolute lack of direction during a heated situation, leading to a lot of frustration and bad memories of 2033.

While I loved Metro 2033 I'm going to say no to this one. I'm gonna say don't even play Last Light. Don't do it!

So let's cover all the basics: what feels like 70% of this game possibly more is reused assets from Metro 2033, it's in the same engine with little iteration, and while some aspects feel like 4A had a bit more of a budget to work with, I hated Last Light by the end.

While the gunplay and shooting in Metro 2033 are what I would call adequate or serviceable, they are inadequate in this game particularly when you spend a significantly larger portion of the game shooting guys. Combat engagements in this game don't actually feel terribly fun, and the developers leaned HARD into the 'stealth-oriented gameplay' playstyle that was possible in the first game, to the point where I am sure you could play this game as a traditional shooter and skip all stealth - but it'd be ABSURDLY hard because this time around the game is extremely stingy with resources.

Keys and safes in the first game, while it felt like a cute little bonus basically for fully exploring an entire area, is something that I basically just lost patience with in playing this game, but safes as it happens are also one of the most important sources of loot. The key placements are haphazard and bizarre, just like the balance of ammunition the game awards you with, and particularly when you're fighting against the clock (and your filter count, which fortunately is something the game is NOT stingy) it's a bad feel running around getting increasingly frustrated asking WHERE IS THE KEY while you search a room for the sixtieth time. So I hated that.

The enemy variety in this game is just the same as the first, except I guess maybe people complained about a lack of bosses, so this game has like 8 bosses and all of them are fairly dull and basically the same idea over and over and they have bizarre extremely difficult to avoid attacks, and at least one boss can't be dodged at all from what I could tell. The game also definitely doesn't adequately prepare you for bosses, especially given you can on at least one occasion see back-to-back bosses!

Your weapon selection this time is a little more rigid, since ammo is scarce now, money is definitely scarce, and there is a massive surplus of shotgun shells, so you best hope you can fit a shambler or whatever in your loadout. The sniper rifle is completely worthless and it was basically a wasted slot for almost my entire playthrough, and it seems to me a great example of a noob trap that looks like it might be useful against bosses, but then when you fight them they don't seem to take nearly as much damage from it as they do from, say, a pipebomb. So you end up carrying around a useless weapon you're saving for a boss or whatever that can't be suppressed so you don't really want to use it against humans, and only VERY rarely has ammo available for it. So I didn't enjoy this either.

I also was not happy with some of the developments in the story, and it even felt like there were bizarre choices made with regards to how the story opens, what it takes from the first game, and it even feels like they retconned a few things, basically, to patch up holes in the original narrative?

Last Light was released in 2013, too, so honestly even at the time it felt a little bit dated, given the engine at this point was at least 3 years old and hadn't received any major tune-ups. While it's not terrible, it feels a lot like a DLC project that got too big and was turned into its own game.

Oh also I should mention, this game significantly tones down the supernatural, mysterious qualities of Metro 2033, explains many of them, introduces one or two new baffling things that AREN'T explained, and then humanises 'The Dark Ones' to the point where you completely understand them and then suddenly the entire sense of wonderment and mystery is completely lost which is a crippling blow the game and the game's setting cannot recover from, because suddenly everything seems mundane and crude. 

The game loses a LOT from the absence of the mystique of the Metro, particularly because you are then just subject to the dull earthly qualities of humans shooting at other humans. And it is boring.

I would not recommend this game unless you maybe LOVED Metro 2033 and just thought the gameplay was the most riveting stuff ever, because I don't think the story is really well developed or compelling this time around. It's not terrible but I did not have a good time playing it, there were too many segments that were frustrating, annoying, or tedious for me to really love it.

Metro: Last Light is a phenomenal game, absolutely beautiful. One problem, a problem that starts from the beginning to the end. The way they rule out who gets the bad and good ending is very... unfair? See, you must save the Bear, don't kill Letsnitsky and Pavel, remove the mask, explore and interact with people, give the teddy bear to the kid crying, save the Prisoners, save the Caravan, and just listen on some conversation. Though, Letsnitsky deserved to die plus I have no feelings towards him, never once had any care, while I saved Pavel cause I actually had some emotion towards him, and he was full of sadness, not anger says the little one, so I believed he can have one more chance. The bear being saved is just stupid, how would we know to do that? The Teddy one is simple, since you actually have a loud dialogue tell you if you simply just snoop around a bit. Overall, this game is great, but the ending choices are wayyyy to strict, If i want to legitimately get the whole ending, without watching a youtube video (of course I watched the video on the good ending) then I would have to replay the game from nearly the start. Its a great ruling for a person who is kind and doesn't engross themselves in this game, but its a game of death, I'm killing those who don't deserve it or I'm saving those who I have emotional attachment to. If I have no attachment to it, it attacks me because its defending its kids, yet I'm no where near them, why have me save it since I personally shouldn't have any emotional attachment to it. Other than that somewhat large flaw, the game is phenomenal. 8.5/10

Metro: Last Light is a survival game first and foremost, so play on higher difficulties. Supplies are often in shortage so every combat encounter has a lot of weight to it.

Combat is tactical but stealth feels too forgiving, since the player character has much better dark vision then the npcs which is something I really don't like. I recommend turning down your gamma to the third or fourth lowest level. That way you actually need to use your flashlight and nvg.

There's a really unfair boss battle at one point.

The story is rather predictable from the beginning, but it's still worth paying attention since there are plenty of smaller details, especially in casual npc dialogue. You can listen in on conversations while you're sneaking around which reveal plot points.

I enjoyed this title towards the end of 2022 after playing Metro Exodus.  To be sure, Metro Exodus is the superior title, clearly, but Last light was surprisingly good.  This is a story driven, first person shooter full of magnificent world building, tension and shooter action.  The visuals are absolutely lovely, although showing their age slightly... but only slightly.  The performance was as expected: buttery smooth.

The aspects I enjoyed the most about this title are the world building and story.  Trudging underground to several human outposts / colonies is great and exploring the colonies themselves were my favorite part of the game.  The imagination on display here is top notch.  Seeing how people survive underground was awesome.

The battle mechanics are absolutely fine.  I enjoyed toying with and modding the weapons and testing out all the possibilities.  There are many cramped and intense moments underground but there are also a few overworld levels that are also quite intense.  
 
     This game is not chill at all.  It is suspenseful and stressful.  Looks beautiful with great. imaginative design and plays well.  If you enjoy linear, single player shooter experiences that are immersive and engaging, you will enjoy this title.  

Recommended!

This game sucks, I played it on ranger mode an while the stealth aspect is ok, the areas out in the open or fighting mutants is a game ruiner.

1. Linear gameplay - go from point A to B
2. Cheap enemies, mainly the mutants. They gang up on you and are bullet sponges. What's worse is the MAGICAL bad timing, the split second I'm reloading or putting on a mask, WOW there they are, bam bam bam I'm dead. 
3. Crappy realistic guns that run out with swarms of foes all over you, you will die again an again because you are busy reloading, trying to heal or switching guns. 
4. Cheap boss fights because of 1-3
5. Filters for the mask die out way too fast. My menu said I had 15 minutes..............I counted, it was more like 30 seconds to a minute. Yknow, why can't they figure out a way for me to enjoy the scenery outside, instead it's RUSH RUSH RUSH. Why bother even making the levels, no ones going to enjoy them. 
5. Got so sick of having these annoying check points save with me with ZERO filters left, so I had to always restart the entire chapter an speed run my way through already knowing where everything was. 
6. No go zones - Well this looks like I can skirt along this way O wait, invisible wall, instant death, etc, etc. Yet there are areas you can go you dont think you can go so you are always second guessing.
7. Horrible fast action paced FPS but with "realistic guns & physics". These games are supposed to be about survival an resource management, yet they ram hard hitting FPS action in my face but hamper me with this BS. Trying to fight a boss but everything is going wrong because my guns are empty, I can't see because it's too dark, controls are clunky & overly complicated. They dont' give you the option to sneak past the boss or to deal with the situation with smarts rather than brawn. It let's you play stealthy one moment...................then shoves you into a cage fight to get royally creamed. 
8. Annoying auto-saves which works horribly, nothing I like better than reloading all my guns an getting stuff over & over because I hit the auto save before resetting all my gear, then die because I'm right before a boss fight or hard spot.
9. Bugs & glitches - My sprint button stopped working permamently for some odd reason. Plenty of other bugs too like this. Like I'm gasping for air in an area that doesn't need a mask. These glitches can't be fixed, you have to restart the entire chapter if they show up.
10. Un-beatable epic fights that are CHEAP AF. the worse is the ambush, you have snipers all over you, an they send a bunch of guys after you, an it's un-winnable. Even if you know where everyone is, an plan the game CHEATS, an that's what this game does all the time, CHEAT. I put up mines where all the enemies would show up, I sniped the snipers getting three before things even started, an it was BS cause they were BULLET SPONGES, I was smashing them with headshots an they just shrugged it off O BUT they kill me literally instantly. An then to top it all off, suddenly the ground guys started shooting rockets at me, while that annoying "see through stuff" vision was on. An they were INSANELY bullet spongey, wtf.
11. Just drags on, they literally have you do the same thing over & over & over, to the point "O look a safe key, yeah I dont' care, nothing in those safes I need anyway." By the time the game is almost finished you are just ramming through the levels as fast as possible cause you are just sick of it
12. This is a big one, but it's "game dev rigged" game play. Example, the "knife throwing" system is absolute trash, I lost count how many times I missed someone by 0.00025 inches. it's insane an it's obvious they programmed that in so you don't run around knifing everyone. That's what they did, they sabotaged an NERFED the mechanic so it didn't get over used. When I toss a knife an it misses by a nanometer, an then I adjust an throw again an it goes exactly like the first one, then yknow they programmed it like that. Any gamer hates game devs who program win or lose like that, from "auto-aims" to enemies not attacking or attacking harder based on data. Either hand holding or deliberate sabotage to make things way harder than it should have been. It was very obvious during the train ride where I had to shoot the rail car enemies, an I KNeW I was putting shots on them but I was missing an dying a lot. Well I recorded a video an watched it in slow motion, an that's what I do when I sense something is off cause I'm really good at "hip shooting" in video games. Well I counted, 1, 3, 5 shots that clearly landed on the body, an did NOTHING, O but when I zoom in an go for a head shot, that's the only time they register. So the devs rigged it so unless you AIM through the sights, the hit box on enemies gets SMALLER while it's the opposite when you aim through the sights, the hit box gets BIGGER. RIGGED!

Clearly this game was puked out for the Call of Duty crowd, it's nothing like the first game. This is a game series that was supposed to let the player play the game "their way" but it won't let you when fighting mutants. 

Am I playing an Action based FPS or a survival game ? Pick one
I've played HARD games an games with SUPER HARD mode, an the golden rule is, if the control is solid, if the enemies don't CHEAT an they give you a fair chance, then it's good. This game CHEATS. One moment enemies go down with a few "broad" hits to the torso, an then they are shrugging off head shots an turn into bullet sponges.

Ok so gottah say something good.

1. Mature content for a mature world - Yes we have strippers an all that, nudity. That's really the few sell points of these games, they don't censor an yet don't shove it in there just to up the edge factor. It fits for the world you are in.
2. Story is excellent.........if you don't mind the fact they went with the BAD ending in Metro 2033, that pissed me off.
3. All the writing & story has stayed good.

Yeah, that's about it, so basically you can watch a youtube "game movie" of Metro Last Light an enjoy it but you won't like actually playing it. 

After Metro Exodus, this will be the last game I buy from this lousy company. I don't care if they sell it on steam on sale for $1

The metro series is for all intents and purposes: a russian fallout knockoff. I've played both Metro Exodus, and Metro Last Light Redux, and they both emphasize realism over actual fun gameplay. The filter system in both games is poorly designed, with very few indicators(if any) telling you that are suffocating. 

The linear design of this game does benefit it, but overall I find it hard to care about the story or the characters presented throughout the course of the game. Then, there are levels like the swamp: where the marker are obscured to the point that you are running around in circles looking for the level exit. The shooting is fine, and the art team did an excellent job building the appearance of a post nuclear society.

Other than that I don't have anything good to say about this game. This game gets a 4/10 from me. Don't waste your money, and go play fallout instead.

Last Light is probably the weakest link in the Metro saga of games, and its still damn good and better than 95 percent of FPSs. Some people prefer the style of the original Metro 2033 over Last Light and 2033 Redux but i personally think you can't go wrong in any way when picking a version to play, as long as you play the series sequentially. While not necessary, playing 2033 or its Redux first will give you some knowledge of your character, the other characters in Last Light and the state of the world in this universe.

So why is this one the "weak" link of the series?
The story is a bit overambitious, balancing three major plot threads in conjunction with each other that eventually meet near the end the form the whole picture in a way that can feel a little confusing and cumbersome. Without spoiling too much, the importance of the young Dark One, the D6 substation where the Rangers (the player's faction) occupy, and the villains plot all flip flop around enough to where the context of each level can feel a little muddy--"are you looking for the Dark One or working against the villain this level?" is a question you'll encounter a few times.
that said, the story is still quite good, with well written faction relationships,  interesting characters, a sorta believable/well acted romance, etc. It can get predictable sure, but it should keep you invested during a few playthroughs. Again, it works best as a sequel to 2033, as characters and scenarios from that game are mentioned and this game's story operates as a near-immediate sequel.

Gameplay wise, i think most people will point out its immersive qualities. Survival in the Metro is relatively straight forward, be stealthy-save ammo, avoid mutants if possible, etc, but the surface levels are saturated in radiation, meaning a gas mask and appropriate filter time is needed to traverse. Luckily, even on the Ranger Modes, survival is never too hard as long as you explore; you don't need to hit every nook and cranny, but you'll find bodies with ammo littered everywhere, stashes of ammo, meds, filters, etc are in safes and those safes are never too far from their keys visible by a red ribbon. Similar to its predecessor and its successor, Metro Exodus, there are "moral points" scattered around levels for doing certain things. Plenty of these are tied to exploration, so if you look around thoroughly, you should have no trouble getting the "good/canon" ending. Other moral points are tied to clear moments of choice, like choosing to forgive or kill a certain character, or killing a surrendering enemy. 

My favorite aspect of this game, and by extension each other Metro game, is how levels flow together and are given enough context through the narrative to feel like a real Odyssey. Artyom (you) never just skips past entire sections to get to the next story beat, rather each story beat involves getting to the next one and traversing large amounts of ground is part of working each level. This definitely adds to the immersion as your loadout and such from one level persists into the next and such.

The worst things about this game are largely related to its survival mechanics. For example, it is POSSIBLE to soft lock yourself on a surface level with no way out if you dont have enough filter time. stuff like this is avoidable as long as you explore thoroughly, but its still a possibility. The other worst thing is that there are like 2 difficulty spikes relating to "boss mutants" in later levels that could potentially halt progress as well. 

It'll take somewhere between 12-16 hours to beat the game once and thats without doing any of the DLC chapters that are included.

good
really fun game, really fucking scary

Fantastic game that oozes with immersion and atmosphere, if you liked Metro 2033 then Last Light will be an absolute must.

Stealth is quite good borrowing elements from Splinter Cell where lights will affect how visible you are, it is very satisfying ghosting through the level with no kills.

Completed the game a minute ago! On the highest difficulty as well! I must admit that although quite challenging it was incredibly rewarding and fun to play. I recommend to everyone to play the game on hardcore ranger for the best immersion possible.
Absolutely brilliant game
One of the best post apocalyptic video games. Recommended if you are into eastern Europe vibes and post apocalyptic fps
A continuation of the first game. Still a solid story even though i enjoyed the first game more (they kept my favourite gun from me till towards the end) a very solid game. 8/10
Blyat

This is what a story-driven action game should be like. An incredible adventure from start to finish, a roller-coaster of an adventure with ups and downs, similar to the high adrenaline adventures of the Uncharted games. Loved every second of story-telling. In terms of gameplay, I believe it is an upgrade from 2033, although I can't quite identify the specific elements that were improved.

TLDR; 10/10, a masterpiece in every way imaginable.

Review By Chat GPT.
Metro: Last Light Redux is a post-apocalyptic survival shooter game that was released in 2014 for the PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and PC. Developed by 4A Games, it is a reimagined and remastered version of Metro: Last Light, which was initially released in 2013. The game is set in the year 2034 in post-apocalyptic Moscow, Russia, where the player must survive against mutated creatures, hostile humans, and a hostile environment.

The game focuses on a group of survivors who live in the underground metro system in Moscow. The player takes control of Artyom, a young man who is struggling to find a way to save his species from extinction. As he travels through the metro, he learns of a conspiracy involving a powerful weapon and the mysterious Dark Ones. He must also face the dangers of the surface world, where mutated creatures and hostile humans are a constant threat.

Gameplay in Metro: Last Light Redux is a combination of first-person shooter and survival horror. Players must traverse the underground metro system in search of weapons, ammunition, and supplies while fighting off hordes of mutated creatures and hostile humans. Players can also scavenge the environment for supplies such as food and medical supplies. Artyom also has the ability to craft makeshift weapons and gadgets from the scrap he finds.

The game also includes a new Ranger Mode, which is a more difficult version of the game. In Ranger Mode, players have limited ammunition and supplies, and must scavenge more frequently to survive. There is also an alternate ending in Ranger Mode, which provides a more satisfying conclusion to the game.

The visuals and audio in Metro: Last Light Redux are stunning. The environments are detailed and immersive, and the lighting effects are particularly impressive. The soundtrack is also excellent and provides a great atmosphere.

Overall, Metro: Last Light Redux is an excellent game that offers an intense and thrilling post-apocalyptic experience. The visuals, audio, and gameplay are all top notch, and the Ranger Mode provides an extra layer of challenge for those looking for a more difficult experience. Metro: Last Light Redux is an excellent game that is well worth playing for fans of post-apocalyptic survival shooters.

"You reap what you sow, Artyom. Force answers force, war breeds war, and death only brings death. To break this vicious circle one must do more than just act without any thought or doubt."

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone that enjoys shooters in combination with an immersive story. I played through the game on normal difficulty.

The gun play is really good, perhaps not comparable to the best shooters out there, but the controls are responsive and there's a decent arsenal to choose from. You can also customize your weapons to make them suit your preferred style of play better.

The story is pretty engrossing, even though the characters seem pretty one dimensional at times, and their motivations are somewhat questionable from time to time. There are cut-scenes and quite a few pages of lore and information to be read. The balance between actual gun play and story is well done though, it doesn't feel like a quicktime adventure.

The graphics still hold up in 2022, at least according to me.

its a good game, there are times where the mechanics of the game are slightly confusing, and if you do something wrong on a save the next part becomes nearly impossible to complete, like as if you were to get in a boss battle with 40 bullets remaining. but overall i heavily recommend this game, ive completed it twice, the first time was just exploring and the second was a speed run. you'll love it just download it. its free!

Metro: Last Light is a bold post-apocalyptic FPS adventure uniquely told from the Russian point of view. Last LightтАЩs setting and presentation are its strong points, though the last third  campaign is Outstanding everything that came before it. If you want a fun first-person shooter that doesnтАЩt remotely rise to the greatness of single player-centric adventures like BioShock but is still fun in its own right, then Last Light may just be for you.

Metro: Last Light continues where [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/286690/]Metro 2033[/url] ended... [spoiler]that is, if you got the 'bad ending'... which is actually the 'good ending' (confusing, I know).[/spoiler] As you know by now from the previous game, you can either choose action or stealth in your playthrough, but your choices have consequences. Nothing big - because NPCs will treat you the same regardless - but it does determine your ending. Again, you get these subtle 'moral points' for 'doing the right thing' and even a penalty if you do not do 'the right thing'. This time it is less obscure than in the previous game. Regardless, you should play the game however you like without worrying about these 'moral points' (although, if you have not figured it out by now, this game is trying to teach you something...).

Contrary to the previous game, I felt that the gas mask filters situation was a lot better. I still almost ran out of air a few times, but I always made it (or maybe I just got better at filter management, haha). Selecting stuff from my inventory was a lot clearer now too. Everything just felt a lot smoother. The interactions with certain NPCs are also a lot more dynamic. There was one in particular that really grew on me (and I am sure on a lot of other people as well).

From all three Metro games, Metro: Last Light has the most DLC and there is quite a bit of it. It ranges from blasting through enemies with your weapons of choice, from a few stories where you take control of Artyom's friends to glue some missing pieces together, to a really cool scavenger level and, ugh... spiders. Oh, how those spiders in the Metro series freak me out...

Overall, I highly recommend this game. I had a thrill ride right from the beginning all the way up until the end! :-)

Solid sequel to Metro 2033

There's a tradeoff of the mutant horror, and slower pacing that made the first more immersive for a faster, more cinematic approach. I miss it but I can see the benefits in focusing on the human characters more, and the child near the end is worth the wait in adding characterization to an enemy whose personality felt empty in substance in the last story. It's still an exciting story, but in its own way through a greater focus on human optimism. I see it in how the stations feel more alive, the refined morality system especially rewarding mercy, and the side conversations not rooted in cheap sentimentality but humanism. 

There are a few misteps, with Anna's romance rushed, Khan losing his cool till it feels out of character, some damage sponge enemies, the level design not being intuitive in telling you which path is side content and which will lock you out by leading you to the next area, and the conspiracy narrative becoming a bit convoluted in the middle. 

Still, I think I prefer this one between the first two.

7/10

An amazing sequel to the perfect predecessor game Metro 2033. The game takes the extensive world that was built in Metro 2033 and further expands upon it even further with more chapters on the surface allowing for the player to get to see more of the destroyed, dark, and desolate world. Also enjoyed how it expanded upon some of the factions introduced in 2033 and made the conflict feel much more real to you as the player and the characters around you.  However the moral points system which effects the ending of the game is extremely flawed leaving the good ending quite difficult to get despite making good decisions.
This game is so under rated one of the must play of the Metro series.

Very good game, got all three and the dlc for Exodus a little while back, I've only played through once so far but i'm definitely considering another couple playthroughs for the first two. I'm installing Exodus as I write this.

Metro Last Light is an amazing game, was my first played of the series on the 360, so naturally i picked it up for Pc with its prior installment 2033 when it went on sale. I would of spent full price if I had the funds to do so. 
Gunplay and stealth are both great, story is amazing, the game has a lot of heart and soul put into it by 4A games.
I may play on potato mode, but it still looks great.
I recomend both this and 2033 at worthy games to add to a collection.

Sequels are difficult if the first one impressed you. You have to build on it and show something more than just story line as requirement for a sequel.
And that is where I feel Last Light has succeeded. The world of metro will always be special to me. Like Artyom said, Humanity just don't die. And that's how Metro in Last Light Redux. We can see advancements in technology and the fact that theatre still exists. And that in a tough and dark world, compassion can still survive.
They also did bring in new characters and gave them a lot of depth. Brought us more and varied mutants to kill. 
Definitely has to be my favorite Metro game of the two I have played so far.

Feels like the same game as Metro 2033, apart from the story of course. Really enjoyed the play through.

Metro: Last Light takes what made Metro 2033 good and improves on it. It feels similar enough to the original game but different that it's not the same game. 

The story is improved from Metro 2033, it feels slightly more believable in my opinion, and it takes you through many new and exciting places. It's dark, and the rest of the game really helps to make this believable.

The combat is improved, guns feel more believable and real now, and there are more. I've done 2 playthroughs and enjoyed using different weapons on both. The music is once again awesome. 

The downside is that the game is more buggy than before. It kept crashing or freezing, and the levels take quite a long time to load for me. These are only really small things, though.

Overall, I'd give it a solid 8/10 and definitely recommend you get it on sale!

Even better than the first one. More time outside, a greater variety of locations, and enemies. Overall this is one of the games that feels done right.
8/10 its a pretty immersive game the story is great losing points for certain game mechanics

The story is much longer than its predecessor, with more moments on the surface that let us see the beautiful wasteland of Moscow and make us watch our filters even more than ever. Added new mutants that fit very well into the atmosphere of the Metro games. The zones have also been reworked, not as scary as the first one but much more vast with some places to explore, the game does not lose its linear side as much as the first one. New boss fights that are really full mutants, not like the first one where it was mostly horde/massive enemies or rail shooter moments. Once again, play Hardcore Ranger difficulty. Compared to the first one, I recommend the Spartan mode because the game seems to have been designed for this mode. I found myself many times in situations where stealth was impossible because the enemies saw you too much or even while looting and looking around, I had a very big lack of ammunition that made me get stuck on certain levels. The addition of several DLC is also very interesting, some are no more than arcade but others can bring some additional information to the universe of Metro. In short, once again very good game, I can only recommend if you loved Metro 2033 Redux.

Great first person atmospheric shooter.
If you want a linear FPS where every encounter is tense and deadly then this game is for you. The tight resource management made me second guess every encounter with enemies. Whether or not to start a fight, use stealth, or find a different path altogether.
However the resource management itself is like a double edged sword to the gameplay, because on the other hand, it restricts players from fully using all the "toys" the game has to offer. Although there is a combat-focused free DLC to fix that, where you can just go ham.
I recommend this game, but not as much as the first game, Metro 2033 / Metro 2033 Redux

Great game

This was a great sequel to the first game. Every aspect of game play was improved from the first, the story was immersive and compelling and kept me hooked throughout the whole game. The gun-play is pretty identical to the first game but felt much smoother, maybe the minor mouse acceleration was removed. 

The story is very unique and original as the plot unfolds in way that I've never seen in an 'Post-Apocalyptic' genre. It really manages to embed a memorable experience. Basically the story follows up a year after the first game and you go through another journey with Artyom as he finds the truth about the dark ones and how he can seek forgiveness or at least find some closure for what he did to the dark ones home, since he now knows that what he did was wrong and that the dark ones were no real threat.  

Highly recommend this game, like the previous one.

Ive just finished this game to completion straight after doing the same with 2033 and its a direct continuation of the story so its definitely recommended to play that first. Its got the same mechanics, atmosphere, gameplay etc. Its got extra boobies though so that a plus. Theres a couple of extra weapons in this game but no much else is different apart from the story. I cant decide which is better as I enjoyed the whole thing as one experience having played them back to back. 

This one has some extra included DLC where you play as different characters whom you meet through the main game which was real nice to flesh out a little more of the story even though they were quite short. Seriously though f@ck the Tower DLC haha, that made me sweat and my OCD would not allow me to leave it uncomplete as theres an achievement for finishing it even though it has nothing to do with the main story.

Some very annoying bugs popped up where I couldnt progress in a level as it kept crashing to desktop and I had to restart the whole level. This happened me twice. Other than that it was an almost flawless experience from start to finish. Highly recommended. 

I got these games for about 2 bucks each on sale. Amazing value for money.
amazing game

[h1] Better? Faster? Stronger? [/h1]

The sequel feels exactly like its predecessor in terms of graphics, and gameplay, however, what makes it better - the level design. As always the chapters are quite linear and you don't deviate much from the fixed path, but the world is filled with beautiful details, astonishing views of the desolated land and is pretty lively considering the setting. Hats off for the flashbacks that cut you deep and put you in the mood for the full submersion.

What I love and admire is that the story is not forced on you but it's made in the way that you enjoy it and your finger doesn't accidentally slip on the skip button.

Outside the main story you have some additional missions that are pure gold and send you back to the locations of Metro 2033.

Overall, Metro: Last Light feels like an improvement that will be an enjoyable experience. The only decision that you need to make is whether to be a sneaky snake or a killing machine.
Great and imersive sequel to the og Metro 2033

Absolutely fantastic sequel to the Metro 2033 game/book. It's absolutely incredible. 

10/10.
A little touched
Great Game

A massive setup up to 2033 in every possible way. Graphics are incredible for a game that came out 9 years ago, and the gameplay doesn't feel dated like it does with 2033. Almost a flawless experience, the only two complaints I have are bullet sponge mutants and the assault rifle changing to the currency ammo on its own if you tend to reload every few shots (even if you have hundreds of dirty ammo). Sometimes I realized halfway through the chapter I've been shooting money, highly annoying.

I started and finished Metro: Last Light Redux right after I finished Metro 2033. Every aspect of the first Metro game has been enhanced and improved in every aspect, from gameplay to graphics. My review is more of a recap of my own experiences and opinions of the game, not really a review that helps a decision in purchasing the game or not. Well I do recommend it if you're looking for some random sign to buy the game lol
Spoilers ahead.

First, the stealth is vastly better than before. Levels are designed to allow for a more polished and enjoyable stealth approach, and you can knock enemies out by pressing a button prompt when behind an enemy instead of the weird punching attack that rarely worked in the first game (unless I was doing it wrong the entire time, then uh oops). Shooting out / turning off lights was fun, and watching enemies react to the lights being turned off was cool. They always did this weird slow walk when they're alerted, and they inch around in the dark like snails.

Gameplay is a lot more improved. Hard to describe, but it is definitely better in some way. 

What I think is the most improved is the graphics. The graphics in Metro LL is absolutely fantastic. The crowded metro areas have some truly extravagant lighting and attention to detail, and are so full of life. The lighting in Metro LL is one of the best I have ever seen. The surface, the destroyed buildings in the distance, underground caves, abandoned buildings and locations, even the most insignificant of hallways, sewers, and rooms were beautiful. I have so many scenic screenshots of the most mundane of places because they are so pretty to look at. My favorite area in the game is the beginning of the level where you follow the small Dark One through a train depot of some sorts. The atmosphere and rain reminded me of STALKER, although I also like the area on its own, not just because it reminded me of the STALKER games. I love the lighting in this game, it's probably the best I've ever seen in any game I've played. Environments in this game are awe inspiring.

Sound design and art design are all great, just wanted to bring up them up to say they are good. UI design, as well. I love the Metro games and their diagetic UI design.

What I really have to commend is the overall level design. I am glad that the Metro series is a linear story series kind of game, because I think the greatest strength of the series is its level design. The series is known for its cool weapons and gas mask aesthetics, along with the mutants and the underground metros, but those are all there to enhance the true draw of the Metro games. Exploring the levels and the creepy hand crafted areas of horror was awesome. I expected random mutant jumpscares here and there, of course, but the best horror parts was when it was more atmospheric and tense, letting your surroundings tell the story. Yeah, the ghost room during the railcar level took me by surprise. And those skeleton guys behind the grating, damn them. I think I remember seeing those guys show up on "top ten scary moments in video games" lists when I was younger.

Story was interesting. I got the good ending, though I was following a guide to avoid getting the bad ending. I don't really play the Metro games for the story, but I do enjoy it.

I beat this game in two days. I spend an entire day playing the game up until the last five levels, and that was because I stopped myself from playing further. I enjoyed this game a lot, and I think I prefer it over Metro 2033. Metro 2033 was great up until the final few levels in D6, and it unfortunately left a bad impression on me even though I did enjoy the first and middle segments of the game a lot. It's what I remember the most when I think back to 2033, and even if I try to remember the good parts I thoroughly enjoyed, it is still affected by those last levels. Still a good game, though.
For Metro Last Light, I pretty much enjoyed every second of it. I ran into a few mishaps, like the game needing to be validated because it kept crashing in the beginning, and at one point my computer crashed and it somehow unbinded all my keys, but those were fixed. I like this game a lot, evident by my playing through the whole thing in just two days.

Looking forward to Metro Exodus. Thank you for a great game!

Equally as good as 2033 in the sound, lighting and general mechanics. It's a little aged now but still holds up just as well in 2022. 

Story is better than 2033 in my opinion, especially the ending and general cut-scenes. Feel like there's much more intrigue and mystery in this story. However, there are still parts that are very confusing as to where to go and what to do, and some very tedious and annoying sections (EG fighting waves and waves of mutants that seem to be almost completely immune to shotgun shells to the face.) But it's worth pushing through to see the ending and complete the game. 

As always, recommended on sale but not at full price, grab the whole Saga deal on sale and you won't regret it! On to Exodus!

Was a pretty awesome game right up until it crashed. After which when I reloaded it proceeded to crash as soon as I tried to continue. Then again when I opened it again in the safe mode it offered me. Believe it or not is proceeded to get worse after that I can no longer even open the game as it gets stuck on the little opening bit it plays. Had to restart my computer twice because I couldn't get task manager to appear on top of it. It was at the end of the game to I think it was, right after you destroy the tank and the shield wall with the flame thrower guy it coming at you. 

Guess I'll have to look up what the conclusion was going to be, pretty disappointing.

Very nice atmosphere and gameplay, as good as Metro 2033. 
I encountered a few glitches where NPCs freeze... but will still give the alarm if not killed. Other than that, the game runs surprisingly well on a low-performance iMac
great game always will be fun

Too difficult in a lot of situations to be fun, even on normal mode. Had to rage quit after getting swarmed time and time again by monsters that require almost a full clip each to kill, running out of med kits, and absurd weapon reload times. Can't recommend this game.
It's an aight game for an FPS. Old school linear storydriven game. Very much enjoyable in between the games you are waiting for.

Boy Oh Boy what a fucking lovely story. The plot grows exponentially after the events of 2033 and we learn so much more about DARK ONES. A story filled with trust, love, betrayal... every emotion you name it.

Even level design was improved manifolds from 2033 which helped us in pushing stealth to whole new limits. This game had one of the best endings I have ever seen. Never knew something so little can become such a huge deal.

There were also lot of boobies and there were a few Monster Boss fight which gave me insane adrenaline rush.

The only bad thing I would say is : optimization. Even after being such an old title I saw performance drops sometimes, Game crashes 3 times and getting stuck between impossible spaces and glitching through surfaces.

THIS GAME IS EASILY RECOMMENDED - 9.5/10. Buy it even at full price or get it for dirt cheap price in metro safa bundle.

If it is some kind of monster or some unknown creature being that resilient, ok you can justify that, but a regular ass human eating 5 headshots, multiple grenades, there is no armor that can withstand that, not even 1 headshot, let alone 5. Last Light fucked me up. I was amazed by its graphics but so freaked out by the monsters rendered in those graphics that I couldn't play the game past a certain point. Then I got the game for free on the Epic Game store and was determined to play it to the end like every other free game I get on there. It was not easy and I had to use a controller and sit away from my pc to shield my eyes from the monsters that jump out at the character. I made it past the scariest point but I still couldn't look at the monsters. But then something happened. At some point in the game the player character meets an extremely hideous child mutant. The last surviving member of a race called Dark Ones  after they were blown up by missiles by the player character in the previous game. What follows is a journey of redemption and forgiveness as the player character bonds with the young mutant as they team up to fend off the dangers of this world in order to reach a common goal. Themes of motherhood and loss are all over the place. Themes of tolerance and acceptance. By the end of the game I was no longer sitting away from my monitor, repulsed by the hideous appearance of the young mutant and bug-like monsters. So powerful is the story of this game. Although you can't escape the fact that the game was  clearly made by straight men for straight men. The themes in it's story are truly universal and should be experienced by every gamer who is interested in action adventure single player fps games.

This is an awesome game.
Some weird hitboxes here and there, transparent stairs, bulletproof curtains, you know, the usual.
But still... AWESOME game.
I tend to take that stuff seriously and judge harshly for them, but here I just couldn't help myself but laugh it off.
Those flaws pale in comparison to the track record of this series (metro 2033 shares the vast majority of the good points)

The world feels so alive, with the setting respected and maintained expertly in all visual and gameplay aspects.
The direction you look matters, NPCs will react to you naturally, and their dialog hits that exact line of relevance to you as a player and believability.
No two gun shops have the same dialog, everyone has their style and circumstances.
Immersion is not something you have to worry about here, at all.
Ranger mode is incredibly interesting to struggle in, ammo management is a must, and hitting heads and timing shots are essential to survive, let alone having spare ammo at the end.
Stealth is simple but sharp, one mistake can quickly turn a flawless run around into a disaster.

One small problem I had with the first game (metro 2033) is the chain of companions you go through.
While making a semblance of sense in the story, felt really contrived and called upon all the luck in the knows universe.
This game sets you off alone, relying on the personal connections built in the first game, I LOVED that change, and it makes perfect sense in the story too.

The writing is incredible and holds up a solid image, unafraid to reach into the important questions, the questions this game is all about.

Your choices MATTER.
Your actions MATTER.
Even the ones not presented neatly with a 'good' and 'bad' option.


What makes you human?
Why is your life worth more than the people at the end of your muzzle?

note that both games suffer from rare game breaking bugs and save errors that force full reloads and/or other fun save trickery to resolve.
if you notice anything odd, look it up and hope you can still salvage the last 5 hours of gameplay...
no ammo? no problem! Just shove your hands up your ass and pull out your insides, this makes as a wonderful weapon to kill the little shits that keep trying to grope me to death.

This is my second playthrough of this game. First time I played it on my old PC when it came out.

I remember when I played this game, I didn't liked it as much as Metro 2033, and now I know why. The previous game had more of a mystery, had a lot more horror elements with a bit of action involved. This game is more action oriented, which for some this might be good, but for others like me I preferred the spooky atmosphere that the previous game had, the fear of the unknown if you will. 

Another issue I have with this game is that the story is fine, but it's not written as well as the first one. There are a lot more scripted events than in the previous games.

With that in mind, this is by no means a bad game. It still offers a good experience, maybe not as much as Metro 2033 but still good enough.

Pros:
+ The environment is still spot on
+ Most of the action scenes are fun, stealth mechanics have been improved a bit
+ The game is by few hours longer than the previous game
+ More weapons
+ More customization 
+ Music is good
+ The expanded lore is a definitive plus to the game


Cons:
- Some of the action parts near the end of the game feel forced
- The story is a bit weaker than the previous game
- Levels aren't as memorable as previous game
- Bad ending is shit, like really shit. You need a guide to get the good ending. While Metro 2033 also had a bad ending, it was more fitting than this one.
