I am a 50 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started metro and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and download this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, looked at the menu, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Not much different from the first game, but what has changed is mostly for the better. The stealth has improved a bit, the environment design has a bit more life to it, and it occasionally leans more into the underlying horror vibe the Metro book goes hard into. If you didn't like the first game this one probably won't sell you on it, but itтАЩs another 10 or so hours of that delicious Metro atmosphere that hooked me in 2033. I should also say that in my most recent playthrough I found a pretty unacceptable bug that knocks down my recommendation to "get it on sale". It's not gamebreaking, thank god, but still immersion breaking.

Anyway, the story this time around is that word of the existence of the secret military bunker Artyom and the gang found at the end of the last game has gotten around the metro. Two major factions have eyes on the prize, the Nazis, who are facists and the Reds who are, you guessed it, capitalists, and theyтАЩre all willing to spill blood over it. Meanwhile, Artyom has discovered that thereтАЩs one Dark One remaining after he drone strikeтАЩd them all to death at the end of the last game and that finding him might be his one chance for redemption. 

So the plot involving the human factions is much more involved this time around, which IтАЩm a fan of. Mostly. On the one hand, such a tight density of good and terrible Russian accents means that a Metro-wide conflict basically is inevitable, and the absence of something overarching in 2033 was a bit glaring. Yes, the Reds and Nazis were at each otherтАЩs throats, trying to find which characters were voiced Steve Blum pretending to be Russian and purging them for the sake of racial purity, but that was background stuff. Here it fleshes out the contrast between the elements of the Metro, against the Dark OneтАЩs plans and the various encroaching mutants on and under the surface, the background supernatural elements. Each faction has its own agenda. It also means that the explosive final confrontation is actually earnt, than a complete tonal lurch in a game thatтАЩs mostly stealth - the go-to for bad stealth games when they canтАЩt think of a more climactic ending (looking at you, Dishonored 2)

But there is a problem in thatтАж Well, you need exposition about the villainтАЩs plans in a plot like this but the Metro games are committed to not leaving ArtyomтАЩs perspective. Fair enough, but this means that heтАЩs captured by the Reds and the Reich something like 4 separate times over the entire game, for no other reason than so he can watch an important conversation between various political figures behind the cover of the vent heтАЩs crawling through. It kind of screws with the gameтАЩs pacing, especially in the first half. To me, these games are at their best keeping a healthy rotation of all facets of the setting - the fact that you can overhear a logical discussion on communism (just kidding, there are none) and then walk for five minutes and be mauled to death by giant spiders is what makes it interesting.

Last Light is still mostly picaresque, though, just down from 80% to 70%. The majority of the story is what happens on the way to the next plot cutscene. And I tell a lie, in addition to exposition, one of those imprisonments also results in you meeting Pavel, a recurring Red foot soldier about to be executed alongside you. He demonstrates the franchiseтАЩs knack for creating fleshed out characters in the tiny spans of time you accompany most of them. Yes, theyтАЩve all got that dour vibe of someone trapped in a giant cramped concrete tomb, but each meets it with different attitudes - resolve, humour, fear, cynicism, violence - and more often than not the banter between them is heartwarming in spite of the circumstances.

The segments where youтАЩre alone in survival horror mode are pretty great as well. Those giant spiders are what I meant when I mentioned how Last Light leans more into the horror angle - their design is pretty ingenious. First off, theyтАЩre giant spiders - unnerving screeches and scuttling sounds are pH neutral when theyтАЩre around. But also, their exoskeletons are communistproof, so you have to shine your torch on them to burn it away and flip them belly-up for a few shots. Sounds simple enough, but a), thereтАЩs usually more than one, so you have to occasionally switch between them to stop one from noshsing on your leg while giving his mate skin cancer, and b), they run away as you shine a light on them, which means that the most effective strategy is to fucking look away, LET them scuttle up towards you in the darkness of your peripheral vision and only THEN turn your light on them. And Marx and Engles help you if youтАЩre too late on the draw. As a recovering arachnophobe, I can confirm itтАЩs great. 

On the whole, the monster design is pretty creative; it reminds me pleasantly of Resident Evil 4. Although the game isnтАЩt amazing at directing you around on your way to them, particularly on the surface. The skyboxes have more colour and life and scale to them, which is nice, but trying to spot a series of brown wooden poles with washed-out red flags on them amidst the brownish-green reeds of a swamp?
 
And itтАЩs weird because the design of stealth rooms in the Metro have improved quite a bit. The floodlights that seared yoтАЩ subterranean corneas out till you couldnтАЩt keep track of enemies are gone, so theyтАЩre easier to keep track of, thereтАЩs more of them to bob and weave through so doing so is more satisfying. Their helmet lamps double as vision cones, thereтАЩs a delay between getting spotted and the alarm being raised and you can naturally exit a firefight situation by hiding behind cover, though guards wonтАЩt forget you exist.

In a word, IтАЩd describe it as тАЬcompetentтАЭ but there are a few issues. For one, the game is pretty stingy with autosaves, which can send you back pretty far. ThereтАЩs occasionally their habit of just having very clear and unengaging paths of darkness to crouch through that donтАЩt need any knockouts or distractions to get through. This isnтАЩt universal, and thereтАЩs plenty of meaty challenges getting to safes with resources and their keys in more exposed areas. Timing your waltz into a fully lit area for when no one is looking, for example. For this reason IтАЩd suggest upping the difficulty so that itтАЩs actually necessary. ThereтАЩs also very few unique mechanics to get through the environment, nothing like DishonoredтАЩs powers or ThiefтАЩs selection of arrows. You occasionally need to shoot out lights and raise a guardтАЩs awareness level to get through more safely, but it doesnтАЩt happen nearly often enough to be a core mechanic. 

And, unfortunately, the stealth is where we find that bug. About halfway through my most recent playthrough, the knockout/stab takedowns stopped working. No prompts, no reaction to spamming E or V.  And with scarce ammo the karma moral choice system that means you canтАЩt initiate combat, quite a few rooms ended in trial-and-error dashes to the nearest loading screen. Again, not gamebreaking, but pretty damn unacceptable for a game that rides on immersion.

So thatтАЩs Metro: Last Light: competent stealth, a decent story, the same great atmosphere and a less-than-healthy dose of jank. Get it on sale.

I love the Metro series but something is seriously broken with the stealth in this game.

I'm playing on Hardcore. The stealth is an infuriating slog, and checkpoints too far apart. When you hit a stealth-focused area of the game, expect to spend several hours trying to get through scenes that should only last minutes.

There doesn't seem to be any rhyme or reason to when the enemy will notice you. Sometimes you can snipe an enemy with a silenced weapon like the Tihar and no one will notice. Other times, you'll snipe the same enemy in the same spot with the same weapon and someone around a corner in a different room will "see" it, or everyone in the level will hear it, blowing your stealth for the rest of the level. Sometimes enemies won't see you while looking directly at you from 5 feet away; other times, they'll notice you so easily that you'd think you were wearing a neon sign.

In a well-designed stealth game, you should be able to make educated guesses about what you can get away with, e.g. when you can kill an enemy without being noticed. In Last Light: Redux, you can only get through most stealth sections with exhausting trial-and-error to determine what you can do that will or will not be noticed.

I'm currently stuck on a game-breaking bug in the "Contagion" level. There's a particular checkpoint where, when you first reach it, you're hidden in a crawlspace under the floor; the enemies are not aware of you and you can try stealthing around as normal. However, if you ever reload the checkpoint, the enemies are on maximum alert. If you take so much as a single step forward, every enemy in a 30 foot radius will snap to attention and start talking about the noise you're making. If you step out from under the floor, in the [i]only[/i] path you can take, they'll immediately spot you. The only "solution" I've found is to replay the level from the beginning (which could mean wasting anywhere from 30 minutes to several hours depending on how seriously you try to stealth), but if you fail and have to reload the checkpoint, the bug comes back.

I don't recall having these issues when I played the original version of the game, though admittedly it's been quite a while. Certainly don't expect any support from Deep Silver, as they only support a game for a few months after release and then stop caring altogether.

TL;DR review updateNow that I've finished the game I can comment on the game as a whole. The story is good but it has a sudden end and feels very rushed. The gunplay is good but the stealth mechanics are buggy and badly developed. The atmosphere is fantastic. My biggest issue with this game is that it's a buggy mess(I encountered a bug with every boss so I had to restart and do every boss twice), it feels rushed in many parts, and it starts to fall off near to the end.

Seriously, wtf was that ending?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
While this game is a huge improvement to the original Metro 2033, it has some terrible fun-ruining bugs and issues I encountered. The game gives you a shit ton of ammo though, so at least you can't soft lock in this game due to that.

The gameplay is a huge improvement, with a larger variety of guns and attachments! I also like that they made a stealth system that, y'know, actually fucking works. The gunplay works the same as Metro 2033 but it does feel more fluid and fit for action sequences. Enemies can now have armour on them making them harder to kill, although on normal difficulty you can take a shit ton of shots before dying, but that's better for the average player I feel like. If you died in one shot regardless, players would just be funnelled into a stealth run. Gunplay isn't particularly the best and with the addition of armoured enemies, it feels like this game heavily favours stealth than run-and-gunning.

Stealth is where this game falls flat. The stealth system works but it works with very specific rules. Step out of darkness for a second? Oops, all enemies in the room are alerted! Move one step(not an exaggeration) while not crouched? Oops, all enemies in the room are now alerted! Use a gun with a silencer? Oops, all enemies in the room are alerted! The last one is probably the most damning. Silencers DO NOT work. Even when shooting an enemy that was far away from their allies, enemies would go on alert. This happens with all specific stealth "rules" this game has. To top it all off, when an enemy sees you, you have 1 exact second to react, but I expect the reality is enemies because alerted instantly if you kill the spotter before they yell out. To top off the topping off, enemies also seem to instantly see you from anywhere when on alert and that's just too crazy. Silencers not working? Taking a single step forwards and enemies suddenly shooting at you through a wall? No, those are nothing. Enemies that just instantly lock on you even when you're hidden way across the entirety of the room is just blasphemy. It also seems like moving between individual areas of a level doesn't clear alert status, as I had moved into another area and enemies immediately started shooting at me. Frustrating, to say the least.

My major problem with this is that going from stealth to sudden action just sucks. If you're trying to stealth, and you know you're doing things right, you don't want to suddenly have the game tear that atmosphere away from you. This game is MUCH more fun than Metro 2033 in stealth and it feels a lot better to stealth in this game, but it's not fun when visible flaws in the game make it harder than it should be.

I think some of my issues with the stealth system is due to the fact that this game has quite a few bugs. Most of them are minor annoyances but some of them are just awful. I had a checkpoint save occur at the exact moment someone happened to go on alert, and this caused all enemies to go on alert and charge to my location upon loading that checkpoint. Not only that, but I had to keep on loading(for obvious reasons) and this caused the game to bug out and crash, although thankfully save corruption seems to be rare. Crashing does seem to be a common issue however. 

The checkpoint system is pretty bad but mostly because in certain areas, a single room can have several checkpoint triggers. This can lead to the stealth issue I mentioned above. The checkpoints are also just few and far between sometimes.

The music is pretty good and the overall atmosphere is much better than Metro 2033. There's much more colour in Last Light, and 2033 was just so bleak and gray without purpose.

I got this game on sale(for really cheap, the number I see at the time of writing is $5.49), so I don't see why I shouldn't finish this game for such a great price and it's a fun game to play. I just had to write my review on this after suffering some egregious issues with the gunplay and the stealth gameplay. Everything else is fine.

EDIT: Added in a paragraph about the checkpoints.

EDIT 2 : Upon further playing, I'm experiencing more and more issues. There's a bug with the swamp boss that is "fixed" by restarting the chapter, and this is more of an annoyance but assault rifles in this game quickly become useless, especially against mutants(although the game claims otherwise). The mutants are bullet sponges in this game, even on normal difficulty.

EDIT3 : And yet ANOTHER bug with the next boss, Big Momma, that causes you to fly all over the room after you kill it.

The Gameplay:
The shooting is solid, headshots matter with all enemies and those knife kills.. oh god. Feels good to play especially since you feel like you are managing a tactical suit without absurd menus.

The Story:
I love the depressing/scary take on post apocalypse compared to the goofy antics of Fallout. There are funny moments but it doesn't feel out of place.

The Visuals:
A big revamp from the original 2033 which looked literally dry by comparison. If it isn't explicitly stated this is on a remake level of upgrade.

The Sound:
The guns sound good, the voice acting is on point, the music is perfectly somber and it helps set it's mood very well.


The Experience:
Both the 2033 Redux and the Last Light Redux seem to have been painted with the same brush. Much of what I like the first is done well on this one. Managing your inventory is surprisingly simple yet in depth. Pavel is the man in this game and it certainly does a better job at fleshing out it's story than 2033.

[h1]Makes fallout look like Disneyland[/h1]  

[u]What I liked about the game[/u]
[list] 

[*]	Like the last game, I really enjoyed exploring the metro tunnels and the derelict buildings of Moscow. The levels in Last Light are well designed and also have a lot of detail. There are more secrets and explorable areas compared to 2033. I also really enjoyed exploring the populated stations like, Venice and the Theater.  

[*]	Likable characters like Pavel, Khan, and the dark one. 

[*]	Last Light has some awesome new weapons like the Preved and the RPK. The weapons look and sound fantastic. The weapons also have a good kick to them.   

[*]	The story is top-notch. The game had a lot of memorable moments, especially the ending. 

[*]	The game also has some bonus missions which you can complete at anytime. In the bonus missions you get play as different characters, like Pavel, Anna and Khan.  

[*]	The game still has those cool mechanics, like being able to burn cobwebs with a lighter, having to use a gasmask on the surface, and having to recharge your flashlight or pneumatic weapon. 

[*]	I really enjoyed MetroтАЩs atmosphere, it is quite a dark and gritty game. I like it when you encounter anomalies and apparitions throughout the levels. 

[*]	I like that you can collect pieces of ArtyonтАЩs journal. The Journal tells you what artyon is thinking and gives you a bit more information on the story.

[*]	The game offers a good challenge. Sometimes the game puts you in a situation that might seem unfair, for example Red Square, but it is satisfying being able to complete a level without getting caught or dying.   

[*]	The game has some new enemies and boss fights.  

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u] 

[*]	I hate the ladders in this game, because sometimes you are unable to climb them or you start climbing them dead slow. 

[*]	It would have been nice to know where I was on the Karma meter when playing the game.  

[*]	Some of the levels I felt were a bit short. 

[*]	ItтАЩs a shame you canтАЩt use junk or an item to distract an enemy, but this was something they added in Metro Exodus. 

[*]	I did encounter some bugs and glitches throughout the game.  

[*]	The soundtrack wasnтАЩt as good as the first game. They reused a few of the tracks from 2033. 
[/list]
[u]Conclusion[/u] 

A very good sequel to 2033. Like the first game it took me a while to get into, because I wanted to play the game right and playing the game on Spartan mode just felt wrong. You get to explore more of the metro and the ruins of Moscow. The game has a lot of memorable moments like[spoiler] riding the railcar and the massive shootout at the end[/spoiler]. The game does put in some unfair situations which may seem impossible, but the game is very rewarding when you do it right. If you enjoy post-apocalypse games , then I highly recommend the game.

Artyom is back at it again, blasting his way through irradiated metro tunnels infested with mutants, Nazis and the Red Line (Communists) while counting every bullet. (Minor spoilers may follow). Compared to the original Metro 2033, I actually preferred this game, as I found the story to be much better than the original game. As a Spartan, Artyom is tasked with eliminating the sole survivor of his missile strike on the Dark Ones, a cute little mutant who can read minds and has some neat abilities. Of course, nothing is as simple as it seems, and before long Artyom finds himself at the center of a bio-terrorist attack in the metro and a conspiracy to seize control of the Moscow underground. At the center of it all lies the most annoying and stupidly smug character, Pavel, ever to exist in either the Metro or Stalker franchises. Being forced to deal with this guy throughout the game did not win any brownie points from me, but the gameplay did. As before in Metro 2033, stealth or guns blazing is an option, and both are completely achievable, allowing the player to pick their preferred style of play/ A few new weapons made an appearance in Last Light like a semi-automatic pistol, bolt-action rifle and anti-material rifle, but frankly I found myself preferring to stick with tried and trusted weapons of 2033. Furthermore, the Redux version introduced some curious variants of existing weapons, such as the shotgun I have thus dubbed the "Quadruplet" (A Duplet with four barrels, making it the most powerful shotgun in the game). Now, fighting humans aside, Last Light presents its fair share (sadly) of mutant combat, and the new enemies (the shrimp) left me wishing I had stayed back underground. In summary, if you liked Metro 2033 you will like Last Light- more of the same gameplay, with arguably a better story. Overall Score: 9.2/10

I have not yet played Metro 2033 and having owned all 3 of the Metro games I installed this Metro Last Light Redux before realizing that it was the 2nd game in the series,
After the download to my PC which took at least 20mins I decided to play this game 1st,
Wow what a game and it kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire game which took me just about 30hrs to complete.
If your into heavy FPS action which requires quick thinking,fast actions and a mixture of stealth then you may really be interested in playing this awsome game.
The graphics are spectacular considering that its aging rapidly and the game presents many many jump scares during the actual gameplay which will keep you on your toes,
To me I feel as if the game pushes the limit a bit too much with overkill as far as some missions go to the point you will be saying when is too much enough already as there are a few cases in the game when it seems as if it will never end as your battling either human foes or creature foes and it does become a bit overkill at times.
You will get stuck in a few missions and will need to check the WIKI page or Google for info on how to get onwards to the next chapter or mission but as with most great games there isnt much hand holding and if you cant figure something out theres always info online to help you out of a jam.
If your looking for a great story these Metro games are pretty awsome and im about to install Metro 2033 which is the 1st game in the series so I can be caught up with story and then I will play Exodus last.
Last Light offers players alot of gaming after the main story is completed and the replay value of the story is pretty high as are the extra chapters players can play after the main story is completed which makes this an even more epic game.
I hope many people will give this a try because they will surely be glad once they do....

[b]Metro is a journey, first and foremost.[/b]

It features shooting, exploration, and scavenging, but ultimately it is a linear story where you are introduced to a terrifying yet mysterious post-apocalyptic Moscow, filled with mutants and monsters, but also enigmatic beings like anomalies or "the shadows". Also, it has a great variety of difficulty settings, so you can suit the game to you preferred way of enjoying shooters, be it sneaky survivor or Rambo, which is great in my opinion.

Metro is one of the few "campaign only" games that I've replayed about 2-3 times each already (both 2033 and Last Light). There's just... something to it, that every now and then I want to go play it all over again. To relive that dark and unnerving Metro experience, without any "crafting, survival, or day-night cycle" bullshit, just you, your weapon, few bullets, and whatever lurks in those dark tunnels as you advance forward.

Godspeed, Artyom. We all are going to need it down there.

[spoiler]On the bad side, the karma god/bad endings are a little bullshit, so don't stress too much about getting either.[/spolier]

I really liked Metro 2033, and this sequel blows it out of the water in pretty much every way. The story is way better, the gameplay is a lot more refined and fun, the environments are freaking gorgeous, and I love the themes it presents of Spring, renewal, and repentance. ItтАЩs dark, for sure, but thatтАЩs part of the appeal when it comes to the post-apocalypse, and I like that the way to get the good ending feels a lot less obscure than in 2033. ItтАЩs barely related to Metro 2034, the book (I believe being intended to take place after that largely unrelated narrative), but it has GlukhovskyтАЩs fingerprints all over it, and it wasnтАЩt a surprise at all to learn that he did a lot of the writing. Overall, a game IтАЩd definitely recommend - the only real drawback is that itтАЩs pretty short, but the bonus missions make up for it somewhat.

Same core as 2033 but with drastic improvements in level design with a lot more focus on stealth and open levels with multiple paths. I had high hopes going in. Sure, there were some genuinely fun parts with solid action, atmospheric exploration, and horror. However, for all the talk I have heard of Last Light since its release, this game was highly overrated imo. 
Not much has changed since the original except that theres more variety in the weapons and a few new mutated creatures. Although I do believe they wasted the mechanic of the rail car.
The music and sound design in this game is phenominal. The guns, again feel real, and powerful.
Play it if you really loved the first Metro, or if you really want to know the story in the series, I guess.

Last Light feels a bit more like an expansion to Metro 2033 than a brand new game, graphically it looks pretty much the same to me. It is on the same engine, so much of the guns and hud/menus look the same as well. It doesn't do much new besides continue the story, which is the main reason to play this one in my opinion. 

There are a few standout moments like this part where you're driving a railcar through the tunnels and can get out to explore side areas if you choose. I feel like there are more moments in this game where you're fully alone and that's where Metro shines in my opinion, so generally I think I enjoyed this one more than 2033 but they are VERY similar games so in the future I'm sure trying to remember which was which will be hard. 

It's more Metro, and if you like 2033 you'll enjoy this one too. I will say going for the good ending kinda sucks though, there's a morality system and if you do bad things like kill surrendering people or don't help certain people with side quests, you'll be perceived as a bad person and get the bad ending. It's just pointless and doesn't really add anything to the game, it would have been better off with just one ending especially considering Metro Exodus (the sequel to this game) says that the good ending is the cannon one anyway.

So despite the game having about 1 whole minute of unskippable cut scene at the start of the game, and despite the game being absolutely riddled in unskippable cutscenes throughout with the time distribution about 80:20 unskippable cutscene:gameplay, i find myself running around in a gasmask.

I can't take the gas mask off because i die. 
I can't work out where to go because:
1) I can't see clearly through the gas mask
2) there's no map that i can see
3) it's just damn unclear where i'm supposed to go

It's a bit frustrating tbh that there's so much unskippable cutscenes and yet when you actually need some help you've got none whatsoever. Just some hint. Something. But I used up about 5 gas mask canisters running around looking for where i'm supposed to go. 

Naturally when i die i've got to fight all the enemies again. 

If i rage quit the game i've got to wait for over a minute for the German games manufacturer to stop advertising how awesome it is to me. 

German computer games suck. I recognise a lot of these problems with Crysis too.

Just to add to this, it's a really painful game, the game is sluggish, not lag, but it's slow to respond and everything feels heavyweight like the aim, the firing, actions take a long time to perform. It's 60fps. But it's like by the time you fire the enemy has moved, and ofc because you've missed you run out of ammo. There are many situations where running out of ammo is just game over. And what can you actually do? It'll just respawn you in the same place with little ammo. 

It's a bit hard to know what to do now, because i can't see how i can continue playing, and it's not obvious if it's possible to get more ammo. 

Also some things in the game seem broken. For example i was in a mine car, and i got stuck in it and couldn't get out of it. It wouldn't let me. Also on the mine car level, the mine car got jammed in reverse and went down the track but the mine car was physically still where i parked it. Even though the 3d visuals had moved, the physics had not. Another weird thing on the minecar level was that i found myself climbing up nothing. There was literally nothing there but it was behaving as a ladder and i could climb above the level for some inexplicable reason. 

That was a pretty buggy level lol.

Must be a few hours into it now, and the unskippable video sequences are still there. They wont fuck off and die.

i just don't understand these type of games that put story before gameplay, i don't mind a good story and decent graphics but a game meant to be played more than hearing shit.

Metro Last Light is far better than Metro 2033 was. The developers took fans opinions seriously and changed the aspects that were especially annoying the players. But not all, sadly. I

The graphics were upgraded, that's for sure, characters look more realistic and overaly better, considering it's game from 2014. Same goes for monsters and Little Dark One - I'm especially happy about the last one, he looks incredibly good. But still there was a problem with physics, and some of the characters broke their neck by trying to look at Artyom. Hilarious, not gonna lie, but I'd rather not see something like that. 

Story is amazing. I really enjoyed it and had so much fun. There are parts where it slows down, letting the player just wander on the surface, and the areas, where you're fighting for you life, cursing out lack of ammo and filters. Not gonna lie, at some point the game got really hard, had to pay attention to my surroundings, enemies, ammo, adn to be sure to be undercovered. This was some great challange I was hoping for! Not waves of enemies that are flooding you, but rather good amount to make you think before you act. Plus the main story is really long, comparing to 2033, which is great.
Going back to story - the characters also make it amazing. We have Pavel, a fucking communist with cute smile - this sums him up. He's incredibly well written, I had love-hate relationship with him the whole time I was playing Last Light. Dude is so smart, yet trusts so blindly the Red Line, never questioning their motives. Probably one of the best characters in whole Metro games - you can't say he's good, or he's bad, he balances between those two, making him an absolutely interesting character, that you just can't forget about. Anna was a surprise to me - I played Exodus first, so I remember her as sweet and caring, here keeping her distance, which I didn't expect. But I did like her a lot! "Krolik" caught me off my guard. I sure did blush at this one, haha! Another big plus is DLC missions, that gave us insight of not main characters, like Khan, which I liked, since he's one of my favs, and there was little known about him in game. Also got a chance to see Ulman again! Which I'm super happy about. And, of course, our Little Dark One - I can't say too much, but everybody, you are going to absolutely love this child. How I wish we saw more of him there.

Combat hadn't changed too much, but the main difference is that it's less junky. Also the waves of enemies you were drowning in, which I mentioned before, has been reduced to amount enough to make you think before acting. This is way better, than it was in 2033, since I actually have time to reload my weapons and don't have 5 wachmen on me. HUD is still sometimes not showing up, which is a pain in the ass while doing stealth, but it happened only twice to me. Still very little places, where we can buy filters, but they're more common in metro now, so it's not as painful, as it was in 2033.

Moral Point. The most annoying thing in the whole game - you can NEVER get the good ending the first try, it's just impossible. They're so randomly given, some I got I didn't even find in the guide I was following. Or given by listening to the conversation that brings nothing into your game and is just annoying, since sometimes you're put in danger because of that. Some I had to miss on, because I would surely get spotted. Or looking for beggars to give them the bullet. Some of them are so well hidden it took me a while to get to them. 

DLC - are okay. I have three favs there. I liked the one with Librarians the most, even if it gave me heart-attack a few times. Gave a great insight of what Rangers' job looks like. And, obviously, I enjoyed Khan's DLC, tho lack of bullets pissed me off. Pasha's DLC was hard since we lack weapons at the beginning, so again, lots of thinking about your next move. The rest of DLC was nothing I was crazy about. The Sniper Team has a bug, where I can't shoot on my left. Which is annoying. 

Bugs I've encountered: HUD not showing up, Librarians attacking when I was staring at them, disappearing Notes and boxes, Sniper Team DLC. 

I absolutely recommend this game. It's well made considering how long ago it was created, great story and characters, good DLCs missions. It's my second fav, next to Exodus. I'm replaying it for third time now, so guys, it's hella good, I rarely do that, haha! Also, worth the full price, 'cause we're getting lots of gameplay there.
A true Metro game!  Great story line and plenty of action!
Like the last Metro game, its survival horror alongside tense combat is fun and engaging. Its story is great and expansive.
Must play! GG !
Huge improvement on the first game gameplay wise and I appreciated the level design and all the optional gameplay paths.

This game seems to be well-liked by everyone, but for me it was a horrible experience. My game turned out to be very buggy.  The autosave was bugged, I could clear an entire section of the map and die at the next area, only to be reloaded to the start of the previous area. Then, once I have cleared it for the second time then did it autosave. Another bug was enemies being able to spot me when I was literally behind them. Happened so many times on chapter 12 that made stealth impossible. I have seen walkthroughs of the game and literally me copying the exact same movements will get me spotted. Sad that this game had to have so many bugs as I loved Metro 2033 redux.

[h1] Metro Last Light Review[/h1]

TL:DR
Buy this game if you like/love
-FPS with other elements.
-A mainly good story line that carries from the 1st part.
-shooting enemies in the head.

Don't buy this game if you dislike/hate
-FPS with mixed game elements (stealth, horror etc)
-linear gameplay structure.
-lack of replay value.



[b] Story Summery [/b]

Set 1 year after the events of Metro 2033, Last light continues Artyom's story and what his feeling after the events of the first game, among his own struggles he has to face enemies such as the Neo-Nazis and Neo-Communists. Last light takes Artyom's journey to previously met locations as long with new ones.

[b] Gameplay Overview [/b]

Like metro 2033, Last Light is an FPS game set in Post-apocalyptic Russia, with stealth and survival elements.

Players have a vast array of weapons to choose from, shotguns, assault rifles, and a few others, Players can also approach levels either by stealth or guns blazing.

Last light also carries over the linear level driven gameplay along with mild exploration that can reward players with equipment or ammo.

Like Metro 2033 the moral point system returns and functions the same way (good deeds = good points, bad deeds = bad points)

[b] DLC overview [/b]

With the Redux remaster all DLC are included upon purchase 

[b] Faction Pack [/b]

This DLC adds 3 new and original single-player missions, the missions and gameplay are focused around game features, such as shooting, stealth, sniping, and stalking.

[b] Tower Pack [/b] 

The dreaded Tower pack adds a single long and probably the hardest level in the game,

Mainly a wave based mode/level players take on different waves of enemies or mutants while surviving the onslaught.

[b] Developer Pack [/b]

Developer pack mainly adds missons that let you mess around with the game's AI such as battling mutants against each other, or by going to the Shooting range for some gun fun.

Also included is a museum level that showcases stuff you encounter in the game as statues, also part of this pack is 1 new single player level that has a heavy focus on 1 type of enemy.

[b] Chronicles Pack [/b] 

And lastly but not least my personal all time favourite the Chronicles Pack.

This pack includes 3 new levels that are each focused to characters encountered in the main story, it also expands on the lore and universe that tie in to the main game.

[b] Abzats and RPG machien gun [/b]

Nothing much to add here this 2 DLC are just 2 weapons added to the story.


[b] My personal experience [/b]

The story picks off almost immediately after the first game as I re-played this after completing the first its a nice way to jump right in. I've enjoyed the story as much as I did the first, but somethings that I notice is the horror element is slightly lacking compared to 2033 in 2033 there are maybe 1 or 2 areas that can make you jump, in last light I barely encountered any scenario that made me jump, there were some surprises like enemies attacking around the corner but that's nothing compared to what you'll encounter in 2033.

As for the gameplay because both Last light and 2033 are redux the gameplay is the same with the FPS and stealth nothing really worth pointing out if you played 2033 redux you won't feel any different here.

DLC wise I've really enjoyed Chronicles Pack each level is unique and tells a different point of view, as for the other packs and DLCS the other one I enjoyed was the Factions pack, the developer pack didn't add much and I got board of it quickly as it doesn't have a story at all. 

As for the Tower pack its probably my most dreaded DLC in any game for a while.. even playing on the easiest mode its just utter chaos, it feels unbalanced and slightly unpolished from the amount of damage you can receive, the AI seems to be on steroids also attacking more aggressively then their campaign counterparts.

I had to use well known glitch just to skip the tower level for the achievement.

as for replaying since its a linear game once you complete the story and get all the collectables there's not much replay value.

Thus my rating for last light will be the same as it was for Metro 2033, mainly because it doesn't offer much in terms of story.
Rating: 7.5/10

I'm on the fence with recommending this game. I had high hopes going in, but had mixed feelings about it all. Sure, there were some genuinely fun parts with solid action, atmospheric exploration, and horror. However, for all the talk I have heard of Last Light since its release, this game was highly overrated imo. The story gets corny really fast and consists of over-dramatized and mediocre twists and reveals, not to mention the over-use of cut-scenes. Play it if you really loved the first Metro, or if you really want to know the story in the series, I guess. But If you don't care either way, then take a pass.

I'd say I'm 50/50 on this, but I think have to leave a dislike review. This game came out almost 10 years ago but my PC (with RTX 2060 super) kept crashing every now and then, especially when loading the next map. Some of the missions are frustrating and the resources are so scarce that it forces you to go back and re-progress the previous chapter to get more ammo & air prepared for the part where you were stuck. It's impossible what you are going to encounter in the next part. For example I was in the middle of being a stealthy guy chasing down Pavel with a pistol and a shotgun but I didn't expect the chapter right after this one was to go through tens of monsters as swiftly as possible. I didn't have enough air and the only firearm I found in the wasteland was a sniper with <10 ammos. Maybe I'm a shitty console player but I failed the mission too many times.

I love the play style and aesthetics and would continue to play but my patience is slowly getting thinner with these glitches and replaying for preparedness...

It seems as if the developers heard my issues with the original Metro 2033 and fixed them in Last Light: 
- Mutant fights are few and mutants themselves are not spammed in overwhelming numbers, just 2-3 at a time at most.
- The "tour guide" missions a'la CoD are few and far between.
- The stealth missions are vastly improved and some even allow full ghosting (i.e. sneaking by without killing/knocking out anyone).
- The railway levels actually allow you to stop at any time and explore the side rooms and hallways.
- The creepiness is still there, and a great Dead City level with some brilliant horror atmosphere.
Compared to LL, the original Metro seems more like an introduction to the setting, while LL is the first proper game.

However, some problems still persist:
- No manual saves. This was an issue in 2033, but more so in LL. With proper stealth missions, having to restart an entire section because of a single mistake, is a complete chore. This concerns all stealth games with checkpoints by the way.
- Still no FoV slider.
- It crashed on me a few times.
- The endings being based on moral points again, which are often so dumb and arbitrary, that there is no way you're gonna get the good ending on your first playthrough.

Storywise I have to go on a bit of a tangent. The story is above average, but still not good enough to focus on it so much. 2033 and Last Light are pushing their plots really hard onto the player, which would be fine, if they were good and/or interesting. For me, they were not, and the ample cutscenes, dialogues, scripted events, all take the attention away from the world itself, which is fascinating.

I played 2033 Redux and LL Redux only on Survival Normal, but out of curiosity I read on other difficulties. The lack of decent information on those is surprising. In-game you only receive very short summaries as to what they do. The official wiki has details regarding the non-Redux versions. It took me an hour to find proper info, more or less.
Anyway, Ranger mode uses one of the worst methods of increasing difficulty: depraving the player of basic information. On Ranger Hardcore you literally have no HUD or prompts. To select a throwable you have to recall the HUD positions from memory or rely on sound cues the items make when selected, since the weapon wheel is invisible. ItтАЩs absurd.

Some DLCs reuse maps from 2033 Redux, some add new but short maps, and some expand on the lore a little. In general, they're ok. A one-time-and-done type of deal.
Overall it's a considerable improvement over 2033.
The moles' are broken af. They tanks shot like fking juggernaut yet run and hit like they are on fking steroid, and they come in fking herde. Other than that, great game

It's just like metro 2033 in terms of graphics and atmosphere but the environments are either on par or much better. The story is much more personal, because the player is being followed by a little guy and it mainly revolves around him. Following the evolution of their relationship is quite interesting especially, if you partake in the evil/good moral decisions that have a very impactful influence on the ending. In 2033 it wasn't as impactful but here it really makes a difference and rewards you for your decisions. Gameplay wasn't altered much, if at all but some weapons got added which spices up the combat a little bit - the classics of course stay. Just like metro 2033 this game is a must have for post-apo fans and would propably be a better choice for those who seek a more varied experience and other environments than just metro and buildings around metro stations.

Really improves the gameplay from the first game, and somehow the flow of this one feels more dynamic than the first game, but somehow being scarier than the first one too!

Length of the game is around 1-2 hours longer than the first one, so it's definitely like "a movie sequel" to the first "movie" kind of pacing, but definitely worth playing the first one before playing this!
Overall, really great story, immersion, and atmosphere, makes the whole game even more fun and immersive.

Finished the XBox One version of this beauty just recently and I had an absolute blast. Now it's time to give it a second try on PC!
To keep it short: Compared to the first game, which I didn't really enjoy and which made me kinda rush to the credits, this one is so much different. Actually I planned to rush through this to finally being able to start Metro Exodus. But my plan went a different route.

The story kept me pretty much engaged from the very first chapter - okay let's say from the 2nd sequence, since the intro sequence felt as weird as the ending of the first game. But then, OMG, the game delivered what I call a JOY TO PLAY! It also has a plot twist which was pretty surprising. Absolutely great work!
This is achieved simply by the fact that Metro Last Light  pretty much excels at writing, world building, atmosphere, survival elements (gas mask, LIGHT, believe me, LIGHT will be your new best friend!) and stealth gameplay. Especially the survival elements felt almost NOT present in the first game. Here you pretty much feel them in almost every resp. level.
When it comes to stealth, I almost felt like Sam Fisher, stuck in Moscow - minus the high tech gadgets that kinda mark everything for you by using the Ubisoft forumala.

Anyway, the world is beleivablely pictured. The factions finally get the required screen time they deserve, but lacked in the first game, plus more. This is great to FINALLY show you, as the player why people fear specific factions. The first game pretty much lacked in this regard imo. Here they aren't empty jars anymore.
Also the people you meet in the tunnels and different hubs. It was so immersive and I did not want to miss any scripted sequence to listen to their talks and let me dive far more deeper into this world, while they shared their experience in this world!

But while talking about audio, resp. localization to be more precisely: The accents in this game are super annoying. And if I would rate this game,  I gave this title 8/10 points, just because of this flaw. The game makes the same mistake many other titles out there do as well:
YOU, a natively born RUSSIAN kid, never leaving the tunnels and area of MOSCOW, meaning, NEVER getting in touch with OTHER LANGUAGES, why do you have to have a Russian accent when playing the German OR English version? This ofc applies to the majority of the people in this game as well!
This makes the game feel so stupid in so many regards. I mean, I do not know any scientific result that proves our brains underly a respective accent when you're  talking with someone from another country. 
Game studios really need to stop this, when NOT implementing DIFFERENT spoken languages in a game!!! If there is only ONE language spoken, there is no need for accents  ladies and gents! 
This would only make sense if a slang supports the origin of a character, which Red Dead 2 pretty much excels at. But here? Maybe the Russian version achieves this by showing different accents of people. But the other languages simply cannot deliver the difference between Russian slang 1, 2 and 3. So please stop doing this and destroyingthe atmosphere. Hire some professional speakers instead!

Anyway, to sum this up: To me, this game just felt like a first person version of The Last of Us 2. I compare both, because I simply could not let the gamepad go when playing both games. Metro Last Light is terrifying, brutal, just written by grown people for grown people! Especially when considering some of the aspects of the game, this game deserves its PEGI 18 rating, it is absolutely not for the younger people out there below PEGI 16. Only the flaw with the voice acting kinda destroys a perfect rating for this masterpiece!

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h2]Metro: Last Light Redux Review[/h2]

[b][h1]Gameplay[/h1][/b]
[i]First of all, the gameplay is the same as that of Metro 2033 Redux and the game can only be played from the viewpoint of the first person. In both games, except for the plot, there's no difference. Last Light continues the story of Metro 2033 where you have launched missiles against the dark ones (the bad ending). There are several new weapons in the game that are actually decent. You can customize your weapons at any weapon seller in the game (found at safe points). You can hold up to three guns at a time with other supplies. You can also select your approach to your enemies in the game, just like the previous game. And, of course, in the game, you will encounter numerous new creatures. The choices you make influence the ending of the game completely. Your watch shows whether or not you are exposed to your enemies. When you crawl up the surface, it is important to wear a gas mask due to radiation. Unless they see a dead body, using suppressed weapons to kill your enemies will not alarm other enemies. You also get other things like a journal, lighter, flashlight, universal charger which can be used to charge the flashlight. The game also uses ammo (military grade rounds) as a currency for buying weapons and other ammo during the game. [/i]

[b][h1]Modes in which the game can be played[/h1][/b]
[b]Survival:[/b] In this mode there are less supplies, lower reloading speed and enemies are hard to kill.

[b]Spartan: [/b]This mode is more action-oriented and gives you more resources.

[i]The modes are same as Metro 2033 Redux. [/i]

[b][h1]Graphics[/h1][/b]
[i]The graphics of the game are pretty good. The game can be easily played on a low rig. Playing on high settings is recommended, on low settings the game doesn't look that good. And do raise the brightness of the game a little bit to be able to see things, otherwise you will need to use your flashlight all the time. You will hardly find any difference in the graphics of Metro 2033 Redux and this game. [/i]

[b][h1]Pros And Cons[/h1][/b]
[b]Pros: [/b] [list]
[*]Decent Graphics.
[*]Optimized for low rigs.
[*]New weapons and creatures.
[*]Very good story.[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b] [list]
[*]No multiplayer / Local.
[*]AI needs improvement.[/list]

[b][h1]Extra Info[/h1][/b]
[i]If you want to get the good ending, help other people and avoid killing people who surrender. There are always ammo and filters hidden, carefully check your surroundings. Avoid killing creatures who are not facing you, so you can easily save some ammo. [/i]

[b][h1]Overall Rating[/h1][/b]
[i]Like Metro 2033 Redux, the game offers a lot of action and has a great story. Do not waste any time if you have played the previous part, just get it already. [/i]

It's an interesting and challenging survival game. It is definitely a game that many people would want to replay just to find the rest of the collectibles across the different chapters and get the rest of the achievements.

One HUGE warning though: once you get to the Big Momma boss, MAKE SURE YOU HAVE AT LEAST ONE SHOTGUN OR REVOLVER WITH A GOOD AMOUNT OF AMMO to use on her. I spent close to 2 hours using hundreds of rounds of ammo from assault rifles and a sniper, and performed around 100 melee hits on various parts of the boss's body (head, neck, back, stomach, and face) and after trying this strategy (and dying dozens of times), I STILL COULDN'T TAKE THE BOSS OUT. I didn't have a revolver and had very few bullets in my shotgun (which is the boss's biggest weakness), so it offered little help in the battle. I ended up deciding to repeat a previous chapter and re-customize my weapon loadout before the boss fight, and made sure that I had a large amount of shotgun ammo, and ONLY THEN was I able to take out the Big Momma by only using a revolver. If you run out of ammo and the boss is still alive, just quit back to the main menu. There is zero reason to waste your time punching the boss and throwing equipment over and over again and hoping that she'll eventually die; I made this mistake and ended up wasting a bunch of time because of it.

As good as the game is, I have to warn you that it is pretty buggy from time to time, and these bugs can occasionally seriously mess up the gaming experience. These bugs range from falling under the map, me being taken into the wrong chapter multiple times over when I want to play a certain game chapter, getting stuck inside of a boss and dying because I can't turn or move while stuck in this situation, among other more minor bugs.

All in all, it's a fun game, aside from a some annoying gameplay elements and bugs here and there.

[h1]THIS IS A "MUST HAVE" SERIES FOR ANY FAN OF THE POST-APOCALYPTIC GENRE[/h1]

This is the second game in the series, and if you haven't played the first--"Metro 2033"--I highly recommend you start there.

So far I have already soaked in 200-300 hours across the whole series. The story telling, and game-play just compliment each other so well you can just get lost in playing for a few hours. Right now I'm replaying the whole series to achievement hunt which has proven more challenging than most other games I've completed, but in a good way.

I only have 2 issues with this game in the series:

1. The game drives my GPU crazy. I have a 3070ti, and yet this decade old game makes it heat up like a furnace, and the fans spike to 80%. Meanwhile I've run games like: Halo infinite, until dawn, and other more modern titles, and this doesn't happen. It's not a deal breaker, but I do find it odd.

2. The game occasionally crashes. This isn't atypical of older games, or games in general. Whats unique about these crashes are if you simply boot up the game, and continue where you left off the game will continue to crash. [b]Here is how I have found to fix the problem:[/b]

When you go to launch the game you will receive an error pop up asking to boot up in "safe mode", click NO, as all this will do is reset all your graphical preferences to the lowest possible setting. Once you get to the main menu go to CHAPTERS, and restart the chapter you were just playing. This will reset your save file, and purge anything that's been corrupted causing the crash. Any collectibles like Artyom's journals you've collected will be saved, but it wouldn't hurt to double check. Repeat for any further crashes.

I am two ways about it. While it was a great game and the atmosphere was fantastic, it was extremely linear. There were invisible walls all over the place and you couldn't get past them, the game basically forced you to travel in a pre-determined path. The collectables were rather easy to find. 

While the combat was somewhat flexible, it was very repetitive towards the end. Waves of mutants and other creatures/humans being hurled at you on several occasions, and you could see it happening even before it happened. The stealth aspect wasn't very good either. 

The story was much better than the first one, but it was all over the place. Voice acting was horrible for some characters and it completely killed the vibe in the end (dark one). Looking away from the person who is speaking would drastically lower the volume of the speech to an extent that you won't even make out if something is being said at all. 

The only thing I loved about this game was the atmosphere and the level of detail on the maps and surroundings. The sights were breathtaking and the whole set up was pretty great. The density of the establishments in the Metro were great to look at and explore.

The good:
Gameplaywise, it's more of the stealthy, Russian, post apocalyptic FPS goodness found in the first game.
Story is better with more compelling baddies.
A few more enemy types, and a couple boss battles thrown in.
Environments, character models and voice acting all quite good.
Frequent automatic save points.
It's 10 hours and that's exactly how long I wanted it.

The meh:
If you're looking for any serious gameplay advancements, you're not going to find any. There are one or two new guns and claymores. That's it.
It wears its influences (Stalker and Half Life) pretty brazenly.
It crashed 2-3 times. I think that's pretty acceptable.

The bad:
You do have different endings depending on...what? I still don't know if I got the good or bad one. Not a fan of games that make you look for online guides to help you get the best endings. But this is a minor quibble.
I really wished they'd clearly gone over the use of the compass (here and in the first game). I only realized it pointed toward my next objective because I read something online, about halfway through my game (yes, I'm an idiot).

Verdict:
If you don't like the creepy crawlies, stay away. For everyone else, it's a great on-rails adventure/shooter in a bleak but fascinating world of ghosts, mutants, Nazis and Communists. Can't wait to play Exodus.

Initially, my review was: NOT RECOMMENDED. But... I do have to admit it's a cool game, just with a lot of WASTED potential. I did enjoy it more than I was annoyed by it. However. The below statement still stands.

I've had it up to HERE with the bugs and crashes from this incompetent company. Yeah, the game got something going for it, a LOT actually, but this is starting to get old REAL QUICK thanks to:

- constant crashes in multiple sections of this VERY DRAGGED OUT, LONG GAME for what the game is trying to present
- very questionable checkpoint placements, hurts a lot on Survival Ranger Hardcore difficulty and just leaves a foul taste in your mouth (negligence, they did not care to playtest the checkpoints in this mode)
- corrupting of the save files for absolutely no reason in multiple sections, learning nothing from previous titles
- silly bugs throughout the entire playthrough like in a game from year 2000
- mouse sensitivity CANNOT be set to 1 pip (it will revert to only 0 or 2 upwards, wtf?)
- same horrible voice actor for 50 different characters in the 3rd (!) Metro game (Metro 2033, Metro 2033 Redux, Metro Last Light and now Metro Last Light Redux)... 

List goes on.

It has it's interesting moments, for example the little Dark One section, and some pretty good level design in many places. But overall, the story is just bland, uninspired and dry. Anna character was also probably just shamelessly plugged in at the end of the development of Last Light. Entire story feels half-a-you-know-what and recycled from the first game.

And finally - I STILL HAVE TO GO TO A CONFIG FILE TO CHANGE THE Field of View. After 3 previous games! Come on!

I really love this game and the franchise in general. Although this is the second game in the franchise, this was my first introduction to the series, and I loved it. I ended up getting the prequel and sequel, although I have not quite finished either, I am looking forward to more. Metro: Last Light Redux is an Action/ Horror single-player linear story game by Ukrainian developer 4A Games, and it is set in Moscow after a nuclear holocaust. More specifically, the game is mainly in the Moscow Metro, the busiest Metro system in Europe. It is a first person shooter. The game centers on Artyom, an orphan in the Metro. Artyom grows up in the Metro until he is called into action (in 2033 by Hunter, and then again in Last Light by Colonel Miller and Khan.) The game is overall very enjoyable and the story is quite compelling. There are a few points where it feels a bit slow, but other than that the vast majority of the game is interesting and there is a lot of care and detail invested into the game. There is a good and a bad ending for the game, so make sure to be merciful and charitable, but also don't forget to explore! The graphics definitely hold up, although they definitely should, as this is a redux. You shouldn't have any trouble running this game even on the worst of rigs, so don't worry too much about specs, but do keep the steam web-stores recommendations in mind.
Always been a fan of the Metro series but had a recent 7.4 gb update and couldnt find any information about it anywhere and now my game wont make it past the start screen.

One of the best games made by Ukrainian game devs. if you decide to play on an easy mode, the game will just look like crappy COD-like shooter in a post apocalyptic world. I recomend  playing on Ranger Hardcore difficulty- this is how it's meant to play. Counting every shot, going stealthy to preserve ammo and medkits. Oh and a quick tip: don't buy weapons. you won't have much money anyway and you will  find the same or even better gun  on the next level if you are attentive enough.

If you haven't touched 2033, I recommend you do, and the same goes for Exodus, the entire current trilogy is just a masterpiece in my eyes. Yes, I'm biased. This is like crack to me.

Well, after playing Last Light I can say that it is a better game than 2033, but not by too much. As I was expecting it takes the base that 2033 established and streamlines more of the clunkier aspects of the gameplay. There's a larger variety of weapons, stealth felt a tad easier and the level design feels much more open to multiple approaches. You can complete most of the enemy encounters without killing anyone, but there is still ample cover if things get too hot. The atmosphere is still amazing and I like the new checkpoints and towns visited in the story as it feels like getting a small look into how a society grows within the confines of the metro. The story itself was decent but takes a more black and white approach as compared to the greys that 2033 presented. Instead of finding the dark ones, you're trying to prevent a conflict between the main factions of the metro. More explosive sure, but not as nuanced as the first. In the end, I still enjoyed my time within both 2033 and Last Light, and I look forward to moving into Exodus.

Also, my game kept crashing on the last mission so I guess I didn't technically beat the game but I ain't gonna reinstall the game just to play 10 minutes of the game and get an achievement lol

OK so... in my humble opinion, both the first and second metro games are pretty awesome and because of that, I'm not gonna point out the good stuff I said in my Metro 2033 review because they're already told and instead, I want to write about the improvements compared to the previous game along with some minor complaints I have about this game.

Combat has improved dramatically, now it feel way more satisfying to fight enemies and monsters. Graphics have (obviously) improved a lot as well, and the environments are gorgeous. The character models are now more unique and you don't feel like you've seen the same face a million times like in Metro 2033. You can now put attachments on weapons which is really nice. There is more enemy variety (for both humans and monsters) now. Even some smaller additions like pressing G to wipe the mud and blood off your gas mask is neat. I really like the music too, Especially the more gloomy and sad ones with the guitar. 

The story and characters (Especially Khan, Pavel and Artyom himself) are very well written as well, now I really want to read the Metro books. Those small scenes and dialogues between levels in safe areas are also nice.

Now for the little problems I had...

1. The stealth feels a lot easier and less fun than 2033, enemies are literally blind and silenced weapons make being undetected very easy to pull off.
2. The whole game itself is easier (or at least I felt that way), I would recommend playing on a harder difficulty than normal, because normal is actually EASY.
3. That "romantic" cutscene with [spoiler] Anna [/spoiler] was awkward.
4. Enemies are still kinda spongy like in 2033.
5. [spoiler] The good ending is easy to miss and I think most players got the bad one first time, the problem is that the game doesn't really make it obvious to the player that their choices are going to make a big difference. For example in BioShock, it was pretty obvious that harvesting or rescuing little sisters is a big deal and has an impact on the ending, but not here. [/spoiler]

I totally recommend Metro Last Light to people who like FPS, Survival and Post-Apocalyptic games.
Oh and, the swamp level was awesome.
Very good game, would recommend this game and the others. Has a compelling story and the gameplay and graphic were ahead of it's time.

The Metro games are excellent. Though theyтАЩre based off the popular post apocalyptic fiction book by Dmitri Glukhovsky, Metro Last Light does not follow the story line in the book, instead it is a direct sequel to Metro 2033 (the game and book). Last Light is a game I believe everyone should try. 

The attention to detail is phenomenal, every part of the Metro has been carefully engineered with precision to create the look of a worn and dying civilization. This attention to detail creates an immersive and atmospheric game.

The game's plot is excellent. The Metro is very atmospheric and immersive thanks to the excellent graphics, the slow paced solo guitar music and the excellent plot. I won't go into detail as I don't want to ruin the story for anyone who hasn't had the pleasure of experiencing the Metro games. Essentially you, Artyom, wipe out the Dark Ones with a plethora of nuclear bombs - or so you thought. Intense radiation plagues the streets, which has caused mutation in many species turning them violent, untamable and monstrous. On the way you meet people, discover the civilizations (Hanza, Reich, The Order) and have a great time. 

 The music and SFX are good but the voice acting feels lacking for some but most characters are excellently voice acted. 

overall rating: 10/10

This game is a continuation from the first game as it plays exactly the same with a couple of minor differences. One of the throwable items is changed from a sticky grenade to a claymore. I was used to using the sticky grenade as it was easier to use when in a fight, but this didn't discourage me from playing the game. Another change was that there were more mutant varieties in the game, like the bosses Nosalis Rhino and Bear. Human enemies felt exactly the same. As for weapons, some were added. Aside from that, nothing else was added from a gameplay perspective.

Unlike the first game, this one had downloadable content. Nine new missions were added to this game. The missions ranged from short to long, and easy to difficult. I loved playing the Tower mission as it was a fun way to test the skills I've gained from playing first person shooter games.

Getting the good ending in this game isn't difficult, but a little troublesome. In order to get the majority of the positive moral points, you had to listen to long conversations between NPCs, which might be the reason why it took me longer to finish this game completely. A minimum of two playthroughs for the main campaign are needed to get all achievements. Like the first one, there are two modes and two endings.

The shooting mechanics, and stealth for this one is good. Though, enemies would sometimes not react in darkness even if you were standing in front of them. It's still an enjoyable experience, nevertheless. I would recommend this game for people who have finished and likes the story-driven nature of its predecessor.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he created an "invite only" game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As in the first part of Metro you slip into the role of Artyom. 
After a nuclear strike made the earth's surface more or less uninhabitable, he lives in the shafts and tunnels of the Moscow metro. Here the last survivors have found a refuge to survive more badly than right. 

However, they do not live alone here and there are enough enemies who attack and kill them again and again. Because anyone who dares to venture into the tunnels or well protected as Artjom to the surface needs nerves made of steel - there are all kinds of mutations that must have originated from worms or spiders and which have now assumed a monstrous appearance. But that's not all, because humanity, which has been decimated in this way, also fights among one another, as individual factions such as neo-fascists and neo-communists have now emerged. 
There are also banal bandits who want to rob you and your wards of your last shirt.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2807507075[/url]
[b]But that's not all[/b]. 
At the beginning of the game, you learn that a creature was discovered on the surface, although this species should actually no longer be alive. This is a form of life that could have emerged from surviving humans and that communicate using telepathy. This ability makes them so dangerous for the other survivors, as their spirit is often too weak to survive contact with these beings without harm. 
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2807506981[/url]
[b]But your job is to investigate this sighting ... and then you'll be right in the middle of it.[/b]

[b]Because of the story alone, Metro Last Light Redux offers much more than just bashful shooting.[/b] You can decide whether you want to end the life of every opponent or maybe sneak past them. Because the decision not to kill a potential victim is remembered by the game and that in turn influences the later end of the game. Precisely this option of being able to leave out one or the other opponent also increases the replay value.

In addition, two game modes are also available with "Survivor" or "Spartan" - the first is something for tinkerers, the steps here must be planned because you will find less ammunition to reload here, among other things. And the second is a tough action spectacle.

I've loved the Metro series, since i first played 2033 when it came out. The concept of survivor/horror, is literally what this game is made of. I have played every inch of this title, and have fallen in love with both the story, and the characters along the way. Even Artyom, whom never speaks, except in level introductions. Even so, it adds an air of mystery to the now, Spartan Ranger. It may not have aged well to some, but the series will always have a special place in my AI-2 medcase <3

SO MUCH CONTENT! Very buggy but worth your time. I dabbled with some of the DLC but ended up passing since I'm exhausted after everything and want to play something new. 8 out of 10 and that is from a picky player. If it wasn't buggy and if it had better checkpoints then it would be a 10. Read up in the guides so you know how to navigate the world, which difficulty suits you, and what guns fit your style.

The atmosphere and artstyle is so unique in this game that it's so recognizable anytime you see it. The game starts to become quite boring anytime you're with a companion as it's just non stop walking then going but anytime you're left alone is when the game gets great and is alot more fun because you can do things at your own pace in your own way. If you want a really immersive FPS game, Metro series does it perfectly and leaves you wanting more of it.
gud

Good followup to an already great game. Does the same as what Metro 2033 did but better and newer. Story carries off where you last finished, Gameplay feels very tactical and has many ways in which you can approach it. Sure you can turn it into an arcade shooter with an easier difficulty or you can experience more at a much harder difficulty, where you have to take out certain light sources, observe your surroundings, knock out or kill certain targets and take on many of the mutated bosses. Being a survival game also means you have to choose the right ammo and weapons for the right time. On top of the main story, there is DLC in which you can do various smaller missions. Nice game overall, get on discount if you can.

Like it's predecessor, this is an enjoyable game, although very short and linear.  Worth playing if you can pick up on sale.

It is the year 2034. Beneath the post-apocalyptic Moscow, in the tunnels of the Metro, there are remnants of mankind. In dark tunnels you can smell fear of death that is waiting for you. Deadly threats are everywhere, outside тАУ and within tunnels. Mutants stalk the catacombs beneath surface, and hunt the skies above. Station-cities of the Metro are locked in a struggle for the power, there is a doomsday device from the military vault of D6. A civil war is stirring that could wipe out the remaining humanity from the face of the Earth forever. 

You play as Artyom, burdened by guilt and driven by hope. A naive young boy who is not so young and not so naive anymore, after what happened a year before. You will have once again a lot of helpers, and sidekicks, that will help you, and you will help them along the way. You will have excellent missions and big problems to solve, levels are very good.

Also atmosphere is awesome throughout the whole game. Desperation, fear, hungry people, everything wrapped up into a really good story. I love both Metro games, and even though they are a bit short (it took me 17 hours to finish it on hard difficulty) it is still an excellent experience and great playing joy.

Main game is superb. A masterpiece. From atmosphere to sound, storyline and graphic. Gunplay sometimes clunky and annoying but better than 2033. Hate the fixed FOV tho
But the bonus maps...they range from decent to terrible.
Worst map is the first map. Plagued with blinding lens flares (I COULDN'T SEE A SINGLE THING), shitty rail gun with shitty accuracy, but enemy snipers have unreal accuracy (you see them you die immediately, especially the one on the left end)
Then the infiltration map. So tight and forceful on progress that I just walk one wrong step and game over. Very annoying.
The collecting map is quite nice. I kinda' like that idea of a stalker go to the surface getting stuff to sell in Metro.
Side character's quests are all nice.
Overall I highly recommend the game.

Second half drags on worse than the "artsy" finale of the first game, dredging through the consequences of Metro 2033's canonical bad ending, which is a bit annoying when you've gotten the good ending.

Speaking of endings, getting the good or bad one depends largely on gathering arbitrary secret points for interacting with the game world (even things like playing with instruments lying around). Basically, you can only get the good ending if you interact with almost everything in the game, no matter how tedious it may be to drink with npcs and get lap dances, or watch a horribly boring theatre show to the end (and act morally in the obvious situations). 

First half of the game is not bad, but nothing to write home about.

I played Mero: Last Light directly after Metro 2033 - and it is definitely a huge improvement compared to it's predecessor on so many levels: graphics are more pleasing to the eye, and lolk great even by today's standards; gunshots now sound more realistic and "pack a punch", voice acting still is great, atmosphere is excellent and the story is much more gripping than the first.
Is the game a clear 10 out of 10? No. It still is very linear,. And, at least on the first difficulty, you have way too much ammo to feel intimidated, reducing immersion a little. But it's a solid 8.5/10 for me. 
I would definitely recommend playing it once for the story/atmosphere.

Metro Last Light is a direct sequal to Metro 2033 and shares the same gameplay system as the 1st one. So same gunplay, stealth, shopping, gasmask etc. So basically everything that I said about the 1st  game is the same on this one, which is a great thing. Again I'm not going to tell about the story you just have to experiance it yourself. LL ads couple more guns to the mix like automatic shotgun that looks like a AK, two different high caliber sniper rifles and semi-automatic/automatic pistol similar to Mauser from the WW1. LL was scary but not as scary as 2033. All though it had more jumpscares. I feel that LL has more replayability than 2033. All and all great sequel.

On my second playthrough I finished the game with stealth and as non-violently as possible (trying to kill just few human enemies) and it made me wanna rip my nutsack and burn it on pig fat *reference*. It's still loads of fun!

Note/helpful tip if your fps is low: When a started the game it ran like turd in a blender, 25-45 fps. I didn't have the same problem with 2033 (2033 ran like 80-90+ fps on max). What helped me was that I lowered my SSAA settings to 2x instead of 4x and after that fps was same compared to 2033. And if your pc is not the most powerful then I advise you to lower that setting to 0.5x ( game won't look that great but it's 100% worth it and it will run well) 

Note#2: After completing the game in the main menu go to chapters and press Q to choose to play dlc missions. Yes dlc is included in the redux version of the game. And their fun. 

Note#3: Metro 2033 redux doesn't have dlc missions, LL has.
