[h1] Metro: Last Light Redux - 8.5/10 [/h1]
[b] Playtime - 6 hours [/b]

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b] 9/10, 9/10
[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b] 9.5/10
[b] Soundtrack: [/b] 7/10
[b] Graphics: [/b] 7.5/10 
[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b] 8/10, 8/10

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b]
The plot and dialogue of this game takes the essence of our last game and decides to take a twist on it by having it a story similar to that of Jesus Christ in the Bible. It certainly is an interesting take but it is well executed here and keeps the player emotionally invested through out. I feel the morality of our decisions is much more weighted here compared to Metro 2033. There are many intricacies and storylines present throughout this game that I would find it hard pressed to not relate to this game in some way, shape, or form.

[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b]
The setting and art design is extremely similar to Metro 2033 but there is a more varied environment that is used which is great to see. The metro still feels decrepit and like a hellscape. Great job on the developers part.

[b] Soundtrack: [/b]
Soundtrack has a minor step up compared to the previous game, with the music being somewhat more pervasive and able to help amplify the scenes we see and live through.

[b] Graphics: [/b]
Graphics are just as good as the previous entry, which are good but not great graphics.

[b] Gameplay: [/b]
The gameplay has the same core elements as the previous game, but the gameplay felt much more responsive and dynamic, giving you many more opportunities through the game to take a stealthy approach. There is more weapon variety so you can customize your loadout better.

New enemies are introduced and new mechanics are introduced with the Dark One, which makes things interesting and keeps the game feeling fresh, while still the similar feeling we expect from the franchise. 

You can pick which difficulty, one that emphasizes combat more, while the other emphasizes stealth and scavenging more. Both are good options to play the game. 

You can collect Artyom's journal entries throughout the game which provides a very interesting look into his mindset that you would not regularly find throughout the game. I enjoyed reading them and I highly recommend you do collect these. 

Sound design is good and works well for the game.

[b] Final Notes: [/b]
A very solid entry into the Metro franchise and certainly as step up from Metro 2033, which is great to see. I highly recommend this game for all.

All the wonderful game play from the first along with the same interesting storytelling that keeps you engaged every chapter along the way. METRO: LAST LIGHT REDUX

Pleased to have completed the second entry in the metro series, returning again you play as Artyom in the gritty horror filled metro tunnels beneath Moscow.

Sequel boasts improved graphics and story line which I can say was incredible, the new weapons and mutuants made this far more enjoyable then the first game, sound design definitely keeps you on edge the whole play through which will last around 10 hours if you take your time. I have to say again though.. some of the mutuants are bullet sponges... later on you will fight these creatures that crawl out of the water and you will.. without a doubt blow through all your ammo...

I wanted to save D6 (your allied bunker) so I tried my best to do a good guy play through.. somehow I still failed and had to sacrifice my home because of some of the decisions I made earlier on...

I checked a walk through and to save D6 you need to do absolutely everything correctly, that is my only issue with this game, besides that I loved it and would highly recommend this game to any FPS fan.

Check it out for sure!

Metro Last Light Redux: I Am Artyom : )

In the halls of the funny Russian games that Yankees like to talk about whenever someone makes a joke about Russia, none have quite the weird mixed reputation as Metro. Half game, half synopsis of the novel series, and a game that defies any specific categorization. Is it a survival horror FPS? A story driven first person experience? A generic action game? Yes. Yes it can be all of those things and more for reasons no one but 4A understands. 

Last Light Redux is a remaster in a way that I legitimately can't notice and the only thing it does now is give you all the DLC from Last Light for free, which amounts to around 2-3 hours of side content and a few weapons that I used once. The Bigun really doesn't shock the balance of the game all that much. Beyond that and the lighting, it is the same basic game as the last one, and it's not the improvement that 2033 Redux is.

Following the ending of 2033 where Mr. Artyom and his fun friend the Rangers took over the bunker of D6, fought a long standing war with the Dark Ones and/or nuked them, you awaken to find D6 under threat. While you were gone on a nuclear genocide, the other denizens of the Metro, the Red Line and Fascists are vying for power, unifying their forces for one push to take the jewel of D6. It is up to you to prevent this, unlock more secrets to D6 and find out who is drinking all of the mushroom vodka. And bully Pavel. It's a story I don't notice, beyond being WICKED short and able to be "completed" in 10 hours flat. But I do notice the gameplay improvements.

Namely when you shot someone, they died and didn't eat half a mag of 5.45 before electing to perish today. I don't understand how STALKER and Metro 2033 shared the exact same weird spongey enemies but they do, and thankfully Last Light doesn't with a reworked combat system that makes it fun to fight people. And to stealth. And for the ability for me to customize my weapons rather than psychotically savescumming to remember which exact station had the suppressed and scoped Kalash 2013. And with a smidgen of new weapons to fit in the niches the other game left behind. Are they good? I dunno, I vaguely remember using the Ashot and the Lolife with a stock and suppressor made stealth too easy, so I suppose it's good.

This is a very good way to kill like 20 hours of your time, and usually for cheap on sale because 4A doesn't care. Pick it up for 10 bucks, lose a couple of nights to the funny Russian game, blow a bandit's face off with a shotgun, and then uninstall it and forget about it until ancient YouTube videos polluting your brain make you remember the game exists in the first place.

[b]Metro: Last Light Redux[/b] is another remaster of sorts тАФ graphical and balance updates. It's stands as the sequel to Metro 2033.

There's going to be vague spoilers throughout this review due to the connected nature of the series.

[h3]Enlightened[/h3]
While Metro: Last Light can be played isolated from the series, you will lose a considerable amount of context if you do. And perhaps to the game's own detriment, the linear, highly narratively-driven structure of the game makes it semi-unapproachable. Mild spoiler: The interesting about these first two games is that they have multiple endings but there is no mechanic to import any of these decisions into the next one. Making them feel slightly disjointed, if not ethereal or dreamlike тАФ depending on your perspective, this may be seen as a positive thing. However, there are canon endings. The elusive but [i]hidden[/i] morality system is still present.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2791414675

What's more is that after the events of Metro 2033, Artyom is made a Ranger in the Spartan Order. In addition to the specific reason as to why that occurred, Artyom's awareness and understanding of the world around him seems to grow [i]with[/i] the player. How the Metro works and the government therein, the monsters and ways to dispatch them. The feeling that Metro: Last Light gives off over its predecessor is not only a feeling that seems slightly more polished, but one that feels innately familiar. And not just because it's a horror-themed FPS.

The world building is slightly better than in Metro 2033, if only because it's built upon rather than an introduction. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2791414684

[h3]Up your Arsenal[/h3]
Being a Ranger in the Spartan Order has its perks. For one, there's an increased set of weapons to use. More ammo types and more types of explosives. Interestingly, this makes the game much more action-focused even when playing in the default survival mode. You still need to manage your gas mask, filters and use military grade bullets (used as currency) for extra damage but there are very long, extended sequences where Artyom needs to trudge across the surface of Moscow or sneak through tunnels avoiding the Reich.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2791414694

[b]Related diatribe:[/b] This is the same thing that Dead Space is criticized for тАФ straying away from its survival horror roots for a more action-heavy game. At no point in this game was I concerned about rationing my ammo, medkits or filters on the default settings. I don't see this as innately negative as there are many of difficulty options. There are even a few encounters that are quite traditional boss battles, which in the context of a tense horror sequence only serve to remind me that I'm playing a video game. Like I had to figure out what to do to win this battle rather than simply survive. I just find it odd this game is not more criticized for the change in direction while Dead Space is. Condemned 2, the FEAR games тАФ even the Crysis games take this path.

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
I don't think Last Light stands out as much as an isolated product compared to the original. But it has an okay campaign and serves as a narrative bridge into Exodus. So if you're concerned with story, it's a necessary antecedent. It's about the same length as Metro 2033 but it [i]feels[/i] shorter тАФ I believe this is largely due to the game seeming less tense overall.

UPDATE: the in-game menus are bad. I was buying the wrong ammo for the guns I had. (I discovered this the worst way, having to reload and finding no ammo available). So, after "dying", I had to go back to the ammo dealer. In the buy/sell ammo menu, there was no way to know which was for which. So I had to go back to combat, and while reloading, memorize the icon of the ammo for each gun. 
I┬┤m pretty sure I┬┤ve lost a reasonable amount of money with those wrong trades, in a game where ammo is already scarce...

UPDATE> I┬┤ve always wondered why I didn┬┤t like the Metro and S.T.A.L.K.E.R, but never could my finger on it...
Now I know. It┬┤s because of the gas masks.
Although it┬┤s a cool concept, especially in a post-apocalypse scenario, you know what they are?
They are timers.
Avery time you have to wear a gas mask, you┬┤re on a timer.
.
.
.
Since I never like timed missions, I don┬┤t like missions with gas masks.
..
..
I will still try this one a little more, but, I like to take my time to address the situation and plan my moves, and a countdown over my have just adds to stress, not a cool, positive adrenaline.
.
..
But if you don┬┤t mind timed missions, I still recommend this game.

It's a little dated, but still a great game. Some of the aspects, such as swamp levels, the "boss fights," and poor collision detection are some of the bigger downsides for me. The story, atmosphere and immersion is simply magnificent. There are so many levels to this game, and many different ways of playing it. Even though you encounter human enemies, it feels sad to kill them - even though they want to kill you, they're still part of just a small number of human survivors after WW3. That's why I prefer to sneak around and simply knock out (not kill) most of the human enemies. The non-human enemies are scary as hell, and after walking and crawling around crowded metro tunnels or caved in catacombs, you really just want to find the next human establishment and relax for a minute.
It is pretty good, lots more variations in environment, tougher enemies and situations.  Play it with the Russian voices for more authenticity.

My opinions on Last Light are largely the same as 2033. Good game, bad port. The FOV is set very low, and the y axis sensitivity is stuck to 50% of the x axis sensitivity. You can do a bit of fiddling in the config files to fix the FOV, and if you're lucky, the sensitivity as well, but for whatever reason, the later fix just doesn't work for some unlucky souls, myself included. Your only other option is a dll file you can download from a sketchy website which probably isn't connected to the keylogger I found on my PC the next day, but it is a hell of a coincidence. Either way, I can't exactly recommend it in its current state. If you've got a console, play it on that instead.

An improvement over Metro: 2033, but still a disjointed mess.

Narrative is greatly improved, but has a very long way to go yet. Gun-play is still clumsy; hit registry and/or enemy durability is still disproportionately spongy or easy to kill; and enemy A.I. is still erratic and unrefined at times. Music and use of music has improved; screenplay/storytelling is much improved, but still very erratic relatively frequently; and exploration and the meaning of choices have been improved. Unfortunately, unrewarding exploration; dead-ends; and death traps are still present in the game, albeit at a reduced rate (by about 2/3rds).

Missing journal entries can obfuscate the entire premise of story arcs; choices don't appear to have meaningful consequences; and character building and interactions are still weak for certain characters. However, for other characters, development is much stronger - again, showcasing the Metro series' extremes of strengths and weakness.

The game is considerably longer than Metro: 2033; coming in at just over double the play time (for a total play time of about 18 hours, if going at a slower pace); thus, making the game more worthwhile to play. Replay value has also been increased, but is still not very high.

Prone to crashing, as well as becoming unresponsive.

Again, I would love to love this series more, but they need a lot of work to be considered even "good" games. This one - compared to Metro: 2033 - however, is more of a very rough diamond, as opposed to an interesting, but highly compromised experience. I would recommend this only for those that are willing and able to see past its technical problems, and disjointed (and problematic) narrative and gameplay; desiring something that is different in tone; atmosphere; and story content than most games. For hardcore gamers, or intrepid narrative and/or gameplay enthusiasts only.

3/10. (Would be 4/10 if not for technical issues.)

Should I give it a 10/10? No, it has some bugs here and there and the AI is effectively generic nonsense. What carries this game is definitely not the enemies, the combat, or the gameplay, but the story and the lore, the ambiance. I have read the books and finished all of the games multiple times. I believe that of all of the three games, Last Light might be the weakest of the series, but it is still an amazing entry in this franchise. The story drags a bit more than necessary and I still dislike the hidden karma system where you can brutalize every individual in the game, but you just can't kill some dude and you receive a good ending. I would prefer choices that are a bit more obvious. Most of the good karma choices in the game I consider to be unwise and naive. Oh, another negative, Khan is a hipster now...pfff
Anyway, take my review as an expression of love, the game is absolutely amazing!
Overall, this is a fantastic story and with this review I am going towards my second run for Metro Exodus, this time the enhanced edition on the PC.

The events of the Metro 2033 game take place in a post-apocalyptic world in the Hero city of Moscow, people went down to live in the metro, since it is impossible to live on the surface...
You will have to play for a young guy, Artyom, whom we will not see in the process of passing. The game from the first person and all the horror that is happening in the subway, we will see with our own eyes. The whole game consists of: a prologue and seven chapters, which in turn are divided into sections. When passing the game, you will meet many NPCs, for the most part they are stupid and will not be able to provide all possible assistance, except to distract the enemy. Artificial intelligence, in the form of enemies, is weak.
There are two main modes of passing the game - Survival and Spartan. You can select subsections according to the complexity of the interface and the level of the game: standard, hardcore, ranger, ranger hardcore. The last two modes are especially tough, tips, sights, some information have been removed, opponents have been strengthened - they are really difficult and difficult to pass.
There are not many types of opponents in the game, monsters and people. And judging by the plot of the game, people are scarier.
Basically, the whole game takes place on two main locations, the surface and the actual subway.
As for the items the character uses, there aren't many of them. The choice of weapons in the game is not very wide, mainly firearms that can be modified, depending on the style of the game. Pleased with inventory restrictions, it is impossible to use more than two types of weapons, the supply of ammunition and medicines is limited. Pleased with the combat mode, the enemy can kill you with a couple of blows or shots.
The game can be played in stealth mode, but the NPCs that keep you company sometimes get in the way.
I can't say that the graphics are outstanding. It is difficult to evaluate the graphic component of the game, which was released in 2010. But I think that for the release of the game on Play Station 4, the graphics were tightened up.
The developers devoted a lot of time and effort to the sound implementation in the project, which is only worth the chant of Mikhail Krug's song "Vladimirsky Central", the character of Bourbon, with whom Artyom travels. In general, all the dialogues are worked out, and if you wander around the stations and listen to what the NPCs are talking about, you can sometimes hear very touching and soul-stirring stories.
In general, it is interesting to play the game using headphones. The sounds of what is happening around sometimes made me shudder, more abruptly than the vaunted Hollywood horror films.
I did not quite like the linearity of the plot, there is no possibility to choose non-standard solutions. There are two choices at the end of the game. Maybe all this is connected with the events described in the Metro 2033 book. But in general, the plot catches and holds for causal places until the very end.
In general, throughout the entire game, you can feel the special atmosphere of the game, which will be understood by people from the CIS and is unlikely to be understood by foreigners, for them this is an ordinary horror shooter.

The sequel to Metro 2033: Last Light (Ray of Hope), was released in 2013. The developer and publisher remained the same; 4A Game and Deep Silver. The plot for this game was the second book by Dmitry Glukhovsky.

In general, the concept and atmosphere of the game has remained at the same level, which is excellent. Continuation of the story about the guy Artyom, who became a hero and a legend in the world of Metro.
Compared to Metro 2033, the graphics have improved significantly. As in the first, so in the second parts, the realization of precipitation and weather events was pleasing.
From linearity, the game has not gone anywhere, but the plot has been twisted so much that it was a pleasant surprise when passing the game. The storyline is turned upside down in an instant.
Management remains the same, intuitive and not particularly tricky. It is difficult to say whether the controls are convenient on the PC, I really liked the controls on the PlayStation. A significant number of various weapons have been added to the game, while maintaining the possibility of modification. It is possible to choose weapons for different styles of play.
The sound in the game is at the same level, just as scary and interesting. Artificial intelligence (opponents) was left at the same level, but it seemed to me that the stealth mode was finalized.
In total, the game has 30 chapters that you pass in one breath. As in the previous part, there are two options for the ending of the game.
The second part did not spoil the Metro 2033 universe, but rather added and shook it up.

Now let's go over the main disadvantages of this game.
This game has a decent amount of bugs, boxes flying away when you touch them. The corpses of opponents fall into the texture. Decently strained replicas of the NPCs who traveled with the main character. When you run, you study something, and in the background there is a comment: "Well, where are you already ..." and so many times, it was annoying.
It is not possible to create a save, if you are playing the game on ranger difficulty and cannot complete the story due to a lack of filters for a gas mask, you need to restart the game.

I believe this sequel to Metro 2033 is much better than it┬┤s predecessor. In terms of gameplay little is done to update or improve the formula, nonetheless there are other aspects of the game such as it┬┤s story and the characters that are clearly (in my own opinion) improved in comparison to the first game.
In terms of storytelling, i believe the story is more interesting since it adapts the aspects of the post apocalyptic Moscow but the story it contains some detalis i think the first game didn┬┤t dare to. For example, i believe that the character of the little dark one as a moral companion for the character is a better than just a white flare in the screen whenever you do something either good or bad. The kid is a way to make us care about what we do, mainly because the kid will learn from what we do. It is a nice touch, idk.
The "good" characters, which are our allies are developed better but the "enemies".... well, they are the so known "Baddies" and they could have made it better.
The ambient is similar to the first game so i do not have further comments other than we are on the outside in more oportunities than 2033 which allows to see the decay of the world we once inhabited.
I recommend all 3 games of this saga, each one improves aspects from it┬┤s predecessor and thats something i can be thankfull for.

Following up on the events of Metro 2033, Last Light continues the story from the perspective of Artyom, the main protagonist of the previous game. Although the story takes place in the year 2034, the game is not based off the second novel "Metro 2034"; nonetheless, story is canon and written by the same author.

In terms of gameplay, it's pretty much identical to Metro 2033 Redux. The realistic aspect of managing your equipment is very enjoyable. Wiping your gas mask feels extremely satisfying. As with the first game, you could choose to go stealth or guns blazing although the game tends to lean more towards action this time around. There is heavy emphasis on story with great voice work and dialogue that is slightly hindered by a less subtle approach in storytelling. Additionally, one of your partners, Anna, seemed out of place with rather weak writing but compensated for by having short screen time.

With a very limited budget, Ukrainian studio 4A Games have created an incredible and believable post-apocalyptic world ready to be experienced. Fans of the series would not be disappointed.

Somehow overshadowed by its prequel and sequel without living much memorable story behind. The retcons that had to happen to shoehorn this game into the timeline really messed with my enjoyment. The child-like whimsy of the dark ones in this entry to the series totally killed any horror vibe that the original had worked so hard to cultivate. While technically superior, the original Metro somehow holds up better years later. I wouldn't skip this entry in the series, but don't waste your time 100% it outside the campaign.
Definitely worth it. Highly underrated series.

Metro Last Light is a well put together and enjoyable game. It relies a bit heavily on deus ex machina but has stellar environment design, strong writing, good pacing, and a stealth system that walks the fine line of being both effective and not immediately killing you for failure.

This is Metro at its peak. I'd love to see a return to the metro in future games. Exodus was a nice change of pace, but I keep coming back to Last Light. It just [i] nails [/i] the metro feel. 

The story is good; Pavel is a very well-written character with charisma that didn't come across as over-the-top or irritating. Anna's writing is truly [b] abysmal [/b] (FAR more competently written in Exodus) and one scene in particular was cringe-overload.
Miller's arc was also good. Nice to see him for more than just a gruff-military-guy; good setup to his development in Exodus.  

Outside of the story, I particularly enjoy the Kshatriya DLC; it's kind of a mini-Exodus in a way. Go out, retrieve things, return to base, but it takes place in the metro. 

8/10

After binging 2033, came to this one to continue the story.  Very good continuation which developed the factions a lot.  Just like the last game, some weird game design things transferred over, however, it is much better than the last.  The game is much smoother and fluid to run through.  I only found myself having issues with one or two small things which, at least for one of them, were mostly my fault as a first-time-through player.
yes.
Great game. Great story. Inspired by a great book.

Great combination of stealth, action, and post-apocalyptic horror. Some might find the storytelling a bit too linear and on-rails, but this approach lends itself well to the overall theme of the game. It's basically Russian Half-Life. 

I really like the weapon design they used for these Metro games. Most of these weapons look and feel like they were cobbled together from scrap parts by mechanics living in a wasteland (which is exactly how they are made). I also love the weapon customization options you are given.

The story is quite interesting, although not unique. Listening to enemy dialogue is fun while sneaking around. And there is a morality system in play. Based on your actions, you can get one of two different endings. 

Overall, I give this game a solid 8.5/10

Immediately following my completion of Metro 2033, I went and bought Last Light. I finished the whole playthrough in one sitting, taking just about 9 hours. If you like the first game, this is more of the same with better voice acting and sound effects. Writing was noticeably weaker, though.

The world looks great and has a certain charm to it unlike the story where it all feels one sided and shallow. It becomes quite unbearable at the end but at least the ''bad'' ending isn't so black and white like I would've thought. Still the most fun you can have in this game is fighting against humans which is not the main focus of the game. There are many monsters that just feel like a chore to fight through or run past. They put so much effort into the ai and voice lines for humans and made they appear on par or even less than the generic boring beasts.

This is still the best series of Metro which I have ever had. Though I fould a lot of glitches and bugs, the game is still really good. Yet, this was the hardest for me, that I shat over 30 times, because I was too scared. Of course, this is what i recommend to everyone, but ONLY (!) if you don't have any mental issues and heart diseases. The only problem is that I was always nervous whenever I was left alone with the Dark Ones. 
Yet I got the bad ending, i still love it more than the good ending (I've not passed it).
I won't regret of passing only with bad ending, because it's actually the good one, how I thought and others did that so.

Just a comically terrible game. Here are a few reasons:

- You know when you get trapped in a narrow maze of tunnels in an FPS and you're simultaneously railroaded down a very narrow path but it's hard to figure out the exact path you're supposed to take? That's this game, all the time.

- You spend so much of the game just doing what a companion tells you, or pressing buttons because your HUD orders you to.

- It's a "stealth" game with enemies who can't see you even if you walk right under their nose, or shoot a pistol half a meter from their head. The non-human enemies are ridiculous and absolutely no fun to fight.

- It has an incredibly depressing vibe and a really weird macho tone, like being stuck in an ad for Monster energy drink.

- While wandering around, you find notes strewn about which apparently are... written by you, describing what is happening at right that minute?

Make a hard pass.
fantastic
great story and very compelling and has gameplay that makes you think

An improvement from the first one.

The environments are beautiful, the stealth is still janky but better.

Level design has been greatly improved and there are a lot of cool mechanics.

Gun upgrades are still meh, but there are a lot more guns to try. Sadly you cans till only carry 3 so you won't try them all out.

The game does drag on in some parts, but at least it gives you interesting things to look at. It does get a bit repetitive with the gameplay loop and could use some different secrets to find.

The levels are very confusing and if you want to go stealth, you have to restart whole levels because the checkpoints are very far apart from each other. Some boss fights aren't as intuitive as they should have been and are really frustrating.

Overall a solid 8/10

[h1]ЁЯУД Review of Metro Last Light Redux [/h1]
[/quote]

[quote]
Metro: Last Light Redux is a 2013 post-apocalyptic-themed, first-person shooter video game with stealth and survival horror elements. It was developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver.
As the sequel to Metro 2033 it has similar gameplay which is fairly linear mostly threw the tunnels in the metro but also on the surface. You play Artyom to find the Dark One. On your mission you encounter members of the Soviet Red Line and Nazi Fourth Reich who are trying to stop you. As a First-Person Shooter the gunplay is a big part of the game. Ammunition is very rare in the post-apocalyptic environment which gives the game an additional layer of atmosphere. The world is designed appropriately and carries this feeling even further.
[/quote]

It is a literal masterpiece! Made from a wonderfully written book, it has a hard driving story that leaves the player with many questions but fewer answers making it perfect for people who like to think and theorize. At the same time it's also grasping enough on a surface level that it can be nice to play as a mindless but enjoyable action story. Overall this game is suitable for many audiences and in the time I have played it, it has become one of my favorite single player games one of the few with repeatability.

Love the Metro games. I think Last Light had a little more heart, while 2033 had a little more horror, but these games are both fantastic. Metro Last Light: Redux is a glitchy, jank laden nightmare. From having to turn off physx just to stop the game randomly crashing, to the game flat refusing to load one level in particular, made this a totally unenjoyable return to the metro. From ex-stalker devs you expect some eurojank and i can take the kind of weirdness like ranger hardcore mode essentially being broken by hiding UI elements that are necessary to complete QTE's or whatever, but the actual issues in just running the game are unacceptable. I didn't have these issues with the standard edition of Last Light, so I'd recommend that over this "redux" version, but I'm not sure if that's even available anymore.

If you're married... do not play the Venice scenes if your wife is in the room.

The 2nd installment to the series and it does not disappoint. Similar to the first it sets you on missions, but the narration in between the missions sets the background for the story and gives context where you don't even feel like it's a loading screen. It's a really nice touch that keeps you going.

THIS GAME DOES NOT CONTAIN METRO 2034 SPOILERS. I waited until I'd read 2034 before playing Last Light, only to find that I needn't have bothered as they are separate storylines... Now that's out of the way, Last Light Redux (I haven't played the original) contains a longer story mode than Metro 2033, as well as some DLC missions that include a semi-open-world Stalker quest, taking your own path through a section of Moscow and scavenging items to trade for bullets and more equipment. As with the first game, you get a good look at the world beneath Moscow even if the linear gameplay doesn't allow for complete exploration; it does push the storyline along though, and if you did play 2033 then you should like how Arytom's story has been added to.

Not so cool as Exodus, because metro is basically dungeon, so its much more straight forward and basically linear. Sometimes I was kind of bored because of too similar situations, like hide in shadow and evade to be seen, done. In case of second play, it would be much more easy to go through, but I'm not really up to play it 2nd time. Moral part of game is not so fine tuned as in Exodurs, too, so I do not even know, what exactly gone wrong where to get bad ending, but since I have not really found any person, I would like to protect, I do not mind. AI of enemies is sometimes strange, because they do see you hidden somewhere and sometimes they do not see/hear you just behind their back, so many times it was like "aaah I do not give dam, and I will not load it only because this last idiot >>killing spree<<"; All mentioned things I do not like on this version of Metro are solved in Exodus, which is 1000x more interesting, mainly because of variability of missions. But this game is really good "dungeon" and all my thoughts are just complains because I have seen next game from same word, and its SOOO much more fine-tuned. So if you like Metro books and you like dungeons and 1st person shooters with possible go-through by hiding in shadows, definitely go for this.

A great sequel to 2033, that expands into the world built before, and continues Artyom's story. As usual, atmosphere, details and visuals are outstanding and have held quite well.
Sadly it's hard to enjoy through the sea of jank this game has. 

-Sound design is bad, literally can't hear people if you turn around. Also expect cheap stock sounds for everything
-English dub is kinda terrible
-Non-adjustable FOV is super low and makes it uncomfortable to play. You can adjust it in the game files but it breaks some visual effects and cut-scenes. Still a good trade off.
-Kinda bad scripting everywhere, specially with NPCs all talking at the same time.
-Ranger mode kinda unplayable in some places if you don't know exactly what you are supposed to do.
-Gunplay isn't really satisfying either, just gotta hope things are dying when you shoot
-Stealth mechanics are a bit better than before but still super basic, and they are a big part of the game unless you wanna get shot to death in 5 seconds.

If you liked the previous game, still worth playing but just be ready for the many, many technical shortcomings it has. It also seems to crash randomly. Funny enough, performance isn't bad. I recommend lowering the brightness tho because the game by default is a bit too bright.

Metro: Last Light Redux is a sequel of the popular game Metro 2033.

[b]pros[/b]
+ immersive story
+ gunplay
+ weapon variety
+ more human interactions than in Metro 2033

if someone is so desperate to find some interesting gunfights with Russian army in some chapters of the game, its recommended to get involved with this unrealistic and disturbing game. Game has an arrow menu to follow, if you do so, all the time your character will keep suffocating and dying without gas mask. I played short cuts some chapters, every 10 seconds character was dying without gas mask. How a ranger going to missions without supply of any gas mask at all very strange. If you keep look around blindly like a hobo or drank, you will have gas masks to go through some chapters which could be really interesting and adventurous other than disturbing. It feels disturbing and disgusting killing the mood of adventure, action fun with bull shit. You can only fight with the humans in this game, they will let you kill most of them in shadow mode like hobos. I only liked the fight on the train which was real action and fight with compact logic. I ran with life in the bridge because the game has foolish logic to ruin adventure and action. It is fine that animals can move fast and aim should be difficult, but if the character does not get no space to move it will become disturbing. Two magazines full of shots cant kill the animals, why do you play actually ? I must say Metro Redux was almost same but playable, the second part they tried to make it hard with bull shit and ruined the game. I liked the Metro Exodus, that one is total mature logic and realistic game without unnecessary bull shit to ruin the test and mood of action and adventure. How someone goes to mission without oxygen I dont have no idea, only stupids and desperate people will play this game wasting times.

I recommend this game.  I enjoyed the story and the action. It sucks to Not Recommend this game because I really enjoyed 2033 (enough to play it twice). Last Light takes 2033's linearity and turns it into a glorified on-rails experience that only gets more annoying the further into the game you get. I don't care about any of the NPCs this time around and the narrative overall just didn't grab me the same way. I also think the arenas encourage firefights a lot more when a big reason I loved 2033 so much was because of the stealth options at your disposal. All in all Last Light is a big step back for me and while that hurts to say, it's the truth.

A more personal issue is that there are way more of the arachnid enemies this time around and my arachnophobia can't handle it. Fighting them is one thing but when the game animates a spider scurrying across your gas mask it becomes too much.

Probably the best of the franchise, an even mix of action shooter and survival horror. I like the first one better, but you should just go ahead and get the first two in like a bundle or something and decide that for yourself.

I really wanted to love the Metro series, I really did. I love this genre of games, and actually had never played the series so I wanted to check them out. What the developers got right was the atmosphere and story. All 3 games are beautiful and the environment is immersive and there's so much story line and conversations you can have with randoms. Last light visuals were delightfully improved from 2033. Unfortunately, I felt my experience was plagued by some bad mechanics that just simply ruined full immersion and made much of the combat and exploration frustrating and not fun at all.

Most of the combat with mutant creatures was still unsatisfying like in 2033, their movements were often jerky and unnatural. The damage required to kill the same creatures was inconsistent, one shot to kill one creature, 4-5 to kill another identical creature.

Stealth was also inconsistent. Often times an enemy was able to spot me through a 1 inch gap in a wall in full darkness. And most of the time, even when killing an enemy stealthily with a throwing knife, every other enemy in the entire map was immediately made aware and ran straight for my position. As far as I could tell, it was nearly impossible to pass any stage stealthily without someone noticing.

Combat with the human elements in the game was by far the most satisfying, but the AI was often pretty simple and overall not too challenging. If these mechanics were a little bit more refined, I think I would have enjoyed the series quite a bit more. Overall the games are decent, but certain mechanics hold them back from being great.

Just finished this play-through as part of playing the entire Metro trilogy series and all I can say is... wow, what an incredible experience. I didn't read any of the Metro books before buying the game, but it doesn't really matter. It was humorous how Anna was all about being tough and strong as a woman in the military and a bit distant with me since she hardly even knew me be but later on, she wanted just anybody to make her feel like "being alive" and she chose me in desperation.  I'm just an available warm body of a man it appears.  Anyway, back to the review.... all of the battles were challenging and a few made me angry that I had to re-do several times and one in particular that caused me to put the game down in anger  ЁЯС┐  and walk away for a few days, but I came back and conquered it on the SEVENTH attempt but just barely at that. Yes, this game can be very brutal if you don't use different strategies and tactics like conserving gas mask filters and ammo. You have to approach this game with the goal of learning something about yourself and the importance to change strategies as situations change. Not every battle requires you to kill everything in sight. Sometimes itтАЩs best to run away  ЁЯПГ  or sneak away just to save your life while saving limited resources especially gas mask filters. Overall, this has been a positive and memorable experience.  I'd rate this game a solid  8 out of 10.  ЁЯША

After 4 play-throughs I still love this game.  I've played the original, I played it once through on PS3 and 4 respectively, and once more on PC with the redux.  After you play a game so much you really start to see its flaws, but that goes with everything.  Visual and audio glitches, enemies spawning right in front of you, cover sometimes just doesn't work, and your shadow glitches the hell out.  And yet it is still one of the most captivating story driven FPSs I've ever played, on par with the greats like Half-Life and Bioshock.  Even with its short comings the games gunplay, story, and atmosphere save it completely.

I think this is mostly helped by the fact that the last few levels are some of the best.  I always forget, after Pavel leaves, the story really starts to drag.  It's not bad but you sort of meander around until about half way through the game where the main story finally catches up.  It's all still amazing but the second half of the game is rather forgettable.

Also, as a note if you are going to play this, play on Ranger difficulty.  I don't mean this in a "get gud" or hardcore gamer sort of way I mean the game is way to easy and boring on normal.  Even if your not very good at FPSs it's still worth it.

Not a fan of this game, 2033 was much better in all regards.

Namely, balance is crap. It doesn't feel good to shoot enemies in this game, humans are somewhat encouraging, but both damage dealt and taken should be buffed greatly. I can understand taking 3 shots to kill a mutant, but not when there are 20 mutants to kill and only 20 ammo lying around, with no option to switch weapons either.

I was particularly upset by a certain "boss" that literally did nothing except eat ammo to the face, which was the weak spot. 60 shells from a fully upgraded saiga + 180 assault rifle rounds and it's still not dead. I spent all my grenades knives, claymores, and ammo just to kill it. And I was lucky to carry an assault rifle because I needed another 90 MGRs to finish it off, as it would otherwise not die.

Really, really boring to press through this game, I wish I didn't buy the Redux pack, and I am very reluctant to get Exodus now, which I heard is even worse.

Metro: Last Light succeeds in telling a continuation of the story of Metro 2033 but fails in enhancing any previously existing mechanics. 

The story is a bit longer in this title but feels disjointed. A love interest is introduced early in the game and then all but abandoned near-instantly, making her a constant question of "why does this scene exist," followed by more confusion. Artyom is knocked out for nearly every level transition which makes it feel like I'm missing small things that could be interesting (and I could be, if they'd done *anything* with these transitions). The level design stays the same familiar and classic linear area with small storytelling moments occasionally, offering a familiar claustrophobic underground environment for about half of the game and long treks across the surface that feel rushed and confused for the other half. 

The karma system makes a return with the same frustrating and inane feeling decisions if you want the "good" end. There are no improvements here, just more points can be earned here by doing nothing or avoiding confrontation than in 2033.

The combat system is completely unchanged from 2033, however we are given a significantly larger pool of guns to choose from. If you play Ranger Hardcore as I did, however, the vast majority of these guns will be inaccessible for you either due to ammo consumption, lack of ammo, or inability to obtain a world spawn of the weapon because you can't earn enough bullets to buy the gun (thanks Hellbreath). Overall, the guns look better and with wider variety but you'll see so few for most of the campaign that they might as well not exist.

Overall, the main story is a miss for me, the karma system is still a miss for me, but the guns and stealth still feel good enough that they'll get you through the game.

This is basically like the first game, but better. It feels more like an expansion to the first game. Pretty much everthing is better, the story is more engaging and personal to Artyom (its more about Redemption). The gameplay is better, and the game is overall longer.

The only downside is you're going to have to jump through some f*cking hoops to try and get the true ending, and I mean really go out of your way and jump through hoops, for instance you can't engage combat too early since you need to listen in on certain dialogue, you can't kill certain people and you have to find certain tunnels. Oh and btw if you even f*ck up once and accidently kill the wrong person just once... then the true ending is locked out for you,

Which is a damn shame since the true ending, known as Redemption ending. Is so good. I recommend looking it up on youtube rather than try to jump through all these hoops.

Other than that, this game is basically the first one, but better. You even get the explore the other factions much more indepth, especially the Red Line and the Reich.

[b]Metro: Last Light[/b] improves upon the first game in every conceivable way. They even fixed the stealth so that itтАЩs actually viable now. 

There are some problems, mainly the way they paced the difficulty. The game gets unforgivingly hard in some spots. 

For example, thereтАЩs this awkward part where youтАЩre waiting for a raft and the game decides the entire room is lit and stealth is no longer an option even though it had been for basically the whole game until that point. It caught me by surprise and looking around the Steam forums it seems a lot of people had problems with this exact place.

There are also two even worse areas towards the very end of the game that are incredibly frustrating: one where you are given a power-up thatтАЩs supposed to help but it only actually makes the fight harder because you canтАЩt see properly. And the second being an obnoxious boss fight. 

Still, difficulty pacing aside, this was [b]exactly[/b] what I was looking for in Metro. The world is depicted in a much more grimdark way than in the original and they donтАЩt shy away from delving into the horrors of the post-apocalypse in a much more grown-up way than something like Fallout. 

I played through the game twice, once in English and once in Russian, and I have to say Russian was really the way to go here. The English voice acting is not up to par and relies on what feels like amateur voice actors faking accents. ItтАЩs awful. One thing I would like to see would be an тАЬImmersiveтАЭ voice acting option. Basically, there are German soldiers in the game. If I pick Russian voice acting, they all speak Russian. If I pick German voice acting, then all the Russians speak German. Would be nice to have Germans speak German when you understand German, you know? 

All in all, I really enjoyed my time with the game and recommend at least giving it a shot even if you didnтАЩt like [B]Metro 2033[/B].

The quality significantly dropped in comparison to the first game. The DLC missions are worse. This game at times desperately tried to pretend to be COD or some fast pace FPS shooter despite none of the games' mechanics make that enjoyable. Quite the contrary every single mechanic in this game tell you not to get into a gunfight out in the open, however the game itself FORCES you to do so in multiple missions. Its almost like whoever made this game has a mind of a 3yo and simply stole the IP to do make their own fanfic game.

Story: Complete garbage.
1.) Abrupt and meaningless romance - meaningless in the sense that NOTHING happened/changed besides a implicated sex scene. IT has no proper development and did not provide any personal growth.
2.) You earn "good boy points" by not killing people who uses biological warfare, and they DID NOT show an ounce of remorse to justify it. You basically let war criminals go free and the game consider this the moral option.
3.) Khan the fucking xenophile. [spoiler]The only reason why he is right is because the game made it so. None of his decision or what he spoke were actually rational. You killed the dark ones because you believe that they also wanted to cause harm on you. They had driven your people crazy as the metro people were struggling to fight off the mutants. The dark ones themselves also wanted to kill you when you were trying to shoot the missiles at them. There was no genuine way to actually communicate with them and therefore the rational decisions were to destroy them. Seek forgiveness my ass. I don't see them apologising for the people they terrorised and I don't see them helping anyone in the first game. Khan is an impulsive hippy that does whatever he wants and the reason why the rangers did not rightfully shoot him or kick him out was because of plot armour. In fact Khan is the embodiment of the plot itself, and everything that is shit about the story.[/spoiler]
4.) One particular scene: [spoiler] Your "love interest" is kidnapped and you have gone to save her. You are confronting the kidnapper, and the kidnapper is holding a knife against the girl's throat. The game let you aim, so you pull out your sniper rifle and aim at the kidnapper's head at almost point blank range. You fire, and the kidnapper is completely fine. He pushes the girl towards you, and your gas mask cracked. I don't understand why they idn't just make this a cutscene considering how stupid the scene was. You are supposed to surrender to the kidnapper so they just forced the scene upon you so that they can go back to their linear story-telling. 

Gameplay: Everything bad in the first game + abhorrent "boss fights" 
1.) Despite the environment being extremely blend, boring and colourless, the devs did not put sound queue prior to enemy attacks. Theres only nosalis hows prior to a wave of attack (no clear sound when they actually attack) and in the swamp sections theres almost always enemy noises that does not amount to anything. In case anyone wants to argue that this is realistic, I recommend you to stop playing this game for 2 weeks each time you get attack, and delete your save whenever you died instead of reloading. You do not excuse poor design as realism. 
2.) There is only 2 new enemy types in this game iirc. It's a bit disappointing but not a huge problem.
3.) Guns are fine.
4.) Boss fights/final fights are the worst part of this game. The entire theme of this game is mostly stealth, avoid confrontations and fight only when you have to. Instead you are forced to fight bosses or large groups of enemies in the open. Worse yet, your rifle is equipped with IR scope so you cant see shit when theres fire and explosion everywhere. These fights are fundamentally against the core gameplay this game was designed around. 

You run around in a small arena to have a bullet diarrhoea on the monster - why? Then, another "boss" fight had you getting pinned down by 6-8 snipers - why? Later in the aforementioned sniper fight, you have to fight your way up a staircase - just kidding, by that I mean you have to shoot a immortal enemy until he backs down - he is almost guaranteed to land his shot on you every time he peeks, and thats also the only time you can shoot him, and you have to force him to back down three times. In the final fight, you have to fight off waves of enemies WITH GUN in an OPEN battlefield with less cover than your bulllshit skimpy female armour in RPGs - WHY? And then you fight a fucking "tank" by firstly shooting its rail, then the wheels and finally its ammunition storage - but only in that order, because obviously the exposed ammunition will be invincible unless you destroy the tank's rail and wheel first, and there is no other way to damage a tank, its not like molotov or incendiary grenades exist.

DLC mission: heavy squad - even more unplayable than the last fight - more open battle, no cover and constant bombardment by the enemy so that your screen always shakes. IT DOES NOT WORK.

COULD have been a good game...better than the original...but it was ruined by developer's insistence in making the game so difficult to the point that the average user can not finish it....EVEN AT THE NORMAL (EASIEST) level. One of the primary problems is there are no MANUAL SAVES and the autosave feature will too often trap you in an indefensible position and you have to start all over. PATHETIC. I hope the next Metro game is much, much better than this one...and includes MANUAL SAVES.

Unlike with Metro 2033 Redux, this was a slog to finish for me. As a shooter it works decently, though the game tries to make you play stealth as much as possible, which takes away the most fun part of the game (that's because it's evil to kill nazis and communists, they are all just trying to feed their families... having a lap dance also counts to bad karma for some reason). While Metro 2033 had a thin plot, it did the job and wasn't distracting from all the fun the game provided thanks to original setting and... well, shooting.
Unfortunately the sequel is more ambitious and tries to tell a story... it's just a really bad one. I don't even want to go on a rant on how bad the plot is; worst of all is the little dark child and his catastrophically bad monologues which are even worse than the unbelievably dull diary entries. Reminds me of all the bad soviet-era young-adult sci-fi I had to endure as a child - it was always the same never-ending moralising with every point repeated 150 times with terrible prose and voice over.
Favorite Metro Game by far. 10/10

Terrible, contrived and godawful moral system that ensures that unless you are an utter saint, who enjoys plucking fiddles and sparing rapists and murders, the next metro game doesn't exist according to their ending. To give a short version of the major judgement: The difficulty of the game on the lowest setting brings a challenge to bear which is far greater than the "good" ending is worth. Alongside their invalidating the effort of the player in 2033, I really don't think they have the right to tell me anything about how I interact with a fictional universe that isn't even theirs, nor do they get to pass judgement on my actions.
Basically, don't do their challenge. Just enjoy the game and the universe as it was meant to be, a brutal and savage post apocalyptic survival shooter. Read the books if you want the story, but don't listen to the dev's contrived and hidden black and white bullshit. Sparing murderers and rapists is not a good thing. Killing isn't always the best solution, but in a world literally incapable of keeping cannibals, rapists, and serial killers locked up and in check it becomes necessary. It is the duty of the strong to protect the weak, not control them. To allow elements to continue to exist which believes it is their duty to enforce their will and control those unable to fight for themselves yields suffering in numbers far too great to immediately comprehend. Revolutions, a revolving circle of suffering and death. Injustices repaid and repeated over countless cycles.

TL;DR: The devs tried to be philosophers, and failed either by enforcing disconnected utopic ideals, or because they're shit at game design. Just enjoy the game, and learn to be better by actual introspective thought. Grab a book to help, if you need to, but not this game. Honestly, it's not even as thought provoking as the first.

Great game, good atmosphere.Beating it on survival ranger hardcore was an immersive expirience my only gripe is that the quick-time events have their promts disabled, this change while in theory makes it more immersive in practice you just spam E (and maybe space) and wait for it to resolve.Also the choices of killing/sparing are E/V but they are not written on the screen(and of course are not in the settings) so it completely breaks the imersion there. Also scripted enemies can be bullet sponges and also somewhat take you out of the immersion since every bullet matters and you can waste a lot of bullets you don't need to on hitting them in a certain phase(or at all).Basicaly the combat itself and mechanics are great for the max difficulty but all the scripted stuff breaks it so be warned, the playing lower difficulties and non ranger mode you probably won't even notice these things.

What follows is not a review of playing the game. It's a summary of what I did to try and start playing the game.
I had played Metro 2033 Redux before and long story short, even years after release it's basically an early access game. It was ridden with technical difficulties that hampered my experience. I was stupid enough however to buy both games together so here I am again. I was warned this time though and expecting problems so here I went.
The game did not start in full screen, in stead taking up a corner of the screen but with no borders. I looks for the fullscreen setting but there was no such thing. Changed the video settings to my liking and restarted. This time it booted up in fullscreen for some reason.
Now, my computer is high level enough that it should be able to play this game in 4K resolution on the highest settings and still get more then 60fps... But even the main menu was unusable at 4K. 2K wasn't much better. Had to lower to 1080p for even the main menu to work. Finally booted up the campaign and no visible tearing or stuttering.
However, I play with a controller and movement was slow but looking around with the right stick was unbearably slow. I go to the settings and there's two options: "Aim sensitivity" and "sensitivity". Right stick is for aiming so I put that on maximum. No change noticable. Then I put sensitivity to maximum and that helps but it's still slow. On top of that, looking up and down is slightly slower then right or left.
I try to live with it for a bit longer as I just want to do something at this point. I have to go to the settings menu once again though because since I'm over 30 I have to put the volume of voices up and the rest down in every game. It's normally the first thing I do. So I go to audio settings and... Metro might be the first game I've ever seen that does not have a setting for voice volume. Neither is there one for background sounds. Only master and music volume sliders...
I give up.

This game is amazing. I've never played another post apocalyptic game that really takes me there like the metro games to. The atmosphere is fantastic, every location is unique, the characters are well written, and you never feel more than a wrong turn away from death.

For a linear, story-driven game, it does a amazing job of making you feel exposed and at-risk the whole time.

I have one large complaint, and it is the same as my complaint with the first game, and that is the ending (no spoilers).

Like the first game, there are two endings, a "good" (secret) ending and a "bad" ending. You are very unlikely to see the good ending unless you pull it up on youtube, because there is a litany of things you have to do during the playthrough to get it. Even knowing about this mechanic ahead of time and adjusting my play-style throughout the whole game I was unable to achieve the good ending and I have no idea why. There is no indication during the game as to what ending you are going to get until the end.

So my assumption is that unless you follow a step-by-step guide you are unlikely to get the good ending, which is frustrating, because the bad ending is pretty bad. They should have scrapped the standard ending and just kept the secret ending as the default.

On top of that, you don't actually get the full dtory unless you watch BOTH endings, so even if you DO get the good ending you should go to YouTube to see what you missed.

Metro: Last Light is a little more character-driven and storied, and the characters and interactions you encounter in the game flesh out the world in ways that weren't as apparent in 2033. Gameplay, soundtrack, visuals and graphics, all still as great as they were before, and I would highly recommend Last Light to anyone who loved 2033 enough to want more of the same.

Good game, although not as good as Metro 2033; this one focuses more on human politicking and intrigue, but there is still a huge amount of parts where you are either alone or facing horrors that haunt you.

It has a better environmental design IMO than 2033, especially in regards to the cities of the Metro like Venice, and it really gives you the feel of how humanity had to adapt their surroundings and live with what they got.

However some levels are very long with a bunch of unnecessary exploring and too many enemies, and the story is not so engaging as the first game, as this is mostly a redemption story about the canon choice made by the protagonist in the first game.

There are still many cool levels though, of human X human fights, and the soundtrack in some parts its pretty good.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]тАв Great story[/b]
[b]тАв Great atmosphere[/b]
[b]тАв Great graphics[/b]
[b]тАв Great soundtracks[/b]

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
[b]тАв AI - Not the best out there, but not bad either.[/b]
[b]тАв Difficulty - Even though I've played on Ranger Hardcore, I always had 10+ min filters. Also, some levels are harder, but the others are way easier. [/b]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]тАв Talk Artyom, talk![/b]
[b]тАв Some graphical glitches[/b]
[b]тАв Had some crashes while loading to an older checkpoint[/b]

Even with those cons, this game is a gold.

The Rhino boss fight is completely bugged and broken, all the pillars and obstacles in both of arenas were destroyed, but the Rhino just remained invincible, 5 claymores, 15 incendiaries, throwing knives, 300+ rifle rounds, 45 military grade rounds, 100+ shotgun shells, 75 pistols rounds, and even countless stabbing, and they were all effortless, hack even the nosalis respawned somehow........... And ofc I also already tried to verify the files and reinstall, but still the same, this is actually a good game, but the bug is unacceptable and hinder me from finish it.

Wander through horrifically deadly places, being told by AI co-op partners where to look to see the next scripted enemy encounter. Forced cutscenes when opening doors or climbing through gaps in rubble put you in plot situations you would easily escape otherwise. Get occasionally betrayed but improbably escape. Rinse, repeat. The Metro game loop is predictable but fun.

Oh, and it sometimes crashes to desktop. Disabling Advanced PhysX in the options helped with that.

Just completed the trilogy.  I enjoy starting a game series from the beginning (though at times if the game is really old that can be challenging) - not the case here,  all three games played well on my system with just some minor hiccups but nothing that prevented me from wanting to continue.  Enjoyed all aspects of the games from graphics to game mechanics and felt the story is well scripted.  AT this point I would advise grabbing it on sale but experience is well worth grabbing the games.

Metro: Last Light Redux starts a little while after the first game ends, so it's essential to play them in order. Mechanically the game is identical to the first, but with a bigger budget. As before, you're mostly going to be guided by NPCs through corridors while following on a linear story. The story is a string of unfortunate and extremely unlikely events that culminate in a great final showdown. The cutscenes are generally a lot more interesting and have more action in them. Overall it was a really good, memorable experience (both games together) and had a proper ending. Still don't know who the Dark Ones are. Still a bit buggy.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Much better action cutscenes
- Still great voice acting
- Has a rather clever unintrusive way of guiding you if you get lost. Your lighter flame waves in the direction of your objective
- The game starts out fighting Nazis, which is way more interesting mechanically than monsters that just charge straight at you
- I found all the factions living in the underground pretty interesting
- I think all the guns were basically the same as the first game, maybe with the addition of a couple of sniper rifles (which you don't really have a chance to use

[b]Cons[/b]
- It still never explains who the Dark Ones are
- Given that these are based on books, I feel like quite a lot must have been lost in the translation to video game. There are sections that I just didn't understand, and points where the plot suddenly changed and I didn't really understand why
- Scripted events are still buggy
- There's a key cutscene about 2/3 of the way through the game that suddenly changes the whole plot. But because there are no words, I found it pretty confusing
- It's exactly the same engine, so all the same pitfalls as the first game in terms of mechanics and UI
- I found it difficult to work out what was going on in terms of story telling, no thanks to the main character being mute and the game taking a rather weird turn in the last couple of hours
- Awful section with a tank at the end of the game. You're getting shot at from every direction, and you're supposed to just magically know that you have to use a sniper rifle to shoot a wheel bar, then two wheels, THEN then turret on top. Oh and not every sniper rifle will do; even after Googling it, I died and reloaded twice more because I was using the 'wrong sniper rifle'

Good step up from the original, another enjoyable campaign. Personally not a fan of games that only give you different endings based on choice where some of the "choice" isn't obvious. Meaning you don't know shooting the crane guy or the surrendering Nazi was a bad thing till afterwards and you get the bad sound effect. Some people love the complexity but honestly I just want to get into a story and enjoy it vs trying to make sure I have a story I enjoy by examining every possible thing I do as a morale or imorale act that will get me a "good" ending. I enjoyed the variety of weapons but again would have liked an addtional weapon slot to have 1 sidearm, 1 assault stlye weapon, 1 shotgun, 1 percison weapon. Idk why the semi auto pistol has to use the same ammo as the revolver as it makes it come down to either high damage or high fire rate. between those two and a the astov you could have a loadout well suited to both surface and tunnels if you wanted the challenge of pistol class only. The valve is by far my favorite though the 4x scope is highly useless both in the tunnels and on the surface irons worked just fine for me and theres a red dot if you need something more percise. over all a good game just didnt like the karma choices 24/7 to effect how the game ended.

Experience of a lifetime. 2.0

Pros (8-10/10): There are no direct spoilers, but there are concepts revealed in review. Such as enemies, weapons, the environment of the story (i.e. atmosphere and setting), etc.

Amazing storyline - actually one of the games I'm not questioning the plot, it all flows very nicely from the previous Metro game. The story also fills in plotholes you'd have if you never played the other Metro games. I'd give it a 9/10. 

Awesome weapon concepts - Customization of weapons in this game is very cool and not like MOST of its contemporaries. You  have a sight attachment, a barrel attachment and can put all other attachments on in the 3rd section (I forgot what it's called) and having that many attachments is weird, unique and cool at the same time. It's like something you'd see in a Call of Duty campaign, but the multiplayer [Of Call of Duty] would lack it. I'd give this an 8/10, only somewhat innovative.

Unique enemies - These enemies are either strong as hell and insanely hard to kill, very strong but their weakness kills them, or weak and strong in numbers. They have unique concepts and are even differing from the other Metro games. I played the previous one and recognized 0 of the the enemies. ex. One of the enemies has a weakness to light, so you can crank up your flashlight (like the intensity of the light) and burn it to submission and then shoot it once or twice. Due to the fact that the enemies are completely different (from what I remember) from the previous Metro game and are unlike nearly all enemies in this genre, I'd give this a 10/10. 

No real 6-7 qualities of this game.

Cons(5-1): Be wary there are spoilers here.

Expectability: This game has such a huge level of expectability, from the betrayl of the friend you make in the beginning to the obvious coming sex scene aforementioned. This isn't game shattering or anything, in fact most games play out this way so it's not really a new experience. This gets a 4/10.

Puzzles: Although some are fun, some are awful. Normally in games like Bioshock if you're having trouble there's that little cloud of dust that points you where to go. This game does not have that, and this leads to you being stuck in a room for 15 minutes suffocating w/o a gas mask because you can't figure out what the frick to do. This gets a 2/10 just because of the awful moments presented in the game.

OVERALL: There are more aspects I can touch on here, but for your sake and mine let's just end this here. This game is awesome, the cons are not even enough to kill the game. It's enough to get you pissed, but not enough to ruin the enjoyment as a whole. Honestly this game is cool as hell, and the bad spots are actually few and far between. This game gets an 85/100.

Last light is imo a bit worse than 2033. I played both back to back and 2033 stood out more. However I still think it is a phenomenal game, just ensure you play 2033 first.

The good:
- Great atmosphere, which is the primary reason why you should play metro games. The lighting, settings, sounds, music all adds up for a phenomenal experience
- The gunplay is very satisfying and well done, I say this after playing Ranger mode, so no idea what the normal mode is like
- The story is pretty well done imo and has good progression. I also like the core message of the game, all though I wouldn't go as far as forgive "certain people"
- The stealth sections are pretty cool (if the checkpoints dont fuck up)
- The music, it slaps.

Some complaints I have:
- The moral points system is still total trash, but this time you cant ignore it because the "good ending" is the canon ending. So if you want the real ending be ready to play the game with a guide. This took a lot of the enjoyment out of the game for me, so I suggest everyone who plays this to just go for the bad ending and not look at guides
- The crashes, I had to restart levels multiple times because the game kept crashing, very infuriating. I think I had 20-30 crashes in total and they definitely cost me a few hours
- Black screen bug, where the screen would randomly go black sometimes for no apparent reason
- Checkpoints, my god. Imagine you just having done a very long stealth section and then getting spotted just to get send back to the beginning of the level because IT WASNT A CHECKPOINT. Infuriating, this is why quick saves are a necessity in these kinda games.
- It feels less survival-esque than 2033, in 2033 I was constantly out of ammo despite playing on spartan, in this game I had like 300 MGRs at all times, which meant I literally could just spam my gun and not care basically, this also dampered the survival atmosphere of the game.

I came across this game only because it looked good, also because it was on discount. This game really make you think in ways you can get through a sequence, and every action really does affect the ending of the game. The first time I played it, I went guns blazing throughout the game and ended up with the bad ending, it was after I finish the game that discovered there was another ending aka the good ending which is the canon ending that leads you to the next game Metro Exodus. Overall I highly recommend this game to anyone that wants a FPS but with great story and ambient.

Amazing, well worth every penny! Action packed from the start to the finish. Gives a good message without any virtue signalllling bs. Gun play is excellent. There was one crash and the 'no stealth takedown option bug' began from the Bandits level. That was about it. There are additional missions in the chapter select menu as well (gotta press 'X' to access them).
The only negative was the lack of clear directions in some later levels Ex: The Garden. The level was dark and all the structures were of similar dull colours so it was kind of difficult to find the path to proceed, even with the compass on.
Overall a solid 8/10 :)

A significant improvement to its predecessor, Metro Last Light takes a step into the sci genre adding a breathe of fresh air to the story while still maintaining its strong emphasis on good level design and stealth based game play. The levels are still a series of carefully crafted set pieces but now with the addition of new enemy types as well as boss fights and a grand last stand. This is a finely crafted first person shooter, and a great instalment to the metro series. 
Once again though I do have to mention, this game does appear to cause launch issues for some windows 10 users, I was able to get mine working by repairing an old 2012 msvcp file but that's not a guarantee fix for everyone, so definitely check if your games runs asap.

Metro Last Light Redux and by extension Metro 2033 Redux are both phenomenal games that have:

- Great gameplay with a wide variety of enemies and locations
- Interesting, atmospheric level design that is extremely engaging
- Fantastic soundtracks
- Plenty of areas to explore that help make the linear design of the levels seem more open, alive and believable places that have been lived in
- Fun and engaging progression with more guns becoming available as you progress
- Military grade ammunition being your main currency as well as being usable ammunition, which in itself can create some quite tense and difficult decisions, particularly on the higher difficulty settings.

However, neither of these are completely flawless experiences:

- The morality system is by far my largest criticism of this game. It is ambiguous, bizarre and can sometimes appear to be downright asinine. Moral actions are all valued equally meaning that strumming a balalaika that's lying in the corner of your gaff will be considered as moral as saving a persons life. For some reason the game will also reward you with moral points in very strange and random places. Such as for perving in on two naked women cleaning themselves or following complete randos around listening to their conversations, or doing something as simple as just walking into a room or turning a corner. You could go through the whole game killing as many people as possible but still get the good ending because you strummed enough balalaika's and listened to enough pointless dialogue and found some secret areas. This in itself kind of makes the whole system look ridiculous. Not to mention the fact that the game seems to think sparing Communists, Nazis and Bandits who pose an imminent danger to those around them is a moral thing to do. The way this system should have been handled is that it should have only been applied to key moments and plot points that were more clear, consistent and engaging imo.
- Both stories for Metro 2033 and Last Light are serviceable and have their ups and downs, with some characters being weaker than others. Khan is an intriguing character present in both 2033 and Last Light, who's background is shrouded in mystery, leaving the audience to fill in the gaps with their own imagination, while having consistent motivations that makes sense. Anna on the other hand is a character that is introduced in Last Light and goes from hating the player's character at the beginning to falling in love with them when you meet her again halfway through the game with little indication as to why this complete switch in personality happened during your time apart.
-The AI can be a bit buggy and at times. In my experience only leading to a couple of frustrating situations with mutants one shotting you or an enemy seeing you through a wall or in a dark area but these moments are few and far between and kind of to be expected, overall the AI gets the job done and is pretty good on the whole.

Overall Metro Last Light and 2033 are both fun and engaging experiences that I highly recommend. The negative points are vastly outweighed by the positives but I still thought it was necessary to elaborate on my criticisms.

Great FPS game, but a little too linear. Having only played the first two games in this series, I highly recommend them for plot/story, but they come up short on gameplay and it constantly feels like you're playing a rail shooter in an arcade since exploration is at a minimum.

Worth buying on sale, but not for $20.

Metro Last Light is everything Metro 2033 is and better. 

The story is great, arguably better than the first game, with an intriguing villain that really caught me off guard and amazing set pieces. Level design in this game it top tier, with large amounts diversity to allow you to play the game you want. From claustrophobic tunnels to the rainy bright surface, this game visuals are breathtaking. The audio design is amazing, as you creep around corners hearing different mutated monsters screeching filling you with paranoia. Only complaint is Artym being a mute protagonist, why can't he talk in game if he talks in the loading screen. All in all, I can not recommend this game enough, it will keep you immersed for hours.

FYI: Do not waste your time with DLC, they are very hit or miss. I would just move on to Exodus in my opinion.
