This game is a superb sequel to a before great made game. The overhauled graphics are once again, the best, the story is very intriguing, and the characters are very well thought out, especially the little Dark One. Though I wasn't very happy with the first ending I got, so I will go through another playthrough of the game, try and go for the canonical ending this time, but very good game!

Overall, fantastic. I feel the preceding entry, Metro 2033, was much more atmospheric, while this one felt much more action oriented. The story is fast-paced, but immersive. The setting is still captivating and enchanting. Whereas in 2033 I felt like a single man struggling against the world, in Last Light I felt like a soldier, capable of taking on the horrors of the world.

The main flaw of Metro 2033 was, sadly for a shooter, shootouts - it seemed like you put bullets into robots: the enemies practically did not react to injuries and possessed a great cancellation, the behavior of the weapon was more reminiscent of pneumatics than of a firearm. In "Ray of Hope" shooting has become better: opponents writhe in agony, and when hit, as is now customary in similar games, a cross is displayed in the area of тАЛтАЛthe sight. But otherwise it is the same Metro 2033 with a little work on the errors.


The story continues the plot of the previous part, and the ending is chosen canon, bookish: people kill blacks with a missile strike and believe that the threat is over. But it soon turns out that one of the black cubs survived, and Melnik sends Artyom, who is again the main character, to complete what he started. He manages not only to fail the task, but also to be taken prisoner by the Nazis along with several Reds. If you, suddenly, do not know, Dmitry Glukhovsky, who this time wrote all the dialogues in the game, began working on the book Metro 2033 while still in school, so the local ideas about the Communists and Nazis do not quite correspond to reality, and the sides themselves are shown several caricature.

yes i recommend but it's not that great as the hype make it to be. Because it is a pretty standard linear science-fiction shooter. Because the story is not a new concept or an old concept with an interesting twist and because the gameplay is basic (although functional, but no story customization besides choosing your weapon). I had more fun with this one than with 2033 because i enjoyed the faster pace of this one more.

Play Metro 2033 Redux first for context. This series uses linear storytelling and level design so well, the story and levels are always engaging. You are moved from stealth gameplay, to exploration, to action set pieces so well and naturally. The game sells the brutality of its world so well and I felt like every mission was justified and not tacked on as you struggle to survive. The animation, environment art and game feel are amazing, even today. There is so much environmental detail and great vfx work that makes the combat always interesting. My favorite parts of the game were definitely the above ground segments where you are hunting around for ammo and collectibles while managing your air supply and wiping gunk of your mask. The stealth can feel clunky at times and I do wish there were better things to spend your money on but, this is a must play for fans of stealth games and FPS single player campaigns.

A solid 6.8/10. A fairly decent onrails story driven post apocalyptic shooter.

The Pros:
The gunplay is pretty good. The stealth is very enjoyable in this game, equip a silencer to your pistols and buckshooters, you can get really satisfying stealth gameplay outta this game. I highly recommend playing the game this way when facing human enemies. In addition, the redux edition runs really well and I only had one hard crash when tinkering with the settings.  Several on railed levels are great. The graphics at times still fairly well done by todays standards.

The Decent:
The story, its okay but nothing really good to shout about. The factions are very cliched, villians are one dimensional and nothing really diverts into more interesting side stories other than the main storyline. Gun customisation is also fairly decent. 

The Cons:
The pacing of the story, the game has a huge fetish of implementing fade to black to progress its story which is annoying as hell. The sound design for some weapons are aweful as well, for instance the reload sound of the "AK-47" sounds like a plastic toy. 

Conclusion:

Metro Last Light Redux is a decent story driven shooter, with several great segments presented in their levels. The stealth is a highlight of the game, as I really enjoy it very much. The pacing of the story could be better, constantly utilising fade to black to deliver their story and certain guns have some terrible  outdated sound designs.

I've played all the Metro games, and please, if you plan on playing them, get all three because they're all excellent in their own right.

I loved the open-world aspect of Exodus, and all of the locations were breathtaking and many were terrifying.

However, something about the level-based and more linear format of the earlier games, Last Light in particular, made it feel even more claustrophobic and terrifying than the most recent installment.

The atmosphere of this game and the first are something I will never forget, it was just such an amazing and enriching experience that introduced me to a completely new genre.

Metro Last Light is a sequel in the right track. The game still feels very amazing in 2021. The story, narration , and the atmosphere of this game are good or somewhat feel better than the original game Metro 2033.


Pro: Story, the lore, the world, the atmosphere
Cons: Still can get stuck/hard to move in some place, also I got annoying gameplay when the checkpoint bugged and pushed me to replay the chapter from the beginning.  Animation and model feel a little bit dated, but again redux version feel better now than the original version.  Oh also I really think the good ending is too hard to archive by first time player, and kinda well pushed too much into the ethic of the author / script writer but nevertheless I can say that I really enjoy the game.
Final Score: 4/5

You know how Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare came out and everyone was like "wow this is one of the greatest FPS games ever made" and then when Modern Warfare 2 came out everyone was like "WOW THIS IS SO MUCH BETTER HOLY CRAP"?This is NOT like that. You know how Bioshock came out and everyone was like, "oh wow this is one of the greatest games ever made", but then when Bioshock 2 came out everyone was like, "it's just more Bioshock"? This is EXACTLY like that.

Metro Last Light is just more Metro 2033. It's exactly the same gameplay. There's some new weapons [new, not better], there's some new characters [most of them are great], there's some new locations [none of them are terrible], and there's more of Artyom's story. It feels more like an expansion pack than a sequel. So if you love Metro 2033 Redux- I know I do- then it's fully worth playing this game too. If you haven't played Metro 2033 Redux yet, what the hell is wrong with you? GO PLAY IT NOW! And then play this.

This game is great but its original integrity does not hold up well on PC. Key mechanics of stealth are very broken. There is a well known (and still not fixed) glitch where the takedown mechanic for both kill and knockout stop working entirely, so if you don't want to kill someone in your way you either have to find another way around them or figure out how to fix the glitch. Add this to the fact the game likes to crash 2 or 3 times with a not so forgiving automatic checkpoint system and the annoyance piles up quick.

Stealth was even more broken past the takedown glitch for me personally. It was more than common for my throwing knives to go through people without killing them and for my throwing knives to go through lights without breaking them but since I can't find a single fix for this online I can only assume this is an isolated or very new issue.

Overall I recommend the game but not on PC unless you are either willing to deal with stealth issues or plan to just shoot your way through the game.

Right, now this game!

So, Last Light - being a sequel - had a lot to live up to.

Don't let my 2033 review fool you - I was really impressed by the stealth and I ADORED the story, characters and world building!

I expected top QUALITY shit, comrade! 

And did I GET that shit?

Ehh... yyyyyyes? 

I mean, I pick like a banjo player on an amphetamine binge - and I split hairs like a slicer in a rabbit factory :P but this game certainly contains PARTS that are better than 2033

For instance - the FINAL level - hot DAMN did I feel godly! Getting pushed farther and farther back - dying MULTIPLE times because I couldn't figure out what the fuck it was the game wanted me to do to stop that tank!

Yes, YES, game, I KNOW your tank is glowing red in some SPOTS, game - but sweet CHEEZITS - EVERYTHING is red right now!!!! Blood everywhere - fire - how was I supposed to SEE the glowing red bits from halfway across the FUCKING base?!?!?!

Ahem... 

The horror is still prevalent - as are the fucking spee-iders and jump scares - but they're paced a bit better and there's a lot more stealth levels this time. 

I think the game twigged on to the fact that it does stealth much better than it does run and gun FPS gameplay - which - I mean - come on - I have to change weapons or freeze time just to check how much ammo I have :P the UI is crap and not designed for anything BESIDES stealth. 

And the story? Oh my GOD the story - this - THIS - is why I'm glad I played these games before playing Exodus. The context of the last game made me so much more suspicious of certain characters and plots - and so much more invested. 

Plus, as I said in my other review, it's only 8 hours (ten or eleven if you're incompetent lol) and it fucking EARNS those hours just as much as this game's STORY does.

And the WORLD - oh - god - you could CHOKE on the fumes this game's world gives off! You could get fucking stoned on the radiant waft of the sweat this game's pits accumulated from building this world! Every corner - every niche - every cranny tells a story - a WORLD - and you just want to know it! You WANT to understand it! You want more!!!

Let me put it this way.

This game's story and world are SO engrossing that I want to stop the review RIGHT HERE... ... ... but, as I put on the cleats of punishment and prepare for some cruel kicks to the bollocks, gentle reader, brace yourself as I DON'T stop the review right here and get to the character's...

And, in some case, I mean FUCKING characters...

Let's start with the good - Khan - Miller - a new addition known as Pavel - and another certain 'newcommer' we'll call 'angel' for lack of a proper name :P - these character's are ALL deeply rounded and fascinating. Khan has lost so much - but he still looks at the world with BOUNDLESS curiosity and fascination. Miller is great and salty and amusing - as always - Pavel, the first stand out newcommer, is probably one of the most interesting character's I've encountered in a story-driven game like this. I know I'm SUPPOSED to end up hating him - but I came away liking him! And the REAL stand out - Khan's 'angel' - I really became attached to him over the course of his involvement with the story... ... ...

Alright, now, those of you who were paying attention, know I'm soothing the game's furrowed brow before I break out the fucking nail-covered spanking paddle and punish it for it's sins :P

Well, buckle up, and let's hope the game doesn't start getting off to it :P

I have two MAJOR character complaints (in addition to all the jump scares, spiders and a UI that looks like it was put together by a guy with his head in a paper sack) and they are named ANNA and LENITSKY.

We'll get the easy one first - Lenitsky is pointless. Not only does he steal the thunder of OTHER certain villains - but you won't even know who he is if you weren't paying attention when his name is mentioned during the first mission :P even worse, there are two times in the game where I wanted to absolutely WANTED to murder him - but I knew if I did - I'd be making a mistake. I didn't dare shoot him when I wasn't supposed to - or I'd get negative points AND I couldn't gut him like a fish for the same reason :P you built him up as this WORTHLESS piece of shit, game, I SHOULD be allowed to kill him!!!!

Now, on to the hard one.

Anna.

I HATED how she was handled.

This is probably my SJW showing or something - but they did her SO DIRTY in this game. You first meet her on your first mission - she's snotty - she's annoying - but has some amusing one liners so I was starting to warm to her... ... ... then the game fucking dumps her for the first half of the game!!!! I spent MORE TIME with PAVEL than I did with a woman the game ARBITRARILY decided was going to end up being my love interest! Even worse, at the half way point, when she shows back up, the game suddenly wakes up and realizes - SHIT!!!! WE'VE GIVEN THIS WOMAN, LIKE, NO CHARACTER!!!! QUICK!!! POINTLESS SEX SCENE!!!!

Because that's why I play games, folks, to put my knob in things :P You just can't understand a character if you haven't fucked it - right? 

Annoying, even AFTER the game seemed to realize that giving me a little side-boob and some pants-on-pants cuddling wasn't REALLY exposition or character-deepening gameplay; the game promptly seemed to FORGET that and dumped her AGAIN because she had a bruise on her shoulder!!! She's built up as this bad-ass sniper who's been hunting in the tunnels for almost two years and she get's taken out by a boo-boo?! 

The most hilarious 'Anna' moment was at the penultimate adventure where I'm about to go off to die and the game WRENCHES the control from me and shows me ANNA (who's been absent for the last three hours) on the debarkation terminal watching me leave!!! 

It's like the game was saying - this is your woman!!! YOU LOVE HER!!!!

The fuck are you talking about, Game? I wanna marry Pavel!!!! You actually gave HIM a personality... 

Or, at least you did, outside of the DLC missions...

God, those were embarrassing folks - amiright? Anna get's a five minute shooting gallery with virtually NO story - and Pavel, the standout from Last Light and my TRUE love, get's a series of closets where I stab some bitches and then get a cutscene with a fortune teller who wets herself... ... ... yet, somehow, out of ALL this, the last one I played, ended up blowing my mind.

Namely, the Khan mission - not only did it start with a character I did NOT expect - but it expanded on Khan's background and made me admire him in a way I hadn't expected! Plus, it had a giant radioactive monster BURNING a whole horde of rats :P what's not to like about that?

Shame they couldn't have put some of that time or budget into making my love interest something besides a pair of badly animated tits but - hey - I'm probably just being needlessly mean :P 

-sigh-

Don't let my incessant birdlike warbling turn you off this game - as you can see my thumb IS still resoundingly upwardly mobile. It's just - characters like Anna and Lenitsky (who are practically cardboard cutouts from the stock writers club) stick out so massively because the OTHER character's around them are so fascinating and deep - the story is so good - that they automatically DETRACT from any scene they're in. I have to pay credit, again, to the redux that was done with this game.

Gorgeously hideous doesn't do it justice - the textures, colors and lighting REALLY pops and even the soundwork seems much improved. The graphics LOOK almost as good as something you'd see nowadays and the world REALLY breathes. 

Ten out of ten - would suffer needlessly from jumpscares, shelob mutha fuckas and badly written character archetypes again!

While I enjoy the 3 Metro games in existence at time of writing, Last Light has remained my favourite since I first played it. Where 2033 was the originator that had notable flaws sprinkled throughout an original premise, and Exodus flirts with open world esq game play in a few hubs, Last Light seems to have taken on a middle path between the two in a few ways. While back before Exodus, Last Light seemed to be the more open exploration brother to the very linear first game, after the fact it has really highlighted what a balancing act Last Light was accomplishing. The story is tightly wound, the characters are fantastic, the world is wonderfully grim and simultaneously beautiful, and they continue the philosophical bent Artyom began in 2033 in new and emotionally intelligent ways as he goes on a kind of redemption quest. If you're a fan of games with a heavy focus on immersion and a palpable atmosphere, you could be hard pressed to find much better.

Solid second entry into the series, took all the things you knew and loved from 2033 and improved it.

Things I liked:

Story - Story was cool, liked how there were multiple endings.
World building - NPCs talked to each other from events in the last game, you learn a little more about some of the main characters from 2033 too.
Combat/Stealth - Aside from setpieces, it is entirely possible to play this entire game with stealth or, blast your way through the entire game

Graphics- Game is hella pretty, played through and didnt experience any bugs or glitches save dead enemy clipping into a surface once in a while. If you play on the harder difficulties with limited hud youll really get to take in the game. 

DLC - DLCs add a lot to the game, probably another 3-4 hours.

Things I didnt like:

Difficulty - The only thing separating difficulty is you have less health and there's less ammo, forcing you to do a stealth play through. There's no HUD on higher difficulties but you can still get all your inventory info by holding up the map screen. Enemy AI doesn't change. Further, you can run past most of the nonhuman enemies without sustaining damage, and enemies will eventually hit a wall where they cant follow you anymore.

Flinch - Your character has a fuckin seizure if you're hit, kind of annoying.

Last Light is just as immersive, well structured, and carefully thought out as 2033, but with even better graphics, more expansive content, and a far more intense feel. What it lacks over 2033 in pacing, it makes up for in sheer quantity of gameplay and overall tension throughout its campaign. The punishment for not being a thoughtful and careful player leaves you hanging by a thread and provides incredible relief when you wrap up ArtyomтАЩs story.

Despite this game being an overall improvement on 2033 in many ways, it does drag on slightly in certain segments near the end of the game, which does enforce the feeling of futility, but can also become exhausting if you play in long sessions. Like 2033, desperation becomes your default state of mind as you progress deep into this game. Slowly but surely, the game demands mastery over your skills, rather than dependence on your equipment. It will keep you on your toes.

At one point in this game, I experienced what I thought was a campaign-ending moment but was able to pull through it on Ranger Hardcore. At first, I found it frustrating. But I hope every player experiences the triumph that comes with beating impossible odds on an already impossibly difficult game experience like Last Light. The game does an excellent job of upping the ante and making you work for your victories, which are far more rewarding than even 2033s.

A strong reminder that linear games still hold up. Worth every penny.

The story continues, and it's generally a satisfying sequel. It has an expanded variety of locales over the first game and improved pacing, but its more complex plot can't quite rise above the very linear storytelling. Though there are lots of characters here, it's hard to care about any of them. As in the first game, there are two endings, but this time you will need to follow a guide to get the "good" one, because there are various things you need to do in your playthrough. That's kinda annoying for completionists.

Unfortunately, [I]Dark Light[/I] also inherits all the flaws of [I]2033[/I], as the gameplay and design are essentially the same. Once again, exploration is often punished, such as when you open a door and move to the next level even if you didn't want to. Tough luck, this is a one-way ride. Again, characters talk over each other and it's impossible to pay attention. And finally, voice acting continues to be horrendous, with the same bizarre decision that everyone use Russian-ish accents even though they speak English. Actually, here this poorly conceived principle is taken to truly absurd extremes (spoiler: [SPOILER]even the aliens have this cringey accent![/SPOILER]).

Apparently some gamers enjoyed the bits of gratuitous sex in the first game, because here it's just all over the place, in all its plasticky, uncanny-valley weirdness. Speaking of which, children are still freakishly rendered and voiced.

In conclusion: if you enjoyed the first game then you'll get more of the same here. Sometimes too much of the same. It's not a new experience, just ... more of it.

I'll be direct here, Last Light isn't up to par with 2033, but even then it has something very special. It's what intrigued me the most to start a second playthrough.  

You see, 2033 was a horror game, assuming one has played on Ranger Hardcore for the full experience of Metro. But Last Light is a more action oriented game, consisting of a few very disturbing and chilling moments as opposed to Metro 2033. Despite that, the game rewards you for being magnanimus. Few action games do that, and that's what sets this apart.  

Narrative wise, it's fine. Plot is mostly generic but not bad. Writing is good. 

It's still a good game, just not as good as 2033.

P. S. Wish they could fix the stutters. I get 100+ fps at high settings on 1600x900, but the random freezing was very annoying.

"My mother told me I'd grow up to be a good man. 'Artyom', she said. 'My light'. And I believed her. When I spared a life, I believed her. And then when I kill, believed her. It was a lie. These things I have done. My hands are blackened with blood. My soul is damned to purgatory. If I could have my time again, I would, and then maybe I could become a good man."

I'm sorry, but the conditions you have to go through to get the canonical ending are just way too specific and the game never even hints at you that you should be following them. 99.9% of players who didn't read guides upfront will get the bad ending, which will make the next game in the series impossible, which of course is pretty fitting seeing as Metro Exodus was an Epic Exclusive and therefore not canon for most of the playerbase for a year of its exclusivity, which is another reason why this game deserves a negative rating, but far from the main one. Apart from the ending, there's too many random bugs, which will force you to reload a save, there are too many NPCs that will be the slowest walking NPCs I've ever seen and you'll spend a large part of the game waiting for them by the door, because you are literally 10 times faster than them and they're the only ones who can open those doors. There's also a section at the end where you have to destroy a large enemy and the game never tells you that you have to pick up a special gun to be able to destroy its parts and that is just some terrible game design and it's far from the only examples that I could come up with, but I'm done caring about this game.

The story is fine, the gunplay is fun, the technical side is great including a flawless 32:9 support and constant 120FPS on 3080 ~4K, but the sour taste in my mouth at the end with some of the other issues is just not enough for me to recommend this game. And I did like the first one, so I hope the third one is better.

The original version of Metro: Last Light featured a multitude of mechanical and quality of life improvements over its predecessor.  With the Redux versions, this is kind of lost to history, though an interesting bit of knowledge of the franchise.  

Metro: Last Light is much easier than Metro: 2033, even on Ranger Hardcore, the authentic Metro experience.  Bugs are limited or absent altogether in a playthrough, which is lovely.  

Characters, creatures, mini bosses and environments are all very well done in Last Light.  This is most apparent in the characters.  Characters are no longer introduced simply to die, they have more dialogue and the original voice work was definitely an improvement when Last Light first released.  

I've said it before and I cannot stress it enough.  Ranger Hardcore provides an incredible challenge and immersion that is unmatched in any other game of its genre.  (Yes, even you, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.)

I would not call Last Light a must-play like I would Metro: 2033, though I still recommend picking up the whole franchise and giving it at least one Ranger Hardcore attempt.
Loved this game. I am not the best at shooters mind you, but I didnt have difficulty playing this.

There's nothing groundbreaking in terms of gameplay or with the story, but it's a wonderful ride through the tunnels and radiated surface of a post-apocalyptic Moscow.

The game picks up a year after the events of the first game, assuming you got the bad ending that most players got, plunging missiles onto the mysterious alien looking dark ones. There's reports of a surviving dark one spotted, and you, Artyom, are ordered to make contact with it and kill it. This encounter ends with Artyom and the dark one being taken by Metro Nazis! So the wild ride begins. 

Last Light encourages stealth from the getgo, and the level design shows a lot more opportunities in being sneaky sneaky with lots of hidden passages to mouse around enemies. This takes away a lot of the blandness of the shooting mechanics as I found 2033 feeling a lot like a Call of Duty clone, damaging the immersion. This also gets around chewing through ammo which was pretty scarce in 2033 but here I believe it is a lot more plentiful even if you do go loud all the time.

There is a key mechanic that was never explained in 2033 and continues into Last Light. You get morality points from doing certain actions, like simply listening to an old farts story at a station or there negative ones like shooting someone in the face (these opportunities don't come up much for morality choices). These morality points are blindly banked and determine what ending you are going to get. This feels like a brute force method to get players to immerse themselves into the game.

Everything is told in first person, and everyone seems to warm to Artyom, even though he is silent. He speaks a brief monologue during the loading screens for each level, but I really don't understand why the team decided to keep him quiet during gameplay, as characters will speak to him and ask him things and even register that he is giving them the silent treatment. Yet everyone still seems to love Artyom. Many familiar faces of the first game return and some new, the best being the personable Pavel. You spend a lot of levels with him, he openly talks about his life and unlike the other characters, the actor really puts some bloody life into him. Which brings me onto the strange world of Metro. It is stuffed with bald men clad with military equipment. In the Metro stations I would say they are filled with 90% bald army men, 5% women, 5% children. It's very strange and takes away another level of immersion leaving a sausage festival environment. The game is also incredibly linear, which many have complained about. I feel the linear design only feels awful when you go through the metro stations. These moments you are told you have some time to wander, but there isn't really any wandering. You trigger NPC conversations as you walk through the station towards your exit to the next level, which all feels a bit flat.

But with all these little issues, I loved the game, it's a wild rollercoaster through the world of Metro. The time in the tunnels is greatly reduced, there is a lot more time on the surface (which looks awesome). I could only predict story points in the game, but I couldn't predict the levels around them. Escape a concentration camp, enjoy a cabaret show, trawl through a radioactive swamp whilst trying not to get eaten, drive a railcar! The first person perspective showing Artyom crawling through the vents, heaving the hatches open to the surface, these little touches immerse you into the environment of the ever changing levels. It felt like a very fun adventure film and, to me, that's a good game.

Metro: Last Light Redux takes a lot of what made Metro: 2033 Redux such an enjoyable game and puts that to the forefront with improved stealth, pacing, and significantly less hand holding. Just like the first Metro, world building and story is put at the forefront and while the storytelling can be a little lopsided and confusing at times, the broad strokes narrative is really compelling and I especially loved how insanely high the stakes were just like the first game. The presentation is also stellar and I love how lived in and detailed the world of the Metro that is further emphasized on with the amount of resource management that makes every bullet feel like it matters. If you liked the first Metro game a lot like I did, this is a definite must play and it is a super solid sequel.

It's amazing, even after all these years. 
In comparison to Metro 2033's Ranger Hardcore, it's been bumped up to something for sure.
The mutants are a pain to deal with now, since assault rifles don't deal good damage to them.
Revolvers work fine on them as long as you hit a headshot, but the shotguns are something completely
different. One shot up close is all it takes to put a mutant down.

I like how you have to use different weapons for different situations, but I don't like how you can't mix it up sometimes. Sure, you can shoot a mutant with  rifles and all but it won't be as effective as the shotguns unless you're using military grade ammo. In other words, being forced to use weapons to kill something more quicker doesn't feel nice, at least for me.

Other than that the game is nice, so is the story too.

Metro: Last Light was my first foray into this franchise and years later it still holds up wonderfully well. In terms of gameplay, nothing has changed much since the previous game; Matter of fact, much of what I had to say about Metro 2033 Redux can also be applied here, and that's not a bad thing by any means. Metro has always been about its fantastic storytelling and incredible ability to immerse the player into its story, and Metro: Last Light is no exception. But between the two games, I would have to say that LL is the stronger one. I just love the way the story was written here, and it's definitely my favorite out of the two. In short, if you liked the last one, then you will absolutely love Metro: Last Light Redux. Even seven years later, it's still one of the best in the genre.

[h1]A worthy Successor [/h1]

   Metro Last Light was a worthy successor to the original Metro 2033. It is objectively a better video game than the original in almost every metric, however some of the changes from the original are in my opinion detrminetal to the unique experience that Metro 2033 brought to the table.

[b] Story [/b]
 
   Last Light follows the events from the previous game very closely. The events of 2033 create a foundation to which the story builds itself from. Similar to the previous game the story has two distinctive endings based on the player's choices and actions, however different from the previous game, some of the choices you make are more subtle, and a unaware player might even miss them in the heat of the moment. While others are far more explicit. All of this is good, it feels natural, and not gamey.

 There is however on aspect of the story that definitely feels off. And that is some of the characters. While some characters are very well fleshed out, others that appear to have quite an impact in the story for the protagonist are completely neglected. One of them is no doubt Anna. Her development through the story is missing so much context that makes the player be confused about the status of her relationship with Artyom. The developers simply didn't spend enough time developing her character for this game and it shows. In Metro Exodus she's a much better character, but here, she's just worthless.

[b] Gameplay [/b]

   Metro Last Light uses a very similar gameplay style to that of the original,  a Heavily scripted story Driven First Person shooter horror game. It is very linear, but you have plenty of room to explore for ammo and filters, as well as room to be exposed to the nightmare that surrounds the city, as well as the entire Metro of Moscow. 
  Last Light was the game that introduced its stealth system to the franchise, the same stealth mechanics that are still present in Exodus. I don't like that stealth system, because in my opinion it reduces the challenge of the game significantly, but that is very subjective. What i'll say is that the system is very functional, however a player needs to be careful about relying on it too much, Last Light will ocasionally force the player into combat situations, and if you are been relying on the stealth too much to the point where you don't have a weapon that can do long range and short range engagement with humans, you will struggle a lot. Overall the gameplay of Metro Last Light is a lot of fun, it can be quite challenging and exciting so that's good in my books.

[b] Graphics [/b]

  Metro Last Light continues its predecessor excellent attention to details. The game looks stunning even to this day, It looks great, the character models, the texture quality, i really can't complain about it, the game looks great.

[b] Performance [/b]

To deal with the great graphics of the game, Last Light also offers excellent performance. The game runs great, a lot better than the original Metro 2033 did, it is very well optmized. I have a pretty good pc this days, but even when i had a more budget computer with a budget graphics card, i was still able to play this game fairly well, and the game still looked good while doing it.

[b] bugs [/b]

  In the Redux version of Last Light i didn't encounter many bugs, most of the issues i encountered were relatively minor graphical glitches. i did encounter a bigger graphical glitch at one point but the fix was just repairing the game so i can't complain about that. So when it comes to bugs, i can't complain the game is very well polished in that regard.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

  Metro Last Light was a great game to continue this fantastic franchise, and though in my opinion the original game was better in a lot of ways, Metro Last Light continues to be a great game and definitely a must have for anybody that enjoyed the first game, as well anybody that was introduced to this franchise by the latest Metro Exodus.

Great story and great gameplay. It's a good mix of action and stealth. Graphics are awesome.

On survivor difficulty, the majority of the game difficulty is just right. However, certain challenges of the game are extremely difficult. They are more of the "trial and error" variety. You'll die a bunch of times until you figure out what is the best course of action. For me, it can dampen the immersion level. Furthermore, the performance of the game could be better. At random times you'll crash to desktop. Frame rate can be a little wonky sometimes. And this kind of performance occurs with a quality rig, not just a sub-par one. However, the story is awesome, the characters meaningful. And there is plenty of player agency. From little mechanics to more complex ones, you feel like you're part of the world around you. You can tell the game was a labor of love. It just didn't age the best performance wise. But overall that shouldn't ruin your experience too much.

A great sequel to Metro 2033. In this one, you are hot on the heels of the last remaining Dark One, following the canon ending of the previous game in which you launched the missiles at the Dark Ones' home. As usual, you will be accompanied by several characters and fight bandits, commies, Nazis, miscellaneous mutants etc. Truth be told, despite a variety of improvements (to weapon handling, more weapons, some more variety in enemies) it's basically the same game, and that's not a bad thing if you enjoyed the first one.

The DLCs allow you to explore a variety of missions - you can let loose against a flood of Reds as a Nazi heavy weapons trooper, stealthily infiltrate a Nazi base as a Red sniper, and play missions revealing more of the characters you played alongside in the main campaign (Anna, Pavel, Khan and Uhlman). My favourite mission is one where you play a Polis stalker exploring the Great Library from Metro 2033. You start out with limited supplies and have to scavenge for money and artifacts on the surface in order to get better gear to explore further in the library. Not all the DLCs hit the mark (in particular, the Developer and Tower missions feel a little flat) but there's plenty here to complement the base game.

As with the prequel, I recommend this. You'll have to make a second playthrough like the first in order to get all the achievements, but thankfully the game goes by pretty quick if you know where to go and what to do. Some cutscenes are even skippable! Definitely try this out.

Metro may not have a variety of creatures and weapons like we'd expect in a game like this, but its story and semi-tactical approach (when dealing with the human NPCs) makes up for the seeming limited scope in player choice. The story hooks you in for one wild ride, providing plenty of apocalyptic and paranormal intrique, with just the right amount of horror.

What I don't like about it? There is no real variety of gear and creatures. There seems to be only 10 weapons, with even fewer available ways to modify. weapons. While the devs have done a fantastic job at at creating such an apocalyptic world, they put more work into the NPC crowds you cant really interact with at each station you encounter, then they do with the ones you do. 

The Mutant Watchmen (the rodent/dog like ones) are overall the same, with the same soundset applied to each one. They are all the same color and size. What I think they could have done better is make them various in size, the bigger they are the slower they are and the harder they are to kill, but also the less places they'll be able to follow you into. Sound could have been done where size determined their tonal range, and provide a more variety of sound sets, which set is played could depend on their state (like whether they have targetted a player or standing idle). The same ruleset could be applied to all the creatures.

There should have been at least some kind of skill system, perhaps a simpler version of Fallout style skills. Being that in Last Light, you start out already a Ranger, the skill set you have would be something equivalent to what it would have looked like when a player has reached the ending of Metro 2033.

To a limited extent, weapons should have been moddable while outside stations, like being able to install/remove scopes and muzzle devices from both equipped weapons and guns laying on the ground. I know this is addressed in Metro Exodus, but I only mention this to highlight something I see as a negative to the overall gameplay experience.

The game is mostly good but in ranger hardcore difficulty is ridiculously bad designed and I'm not willing to start over. The problem is ammo, basically. You can take care of your ammo all you want but there are sections of the game with boss fights and where you have to fight waves of enemies that are basically next to each other, and it's almost impossible not to waste bullets and eventually run of of ammo.

Using grenades and knives can help but playing on PC, the controls for switching from one to the other are very unresponsive and enemies attack hard and fast, so you'll get hit a lot, and use your medkits very quickly.

Worst yet, there are certain kinds of weapons that you rarely find, like handguns for example, meaning you might have handgun ammo but not find a single one in hours! So, you'll sell your handgun bullets to buy other kinds of bullets for a very low exchange rate.

Do not play it on ranger hardcore, even if you played 2033 in that difficulty without any issues (like I did). The game was clearly not designed for it

So I played this right after I finished 2033 Redux. It was a huge upgrade over the first game, every aspect of it is better. One improvement I really like is that stealth can now be toggled and there are now proper stealth levels, though it's not perfect, some areas were really frustrating,

Story-wise it's good, it picks up right after the ending of the previous one. I was confused with happened in the events of the first game but the whole plot makes sense now after playing this.

Like in 2033, I really like all the characters but it felt like the interactions with your companions have dropped down in the second half. Still, all the side characters are great and they are the ones that makes the bleak world of Metro alive.

I didn't get the good/canon ending and the game itself is not something I would want to replay but still, it's good. I would recommend anyone to play this at least once.

[h1]tl;dr[/h1]

I had it originally as a thumbs down and I'll leave it as that even though I'll recommend it.

The reason I had it as a thumbs down initially is there's a few very annoying issues with the game but over all it's worth playing.  

[h1]pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Enjoyable story
[*] Nice art direction
[*] Decent graphics
[*] Decent voice acting
[*] Game play is pretty fun
[/list]

[h1]cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] Facial graphics weren't very good. Mostly you don't notice it but some times it's really jarring.  Like a romantic scene looked just goofy because of the facial animation/graphics.
[*] Voice acting isn't consistent.  Artyom is great and a few of the others are too. But some of the other voice actors you can hear them slip in and out of the Russian accent.
[*] Confusing maps.  Some of the areas are confusing and it's hard to determine where you're supposed to go.  This isn't normally an issue ("oh no! you had to wander longer!") but this does matter when you have a limited time you're allowed to explore or you die (bad air requires filters, these confusing areas are in areas where there's bad air so you'll go through filters fast).  If you don't get lost or confused on where to go, this is not an issue.  I only had this issue on three areas and it only was a huge problem once.  But this combined with the next problem is what caused me to almost quit playing this game.
[*] Save spots don't care how much ammo or filters you have.  So what happened to me which made me almost quit the game was I had two maps in a row where I wasn't sure where to go and used all my filters and had only like 20 seconds left of air and it saved right before a mini boss battle.  Welp, it was impossible no matter how many times I played it since the boss would take a couple of minutes at least to kill when I had 20 seconds.  Only solution I could find online since others had this same problem: Restart the chapter. I was about to quit the game because I didn't want to play a lot of it over, but I discovered the chapter start was less than 5 minutes behind where I was anyways so I played it again.  But it still annoyed the heck outta me.  The game should've really had a minimum of ammo and filters you can have when it loads up a save point.  So if you're at a save point and you have 30 seconds left, it should default you to like 3-4 minutes of air.  If you have 0 ammo, it should default to some.
[*] Other confusing parts.  Near the end you're told to stop a tank but you're not sure exactly how you're gonna fight a tank with normal bullets from far away.  You shoot at the place where you THINK you're supposed to but nothing happens.  I did this many times and it just doesn't work so I finally looked it up.  Turns out you don't shoot there, you shoot elsewhere, somewhere where it isn't that obvious.  But as a hint, if you're stuck, look all around the tank and see if any part is colored slightly different and shoot that part, and then the other parts that become that color.  It would've helped if one of the other guys mentioned what to do instead of "stop the tank" where shooting at 95% of the tank does nothing.
[*] How to get the "good" ending.  Well, I found this out very late, the good ending depends on "moral points".  You can get a lot of "moral points" from 2 major decisions in the game and from another action you can take on your own.  But doing just those isn't enough.  You have to get plenty others which is annoying because moral points can be things like "knock out those guys", "avoid battle with those guys", "find secret location here", "listen to that dialogue all the way thru".  If you want to, it's basically be as "good guy" as you can, search all areas, listen to all dialogues.
[/list]

I can't recommend it. It's a good game when it works; but that's when it works. This review is based on my experience alone with the game; and I can't say it worked by any means.

I'm playing on Hardcore - and have done so before, when this game was previously available on the Discord Store. Completed it there, bought it here to play through again. 

This time however it seems the game really didn't want me to complete  it; a few chapters in (Bandits) the entire prompt system for knocking out / killing an enemy just stopped working. So the entire moral point system for being stealthy just gets thrown out the window, because the only thing I can do is shoot from here on. I tried messing with save files, I tried restarting from previous chapters (Revolution, Regina) but it always seems to break. I daren't try replaying the entire game just for it to break again. Point is; if there's a fix you can search for online, I've tried it.

Furthermore, it seems to not only be an issue with Last Light Redux, but also 2033 Redux, and even Exodus! I'm not really sure whats going on behind the scenes, but I doubt it will ever get fixed. I'm permanently locked out of the good ending here.

If I manage to fix it, I will update this review with the steps I took so other players can hopefully get out of the same mess.

I loved Metro 2033. It's my Showcase here on Steam. The dark, haunting story matched the frightening gameplay, and the killer music still leaves me ringing. Metro: Last Light is a worthy sequel in that regard. About 12 hours of play continues the same deep story, with similar game mechanics and an eerie soundtrack. Play it for the story and you will not be disappointed.

But play it for the gameplay... I have a few minor complaints. In order to continue the perhaps overly complicated storyline, Last Light featured several cinematic sections where you walk and talk for exposition. Obligatory cinematics make a game feel like a movie, stealing time from gameplay itself.

I also fought more humans than monsters. That may have been a commentary on how we humans, the species who destroyed the world in a nuclear war, are the real monsters. Fighting humans also gave the stealth levels more emphasis, which I unfortunately found tedious.

And I did not find the bonus levels very fun, so I didn't bother finishing them.

Again, these are not major complaints. I still wandered Metro and the wasteland with my trusty shotgun, shooting everything in sight. [spoiler]That method will get you the "bad" ending, but hey, I never said I was a hero.[/spoiler] And I had 1.5 heart attacks from jumpscares, so Last Light gave me what I wanted, for the most part.

8/10, if it's hostile, you kill it. C'est la vie.

A great successor to Metro 2033!

I did experience some bugs at random times. The game would minimize itself at startup and refuse to focus, only after letting it run in the background for a good few minutes would it focus and stay focused. I only actually had the game crash once and never experienced any bugs in gameplay.

As for the actual game itself, it's phenomenal! The story telling is great, the game is neatly balanced between being a linear storyteller and a semi-open world allowing you to veer off into some arbitrary room to loot or have some enriching experience [spoiler](like a flashback into the past, looking at the bombs falling through an apartment window)[/spoiler]. You feel connected to the characters, especially in a time like this (for the really late ones, this review was written during the COVID-19 pandemic) the feeling of being isolated to a safehaven (IRL the safety of your own home, in-game the underground) is actually enhancing to the experience.

In most similarly styled games (TLoU, Resident Evil, Chernobylite), the mobs i.e. zombies or indeed mutants are "just there". They don't really have any reason for existing, they just do for the sake of having something to kill. In Metro this feeling was not there for me at all. It feels very imminent, everytime you step outside the sense of immediate danger always hits back just as hard if not harder. The world isn't "ours" anymore, we do not own the surface and the Earth has turned on us..

PROs:
- Amazing storytelling
- Linear / semi-open world allowing for minor exploration
- Compelling environment
- No "be the hero" characters, just survival

CONs:
- Sometimes minimizes itself at launch, will work after running in the background for a few minutes
- NPCs during "follow him/her" objectives are [i]so god damn slow[/i]
- Some objectives can feel a bit tedious and pointless.

Playable in more than one style, Metro Last light Redux really is whatever the player wants it to be (In the realm of reality, of course. It's not a farming sim). The combat in Metro Redux may be sightly under optimized (The Grenade throwing in particular), but it still holds up today as a more tactical shooter, or full on guns blazing in Ranger mode. In short: I loved it for the story and the gameplay, but the combat may be a strong turn of for some people; Highly Recommend for FPS player and those  who simply enjoy Post-Apocalyptic terrain.

Better than 2033 and not as good as Exodus. I write this review having beaten all 3 games, which may be a unique perspective to anyone who may read this. Love the story of this game and was much easier to follow than 2033's story. Graphics are solid but not as good as exodus. Overall, I say Last Light's story is the best of the 3 games with Exodus being very close in that regard. Gunplay is good, and the support characters are phenomenal. I'll give this a 9/10, as it is definitely deserving of the rating and is a great game all around.
This game is one of the best story I ever played ─▒n my life. You should absolutely try this game.

This is honestly one of the most enjoyable FPS series I have found in a while. I picked up the trilogy on sale a while back and recently loaded up the first game Metro 2033... I got hooked and played the whole thing, including getting 100% achievements in about a week and immediately moved on to the second installment, Metro Last Light.

Everything I loved about the Metro 2033 Redux has been improved upon, expanded upon, and made tighter and sharper in Metro Last Light Redux. The light stealth elements become more important and more fun. The weapons and weapon customization is more robust and the addition of new weapons like sniper rifles gives you more choices in how you want to play. 

The story is deeper, more sinister, and more engaging. The maps are larger, more varied, and more exciting (albeit still a little too linear in some aspects). 

I have blazed through the game and after roughly 30 hours I have gotten all of the main story achievements and am moving on to the DLCs next. 

While I wouldn't say the this game stands up to modern FPS games, it IS one of the best last-gen games I have played and was a joy from start to finish. And I am super excited to play the next installment in the series, Metro Exodus, as soon as I finish.
Accomplished the difficult task of being a sequel to 2033. Expectations were high and 4A Games did not disappoint.

While first game was lacking in terms of plot and it's progression, normal animations, characters, this one - is better in everything.
Story is not based on a book, but it was co-written with an author of Metro. This time 4A Games had a success with overall feel of the game. It was not rushed anymore, had much more events, levels and interesting sequences. I felt that this one is 3 times longer than previous.
Environments, visuals, characters, presentation, story, variety of basically any aspect - everything is a big step-up.
Two flaws I found: no way of changing Field of View and non-skippable movies (can be fixed manually).
Haven't played Exodus yet, but I can totally recommend to enjoy Last Light, a solid buy.
Great game but the weakest of the trilogy.  It has a lot of free DLC though so it could be considered better than 2033 for that reason.

Atmosphere - 5/5
Characters - 4/5
Gameplay - 4/5

Unlike 2033, this redux is just a slight texture update, so you don't have to choose between atmosphere and gameplay like with the 2033 redux.

- Story is a bit better (more complex) then in 2033, but still the main focus is on the life in metro stations and its people. Khan character is somewhat weak written and demistified. He still knows the metro's misteries and lore, but I couldn't get through the fact that he knows that the Dark ones are good, even calls them angels. While he never says how does he know. Which is kinda distracting. I am not a big fan of the design change from the original 2033, but at least the characters are distinguishable. Oh and yes, Ar┼еom gets a girlfriend in this one and while everyone has a problem with her changing from hostile to lover character too quickly, I am not even sure I understand why is she hostile towards the main guy in the first place. But those are the biggest minuses of the game.

- Gameplay didn't change, but it was improved and polished. Some new weapons were added. There are more levels above the ground this time, but the great level DLCs bring you back to the dark, claustrophobic tunnels you haven't visited before. What I had a problem with regarding gameplay, is how the good/bad endings are determined. Basically you will only get the good ending if you let every ars*hole live. Which feels really forced. Other than than it is a good game.

Very short game compared to modern titles but one of the more unique games I've played recently. Still very playable in 2021.

Really liked the story & the game play mechanics are very satisfying. Especially if you find yourself frustrated with how forgiving a lot of shooters are these days. I found this to be a perfect balance where there is a lot of challenge to be had & you need to manage your resources well on most difficulty settings but it isn't just a frustrating grind. When you get something done in this game there is for sure a sense of satisfaction that is lacking in a lot of the big titles.

Most of all though I was surprised at how much this game made me think towards the end. Without spoiling anything some choices come up that I did not realize we're choices and they made me reflect on human nature & gut reactions based on our preconceived notions for a good minute. I got the impression that was intentional and I really love that in a game. I think when a game can make you feel & reflect on something like that with relatively indirect story telling that elevates it to the level of an artform. Playing this I felt uneasy, fear, accomplishment, sad at times, & even a little disappointed in my choices. Pretty much everything I would be looking for from a survival shooter with horror elements.

My only real critique for the game is that it is short & would benefit from being a little less on rails (yes yes) so I might say get it when it's on sale. I'm very excited to play the latest installment and see what improvements were made.

Metro Last Light Redux was a action-packed journey in post apocalyptic Russia. I wanted to play this game as I recently got Metro Exodus and wanted a short but fun game to fill the time. All in all, it was really good playing as Artyom again after several years :)
[h1] The Good [/h1]
+ The remaster really had me taking a lot of screenshots because of some scenes (Did not look like an old game at all!)
+ Action-pack scenarios (shooting radioactive wildlife on sec and then riding on trains the next!)
+ Gameplay option based on preference (spartan for more action and survival for more resource management)
+ Each town/hub location is memorable - the townspeople have their own stories which you can hear when you pass by
+ Plenty of weapon selections

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
- I didn't really like the Dark ones story. I think Metro is strongest when it focuses on the more human aspects of the story rather than the fictional.
- Weapon customization is limited
- Night vision goggles made me dizzy at times


Overall, this is an easy recommend if you want to play a linear shooter with a memorable story!

Best linear FPS story game I've played. I didn't think it could top Metro 2033, but it absolutely did.

One of the games that rewards exploration the most. I am a sucker for Lore and story, and this game oozes with soul, if you take your time, and let your curiosity and senses lead you away from the path forward. Listen to the Metro's inhabitants stories and scavenge your surroundings. More often than not, you're rewarded for it.

Top notch gun-play and stealth mechanics as well. It's a lot of fun to be Batman, thinning out a group of opponents, without them ever seeing you.

Slight spoiler: The ending WILL change depending on your actions, your immersion, and your innate ability to sense points of interest away from the beaten path.

Pros: You can tell a lot of love went into this game. They did a GREAT job with the story, the characters, dialogue, and immersive world building. I think the pacing was great. There are some truly terrifying survival horror elements but it's not overbearing.

 Despite being almost 7 years old the overall look of the game still holds up really well. 

Cons: *rant* The controls are pretty terrible. They are very 'tanky' and the player moves excruciatingly slow on almost all fronts. It takes forever to throw a knife, reload your weapon, throw a grenade, melee, etc. I think the delay is there by design so you have to plan ahead before you do anything (kind of like Dark Souls 3), but it just feels poorly executed. Quite often you will find yourself getting swarmed by fast moving enemies and there is a NOTICEABLE LACK OF URGENCY in the main character's movements that will make you want to throw your keyboard across the room.  

Also, there is a lot of debris in the post-apocalyptic world and poorly placed collision geometry to go along with it.

[b][u]Story[/u][/b]: 8/10 - A better paced story with new elements integrating with the actual threat of the mutants 
[b][u]Graphics[/u][/b]: 8/10 - Loved the way how lighting is handled. Weather effects are so much better than the prequel.
[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]: 9/10 - A good mixture of survival, stealth, shooter, and atmospheric horror. Your choices matter throughout the game and will affect the ending.
[b][u]Level Design[/u][/b]: 7/10 - Levels designed above the metro are more fun and challenging.
[b][u]Sound/Music[/u][/b]: 8/10 - OST is just okay. Gun sounds are the same as the first one. The sounds of mutants outside and the weather are nicely done.  
[b][u]Performance[/u][/b]: 9/10 - No issues here. Ran consistently at 60fps on low-medium settings.


[h1][b][u]Overall[/u][/b][/h1] 8/10 - If you liked the first one, you'll like this one as well.

[h1]Metro Last Light[/h1]
With my complete experience, I'm about to share my thoughts about Metro Last Light, which is followed by novel from Dimitry Glukhovsky. In my opinion, Metro Last Light is merely a successful contender that continues the story with the same tension, immersion just as Metro 2033 did. Now let me talk about it much more openly.

[i]10.0/10.0, Entirely exhilarating continuation of the story with more fiercest survival experience[/i]

[h1]Story[/h1]
First of all, Metro Last Light continues the further story where Metro 2033 dropped off. Through the story, you have to survive a widespread complicated journey for making amends which makes the main character and his fierce story more ambitious and sharp. Also all the characters are well developed and will be growing in you. Besides, there are lots of unexpected complications to immense the lore of the story. So this is how the story continues and embarks. After all this, there's always a message for us through it.

[h1]Gameplay and more[/h1]
This is almost same as their last wing, Metro 2033. Like FPS genre with challenging combat, insecure situations and subduing atmospheres. But for challenging combat, you've got capable weapons like Shambler, Kalash and much more. Also you'll have lots of equipment for strategical approach. But if you aren't into conflicts then you're welcome to stealth approach most of the times. Like you can complete most parts without even killing anyone which takes unimaginable patience and tactics. 

About collectibles and more, there are tons of collectibles around you. Like ammunition, equipment, additional things. In that post-apocalyptic world, Collectibles won't be your choice, that would be essential for you. But your difficulty mode matters strictly here.

[h1]Visuals and more[/h1]
Visuals, this actually apprehends initial preface for immersive atmospheres. Visuals are definitely beautiful even more after Redux. Surely, Redux's been more improved and detailed for better experience. Even facial expressions and textures has been reworked. So i have nothing to yammer about visuals.

[h1]Soundtracks[/h1]
For creating the immersion, we need atmospheric and intensive background scores and i'm pretty aware that Metro Last Light has it. Composers affiliated every situations with perfect soundtracks. All those soundtracks would lift your survival experience into another level.

[h1]Impressions[/h1]
Metro Last Light has absolute enormous storyline with extreme plots which might pop up your jaw. For fierce experience, this has very complex gameplay and subduing atmospheres. Also, your journey will be very comprehensive because there are tons of chapters for you.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]
Obviously, I'm completely recommending it. I'd suggest you to start from Metro 2033 and then this one which is the chronological order. Back in 2015, I completed it for first time and I didn't even know that it wasn't the first, It's actually a sequel.

This game is the sequel to Metro 2033, It is recommended that you play it first.

A simple way to sum up this game is atmospheric, apocalyptic Russia with an epic story and gameplay that is good, but not Call of Duty's gunplay. It is more clunky and it makes you feel like a survivor in Moscow, not a tough Soldier.

One of the greatest sequels I have seen, you have to played it if you completed the first one. It expands on the story left behind from the first one it also adds many thing that you must experience on you┬┤re own. Good luck.

It was pretty good, not as good as Metro 2033, mind you.

I don't like how the story tried to make us sympathize with the Dark Ones. In the first game, they openly kill other humans and they directly threaten Artyom (which gives us the iconic line, 'If it's hostile, kill it') and the first time we see them in this game, it's a shot of them tricking a crew of humans into killing each other. Not exactly the best way to portray them if you wanted the player to like them.

Also, I'm confused about Khan and Anna. Khan was this magic mystery guy that shows up just when you need him, and we get no other information on him ever, and barely even get to learn anything about him. Where did he come from? Why can he do all these things? Originally, I thought he was a Dark One himself, but nope. I wish we could have got more out of him, but nope. This is one of the characters where the mystery isn't enough to satisfy me. 

Also, Anna gets sidelined really early on, which sucks. She's supposed to be this badass sniper, but she can't take out a crew of Reich guys and it gets the player captured. Then we see her later on, for two minutes before she gets captured, and then she ends up fucking Artyom after another two minutes of them talking, and then she dips out, and doesn't even show up to fight at D6, when her skills could have been very useful. It just feels like she could have been so much more, but she shows up, has his kid, and game ends. I probably wouldn't even be mad about this romance if we had seen more scenes of her and Artyom bonding.

Metro Last Light Redux is the sequel to Metro 2033 Redux, overall, it is very similar gameplaywise, and I highly recommend playing 2033 before Last Light if you can (especially to understand the plot, as it's a direct sequel)

There are a few changes to how the game presents itself that aren't bad, but they are different, and they bear mentioning. Last Light is more bombastic and action focused, while 2033 was slower outside a few exceptions. 2033 very rarely required you to fight human enemies toe to toe (allowing stealthy ways around) Last Light will make you fight more often, which could be a problem for some people. Overall it wasn't too bad for myself, because I often use a mixture of stealth and combat, but there were one or two situations that it definitely put me in a bind (once on a moving train and another in the red square, fair warning, if you're playing on ranger hardcore, which I still recommend you do, keep your head down and play smart in those parts) That said, there are also some more exploration based sections that I find to be significantly more compelling than things in 2033, Overall, there's a little more in both directions, and both are good. 

Similar to this, the story has become both more juvenile and more mature. With it pushing big bouncing russian boobies in your face on a few occasions (including a mandatory not-quite sex scene), but on the other hand having a pretty mature plot about war in the post apocalypse, and seeking forgiveness from people you've wronged, trying to do the right thing, ETC. If you can ignore the stupid parts, the rest of it is very compelling, and a definite step up from the "stop the dark ones" plot in 2033.

I enjoyed Last Light a lot, and, if I had to think about it, I'd probably replay it over 2033, although they're very close. Last Light has a few changes some people might be less tolerant of than others, but overall I still think it's a good experience, and I look forward to playing Metro Exodus when the Enhanced edition comes out in a few days, Strong Recommend to fans of 2033.

TL;DR: DONT BUY METRO:EXODUS. IT IS TRASH.

This is one of those titles that proves videogames as an artform.
The plot is amazing, the side conversations add depth to the surroundings, and all the little details in each station tell a different story of what life would be like there. It's also always fun to find hidden content.

This is a story of damnation and redemption.
Its an epic of the most radiant good, and the darkest evil.
The entire metro is anxious, all whisper of uncertain rumors surrounding the contents of the doomsday bunker D6.
The only thing that is certain, is war.

In this installment, [spoiler]it is made canon that artyom condemns the entire race of dark ones to nuclear extermination;
except one. 
Will artyom finish what he started? Or will he earn his, and all humanities, forgiveness? [/spoiler]

The DLC is well worth the price, major huge dank chron props to the developers (WHO CLEARLY WERE FIRED AND DID NOT GET TO MAKE EXODUS ), for maintaining a careful, often downright impossible, balance between two political extremes. Also without excessively painting one as worse than the other.

You can defend the proud and glorious reich in the Front Line DLC, mowing down hordes of communists (rare these days)
You can also infiltrate the reich as the sneaky, subversive reds (not so rare) in the Sniper Team DLC. Featuring the VSK sniper rifle.
Theres a spartan training mission, where you collect supplies and resources for the underground, it gets progressively difficult.
They even have a mission for pavel and anna too!
Consider this where metro left off, they havent actually made a metro game after this. Some people say they did, but those peoples standards are low, and they let bad games get published because they'll buy it. 
Look at star wars. It sucks because people bought in to the mediocrity. 
Anything i forgot is just a bonus for you, now buy it!
AND DONT (EVER) BUY EXODUS. Trust me, just read the book, i wish i did that and never spent a dime on that waste of gigs.
i didn't understand much of the several plots going on and jumping between one another, but entertaining game over all, 7/10 would recommend i guess, don't think i will replay it, worth the price tho

Metro Last Light builds on Metro 2033's world-building tenfold, and brings even more atmosphere to an already extremely atmospheric game series.

The story is fantastic, and it really plays into the dark dystopia that these citizens have to experience. There's more subtle dialog, more locations to explore and many more ways to get immersed.

The gunplay, environments and gameplay have evolved and still hold up great today. The DLC levels are a nice addition, short but nice little filler levels. 

I have experienced some crashes but otherwise the game performs fantastically, and still looks fantastic to this day.

Play this if you enjoyed 2033, or if you find it cool. Odds are it actually is cool to you.

Metro 2033 Last Light Redux is a perfect continuation of the first game. It expands the universe of the story, takes over and improves some characters, puts better, more developed and different action scenes than in the first game. In the first game of the franchise it was very common to know that there would be a scene or chapter that was very similar to the previous one, since the whole narrative was very similar. In this second game we really don't know what comes next: the story is much richer, full of details, with characters that are more engaging or better developed. As much as it has more or less the same amount of hours of gameplay as the first game in the franchise, it is much more worth it, as it improves the development of the game universe! It took about 12 hours to finish the game, very well developed, with a surprising and action-packed ending!

Like Metro 2033, Metro: Last Light is based on, and inspired by the Novels from Dmitri Gluchowski. The game definitely gave me the urge to read the Novels myself now and to dive even deeper into the lore and world of the Metro Universe.
Once again you slip into the shoes of Artyom, who became a full Ranger after fulfilling his mission successfully at the end of Metro 2033. Last Light takes part after the 2033 ending in which the Dark Ones were eradicated by a Missile Strike. 
      
Or were they? What starts as an easy mission to confirm a sighting of a last Dark One, turns into a mission to prevent the Metro from a grim dark fate which could ultimately lead to the death of every last remaining human. 
Your journey leads you through vast tunnel systems, friendly and hostile stations and long forgotten claustrophobic passage ways. And of course, there a lot and lots of spiders!
As a difference to Metro 2033, a large part of Last Light takes place above ground, you will see a lot of the Ruins of Moscow and what happened to the city after the bombs fell. 
4A Games did a fantastic job again with the level building the style of the environments you pass through and the atmosphere of the game. You really get a good feeling for the game world and the characters and their goals and feelings. 
4A nailed the тАЬthis feels so realтАЭ feeling once more in my opinion.
   
Beside the fantastic main game, the Redux version of Metro: Last Light contains 9 dlc levels, which are the following.:
->Heavy Squad: It was okay, more or less a 10 Minute shooting gallery with annoying boss fight. 
 ->Sniper Team: An enjoyable stealth experience in which you infiltrate an enemy base as a Sniper.  (Surprise!)
->Kshatriya: Quite a lot to this one. You are a scavenger and progress through the level and unlock new Guns/Areas on your way. 
->Spider Lair: Spiders, Spiders and even more Spiders. Did I mention mutated Spiders?
->The Tower: Very Hard Wave Mode DLC with a wide variety of weapons to choose from.
->Pavel: As Pavel you have to escape a Reich base after getting captured. Either stealth your way through or go in all guns blazing. 
->Khan: Quick journey into KahnтАЩs past and one of his key experiences from his perspective.
->Anna: The first mission of the Game from AnnaтАЩs point of view
->Developer level: To play and toy around with 

Like Metro 2033, Metro: Last Light is a great, atmospheric shooter experience you donтАЩt want to miss out on. 
Like 2033 though, Last Light is once again not a game for people with Arachnophobia, Spiders are everywhere and you often also have to deal with gross mutations of them.

The gaming universe of Metro 2033 has always been based on two main principles: on the one hand, every time we are shown the decline of civilization with all the accompanying horrors, and on the other, there is always some glimmer of light in this hopelessness, something good at the end of the adventure. This "good" is not always achievable, but the hope that guides the protagonist is captivating and intriguing. This statement is also true for Metro: Last Light - from the very first moments, the sequel begins to take the soul. After a difficult introductory video, which can be safely attributed to one of the most impressive moments of the game, you begin to fully understand how imaginary human superiority is and how quickly a personality can degrade. One press of the button - and the whole planet plunged into chaos, and humanity was on the verge of extinction. Sincere emotions evoked by the unique atmosphere are the most amazing thing in the game. The world, twisted by a nuclear catastrophe, still makes an impression, and the excellent musical accompaniment only enhances it. The environment looks extremely dignified: solid graphics, well-built lighting, competent design solutions, as well as serious attention to detail - all this contributes to a deeper immersion in the world of the game you want to believe in. In addition, the developers have brought to mind the stealth, polished the gameplay, tightened the animation, improved the impact and added customization of the weapon (compared to the original in 2010). Metro: Last Light masterfully combines bouncy linear stretches with the ability to explore dungeons and surfaces, spectacular staged runs coexist with the relative freedom of large levels. At the same time, the player is not forced to stealth or a power approach, instead offering to combine them in the desired proportions. The local history has transformed from a depressing parable into a kind of action adventure, the plot develops very dynamically and, one might say, there is a certain epic character. As a result, despite the shortcomings of artificial intelligence and flaws of a technical nature, the positive aspects seem to be more numerous and significant, which makes it possible to put the game 9/10 - the continuation managed to do the main thing - to improve the original in all respects and at the same time not to lose everything that it was for. so loved by the players. And this, in my opinion, is the main hallmark of an exemplary sequel.

One of the best games I've ever played. Stealth, monsters, and a beautiful environment. I think this one is much better than Metro Exodus, even though it is much more linear. None of the levels are repetitive and offer new types of gameplay. This is the strongest point of the game. You will find yourself going from stealth in Reich bases, to underground rail systems, and then find yourself in dangerous monster infested catacombs. Loved this game and finished it in two days.

Great game, it really took the themes of the first game (Metro 2033 / Redux) and expanded them. A first-person horror game and shooter that features a morality system is such a great combination. You really have to decide what's more important to you as a person; your own safety and sense of security, or doing the right thing. 

Of course it's easy to make the right choice when you're in an armchair being asked about a trolley problem or a "what if" scenario. But when you're in the thick of it, in that fight or flight mode, do you still make the "moral" decision? Is the moral decision always so obvious?

Metro: Last Light is the sequel to Metro 2033 (duh)
It was sitting in my library until a friend of mine gifted me Exodus, so i knew i had to install & finish this game before playing that. Having played the 2033 in 2013 and Redux version in 2017 respectively, I completely forgot how it feels to finish a Metro game. And let me tell you, you're in for a ride! It's a great run with great atmosphere, always keeps you on your toes just a second after you started relaxing by throwing you noises or creatures at you. Story is interesting enough for you to ask for more, and graphics on the other hand... My, my, my, my, my, my, my. I've never expected a game that came out in 2014 to be this beautiful! The environment is extremely rich and immersive, underground metros are depicted as warm and comforting and a little bit of dirt on top of it; politics, corruption, poverty and such... And surface being a cold, dead wasteland that you never want to step in unless you absolutely have to... Enough to send shivers down your spine! I was already in love with Metro Franchise's soundtrack, so i won't make a comment about that. My only complaint would be not-so-frequent crashes (that i still don't know the reason of) and weird AI -not game breaking but rather immersion breaking. Definitely recommended though, the whole Metro Franchise is one big gold piece.
